    Organic Electrode Materials for Metal Ion Batteries

    • John J. Shea
      John J. Shea
      Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, George Mason University, Fairfax, Virginia 22030, United States
      More by John J. Shea
      http://orcid.org/0000-0003-2146-2477
      •  and 
    • Chao Luo*
      Chao Luo
      Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, George Mason University, Fairfax, Virginia 22030, United States
      *Email: [email protected]
      More by Chao Luo
      http://orcid.org/0000-0001-8497-8548
    Cite this: ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2020, 12, 5, 5361–5380
    Publication Date (Web):January 9, 2020

    Publication History

    • Accepted9 January 2020
    • Published online9 January 2020
    • Published inissue 5 February 2020
    https://doi-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/10.1021/acsami.9b20384

    SUBJECTS:
    • Ions,
    • Electrodes,
    • Carbonyls,
    • Batteries,
    • Polymers
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Organic and polymer materials have been extensively investigated as electrode materials for rechargeable batteries because of the low cost, abundance, environmental benignity, and high sustainability. To date, organic electrode materials have been applied in a large variety of energy storage devices, including nonaqueous Li-ion, Na-ion, K-ion, dual-ion, multivalent-metal, aqueous, all-solid-state, and redox flow batteries, because of the universal properties of organic electrode materials. Moreover, some organic materials enable the batteries to be operated in the extreme conditions, such as a wide temperature range (−70 to 150 °C), a wide pH range, and in the presence of O2. As a guidance for the research in organic batteries, this Review focuses on the reaction mechanisms and applications of organic electrode materials. Six categories of reaction mechanisms and the applications of organic and polymer materials in various rechargeable batteries are discussed to provide an overview of the state-of-the-art organic batteries.

    KEYWORDS:
    • organic electrode materials
    • rechargeable batteries
    • energy storage
    • polymer materials
    • organic batteries
    • reaction mechanisms

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Lithium ion batteries (LIBs) as the dominant energy storage devices for portable electronics are also the main power supply for electric vehicles and smart grids. The large-scale applications of LIBs in electric vehicles stimulates the consumption of electrode materials. However, the conventional LIBs consist of inorganic electrode materials, such as LiCoO2, LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2, and graphite, the manufacture and recycle of which release a huge amount of CO2 and requires massive energy consumption. (1) Moreover, the toxic heavy metal (Co) from the LIB cathode could induce severe environmental pollution. Therefore, to circumvent the negative environmental impact, it is of great importance to search for green and sustainable materials as substitutions for inorganic electrode materials in rechargeable batteries.
    Organic electrode materials (OEMs), which could be derived from biomass, are promising candidates for green and sustainable LIBs because of the low cost, abundance, environmental benignity, high sustainability, and recyclability of organic compounds. (2,3) As it is well-known, the photosynthesis of biomass gains solar energy and converts CO2 to organic compounds, which could balance the energy consumption and CO2 release during the battery production and recycle, and eventually achieve a CO2 free and energy consumption free process for the manufacture and recycle of LIBs. (2) The advantages of OEMs have attracted considerable research interests from the battery field, and remarkable efforts have been devoted to designing and synthesizing advanced OEMs. In addition to OEMs from biomass, a large number of OEMs from the fine chemical industry are also developed for LIBs because of the low cost, abundance, and high sustainability. To date, OEMs have been applied in all kinds of rechargeable batteries, including nonaqueous Li-ion, Na-ion, K-ion, dual-ion batteries, multivalent metal batteries, aqueous batteries, all-solid-state batteries, redox flow batteries, and can be used under extreme conditions, such as high temperature, low temperature, high pH value, low pH value, atmosphere (with/without O2). (4−8) Moreover, apart from small molecules, polymers, polymer frameworks, and 2D organic materials can also be used as OEMs in organic batteries. (9−11) Though great success has been achieved for OEMs, there are still two major challenges in organic batteries: (1) the low electronic conductivity of OEMs limits the reaction kinetics of organic batteries and (2) the high solubility of OEMs in the electrolyte results in fast capacity fading.
    Considerable research efforts have been devoted to overcoming these two challenges in organic batteries. To date, the development and applications of OEMs in nonaqueous alkali-ion batteries and all-solid-state batteries were summarized by a number of exceptional reviews. (12−16) In contrast to previous reviews, this Review not only covers the fundamental reaction mechanisms of OEMs in metal ion batteries but also comments the applications of OEMs in dual-ion batteries, multivalent metal batteries, aqueous batteries, all-solid-state batteries, redox flow batteries and the extreme conditions. The commercial LIBs consist of inorganic cathode and anode, providing an energy density of 250 Wh kg–1. The electrochemical performance of OEMs in LIBs cannot compete with inorganic materials, in terms of energy density and cycle life. However, the performance of OEMs in dual-ion, multivalent metal, aqueous, all-solid-state, and redox flow batteries is competitive or even better than that of inorganic materials, so it is important to highlight and point out the future research directions of organic batteries, which should be beyond LIBs. More importantly, OEMs exhibit exceptional performances in rechargeable batteries under extreme conditions, such as wide temperature ranges (−70 to 150 °C), wide pH ranges, and the presence of O2, which is also an important research direction of organic batteries. This Review will shed light on the future research of organic batteries and attract more interests toward OEMs in rechargeable batteries beyond LIBs.
    In this Review, we discussed six types of reactions by classifying the functional groups of OEMs, which cover most of reaction mechanisms in organic batteries. The methods used to overcome the challenges in organic batteries were discussed in each reaction mechanism. Figure 1 summarizes the six types of reaction mechanisms for OEMs. In the disulfide and azo reactions, organic compounds reversibly react with metal ions, followed with the dissociation and formation of chemical bond, and the intramolecular electron transfer within the organic molecule is not necessary during the electrochemical redox reaction. In contrast, the intramolecular electron transfer exists in the carbonyl and imine reactions. During the reactions between O in carbonyl group/N in imine group and Li-ions, carbon free radicals will be generated as intermediates. To stabilize carbon free radicals, the rearrangement of the carbon–carbon double bonds in the conjugated structure is required to trigger the intramolecular electron transfer and form new carbon–carbon double bonds. The different reaction mechanisms require different structure design strategies. In the disulfide and azo reactions, only one functional group is needed to act as the electrochemical redox center for the battery charge and discharge, while in the carbonyl, imine, and superlithiation reactions, a conjugated structure is required to connect two or more electrochemical active sites to maintain the electrochemical performance of OEMs. The advantages and drawbacks of each reaction mechanism are summarized in Table 1. In the subsequent discussion, we will explain each reaction mechanism in detail using representative organic and polymer materials.
    Table 1. Advantages and Drawbacks of Six Categories of Reaction Mechanisms
    reaction mechanismadvantagesdrawbacks
    disulfide reaction (S–S)wide operating temperature rangelow potential as cathodes
    lack of lithium source as cathodes
    sluggish kinetics
    large steric hindrance
    high solubility in the electrolyte
    anion insertion reactionfast kineticslow electronic conductivity
    high potential as cathodeslow capacity
    high solubility in the electrolyte
    azo reaction (N═N)fast kineticshigh potential as anodes
    long cycle lifelow capacity
    low electronic conductivity
    carbonyl reaction (C═O)wide operating temperature rangelow potential as cathodes
    high capacitylack of lithium source as cathodes
    fast kineticslow electronic conductivity
    high solubility in the electrolyte
    imine reaction (C═N)high capacitylow potential as cathodes
    fast kineticslack of lithium source as cathodes
    low electronic conductivity
    high solubility in the electrolyte
    superlithiation reaction (unsaturated carbon–carbon group)low potential as anodeslow electronic conductivity
    high capacityhigh solubility in the electrolyte
    fast kinetics

    2. Reaction Mechanisms in Organic Batteries

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1. Disulfide Reaction

    The organosulfur compounds were introduced as positive electrode materials in rechargeable batteries by Visco et al. (17) The disulfide groups in organosulfur compounds (RS–SR) can reversibly react with sodium ions and electrons to generate the corresponding sodium thiolates (RS––Na+). The organosulfur electrodes can work in a wide temperature range from the ambient temperature to 150 °C. However, the organosulfur compounds are soluble in the electrolyte, resulting in poor cycle life. Moreover, the regeneration of the disulfide bond from thiolates is impeded by the large steric hindrance. To mitigate the large steric hindrance, disulfide groups are confined in the side chain of the anthracene in Figure 2, which benefits the reconnection of thiolates. (18) The organodisulfide cathode material based on anthracene can reversibly react with 6 Li+ and 6 electrons, accompanied by the dissociation and regeneration of disulfide bonds. However, this small molecule still suffers from high solubility and low conductivity challenges. To circumvent these challenges, a number of organosulfur polymers were synthesized. The polymerization of the small organosulfur compound remarkably decreases the solubility in the organic electrolyte and the confinement of disulfide group in the side chain of the polymer benefits the reconnection of thiolates. (19) Since then, the polyaniline derivatives and polyanthracene derivatives containing disulfide groups were reported as promising cathode materials in rechargeable lithium batteries. (18,20) The polyanthracene derivative contains a conjugated main chain structure, resulting in the good electronic conductivity. The confinement of thiolates by the main chain mitigates the steric hindrance of the regeneration of the disulfide bond. The polyanthracene derivative showed a high specific capacity of 300 mAh g–1 with a pair of reversible charge/discharge plateaus at ∼2.5 V during the second cycle. Further improvement is still needed to further reduce the solubility of the organosulfur polymer and enhance the reaction kinetics of the organosulfur polymer.
    Five selected disulfide group-based OEMs are shown in Figure 3 with the first cycle capacity, current density, and cycle number. In ABTH, disulfide groups are connected to anthracene, which contains three conjugated benzene rings. After adding more benzene rings to the conjugated structure, TTT and HTP exhibit higher specific capacity and longer cycle life, because of the stronger intermolecular interactions in the crystal form, which play a critical role in maintaining a better crystal structure during the battery cycling process. (21) In addition to enlarge the conjugated structure, the other way to improve the electrochemical performance is to polymerize small molecules. When the monomer (ABTH) is polymerized to form the polymer (PABTH), its initial capacity dramatically increases from 180 to 300 mAh g–1 because of the higher electric conductivity of the polymer. (18) Another example of the organosulfur polymer is PAPOD, which contains disulfide groups as cross-links in its polymer structure. (20) The polyaniline chain in PAPOD enhances the electric conductivity of the polymer, while cross-linking the polymer reduces its solubility in the electrolyte. Its initial capacity is higher than inorganic cathodes, but further improvement of the cyclic stability is still required.

    2.2. Anion Insertion Reaction

    The second reaction mechanism in organic batteries is the anion insertion reaction based on the nitroxide free radicals, heteroatoms and amino group. The nitroxide free radicals are bipolar organics, which can either gain Li-ions to be reduced to a negatively charged state or gain anions to be oxidized to a positively charged state. To illustrate the anion insertion reaction, Figure 4 shows the reaction between a free radical polymer and anions. As shown in Figure 4, the outer-shell electrons of the nitroxide radical are taken away at high reaction potentials to be oxidized to oxoammonium cations, and then bond with anions, such as PF6–, TFSI–, and ClO4–. (22) Since the free radicals are very electrochemically active species, the reaction kinetics between nitroxide radicals and anions is very fast, but the high solubility of free radical-based polymers results in self-discharge, which is a main drawback of free radical-based electrodes. To mitigate the dissolution, the nitroxide radical is attached to a polymer backbone, which is nonconductive and compromises the reaction kinetics of the electrodes. (23) However, the nitroxide free radical polymer is still soluble in the electrolyte, leading to the capacity fading. To completely avoid the dissolution of the nitroxide free radical polymer and improve the reaction kinetics, the nitroxide free radical polymer is anchored to insoluble inorganic frameworks, such as carbon nanotube, reduced graphene oxide, and graphene. (24) The resulting carbon/free radical composites exhibit excellent battery performance.
    2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxyl-4-yl (TEMPO) is the most prominent free radical compound containing the nitroxide radical so far. Most of organic free-radical polymers contain TEMPO as the electrochemical active site in the side chain. A decade ago, Oyaizu et al. synthesized a cross-linkable polynorbornene with the pendant TEMPO groups, exhibiting electrochemical behaviors in acetonitrile-based electrolyte. (25) Since the TEMPO-based polymer suffers from dissolution induced capacity decay, insoluble inorganic hosts, such as carbon nanotubes, reduced graphene oxide, and graphene, were used to achieve a stable TEMPO-based organic battery. (26,27) Kim et al. reported to encapsulate poly(2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidinyloxy-4-vinyl methacrylate) (PTMA) in the carbon nanotube, and the PTMA/carbon nanotube electrode displays two pairs of charge/discharge plateaus at 3.36 and 2.1 V with a reversible capacity of 222 mAh g–1 for 100 cycles. (22) Zhang et al. reported to stabilize pyrene-functionalized PTMA with reduced graphene oxide (rGO) via the π–π Stacking interaction between pyrene and rGO. (28) The resulting pyrene-functionalized PTMA/rGO composite exhibits fast charge rate (20C) and long cycle life (400 cycles) in LIBs. Therefore, the carbon framework stabilized organic radical polymers are promising electrode materials for rechargeable batteries.
    Though most of the other categories of organic cathode materials show a low discharge potential (2–3 V) and cannot provide lithium source, anion insertion reaction-based OEMs provide a new opportunity for developing high potential organic cathodes. In the anion insertion reaction, the anions, such as PF6–, TFSI–, ClO4–, are inserted into organic materials after the outer-shell electrons are taken away from the functional groups at high reaction potentials. (29−31) The reaction potential of the anion insertion reaction is above 3 V. (32,33) Since lithium ion is not required for the p-type active material, it can match with the other lithium ion insertion type anode materials to make a dual-ion full cell. (34)
    Here another example of the p-type organic cathode is discussed in detail. 5,12-Diaminorubicene (DARb) with two amino groups connected by a large conjugated structure is shown in Figure 5. (35) The two nitrogens in the amino groups of DARb lose two electrons step by step at high reaction potentials and then bond with two anions to form the neutral products, providing a theoretical capacity of 150 mAh g–1. The anion insertion reaction based on DARb also triggers the intramolecular electron transfer in the conjugated structure. The reaction potential of DARb is in the range from 3–4 V. The drawbacks of this p-type organic cathode are the low reversible capacity (<120 mAh g–1) and poor cycle life (60 cycles). Future work in synthesizing amino group-based conjugated polymers and using graphene or carbon nanotube as carbon additives is required to reduce the solubility of the organic material in the electrolyte and enhance the electric conductivity of the organic electrode.
    The heteroatom (S) containing polymer, polythianthrene, also acts as a p-type organic cathode to lose four outer-shell electrons at high reaction potentials and provide a high theoretical capacity of 388 mAh g–1. (36) To enable this anion insertion reaction, two or more thioether groups should be connected with a conjugated structure, such as a benzene ring. During the anion insertion process, intramolecular electron transfer is triggered in the conjugated structure, and each sulfur atom loses an electron and possesses a positive charge. The reaction potential of this polymer cathode is ∼4.1 V versus Li/Li+, which is comparable to the reaction potential of the inorganic cathodes. However, this organic cathode material only delivers a low specific capacity of 71 mAh g–1. Zhan et al. reported another thioether containing conjugative polymer (poly(tetrahydrobenzodi-thiophene)), which shows a high specific capacity about 560 mAh g–1 after 20 charge/discharge cycles. (37) The high capacity is attributed to the multielectron process of the reversible redox reaction on thioether bonds. More study is needed to improve the cyclic stability and understand the reaction mechanism of this anion insertion reaction. The high reaction potential of this type of metal-free organic cathodes are promising for dual-ion batteries.
    Other examples of the OEMs based on the anion insertion reaction are shown in Figure 6. The poly(3-vinyl-N-methylphenothiazine) (PVMPT), which contains nitrogen and sulfur in the side chain. (38) The tertiary amine and thioether groups in PVMPT can lose electrons and gain anions to form radical cations. The π–π interaction between the phenothiazine units stabilizes the radical cations. The reversible reaction of PVMPT provides a reversible capacity of 50 mAh g–1 at the high current density of 10 C. Though the capacity is low, PVMPT exhibits ultralong cycle life (10 000 cycles) and high rate capability up to 100 C. The success of PVMPT as an electrode material in rechargeable batteries provides a new strategy to design the organic cathode based on the π–π interaction.
    Apart from DARb, polythianthrene, and PVMPT, there are a lot of p-type OEMs (Figure 6) containing free radicals, amine, or thioether functional groups for rechargeable batteries. Though significant success has been achieved for the long cycle life and fast charge organic cathodes, the reversible capacity of p-type organic cathodes is low (<150 mAh g–1), which compromises the advantage of organic cathode materials over the commercial inorganic cathode materials. The future work should focus on designing and synthesizing p-type organic cathode materials with small molecular weight to enhance the energy density of the organic full cell.

    2.3. Azo Reaction

    The azo compounds were a new class of OEMs reported by Luo et al. recently. The azo group (N═N) was found to be the electrochemically active site in LIBs. (39) In the aromatic azo compound, the double bond in the azo group is converted to a single bond during the lithiation process, and the single bond is converted back to the double bond during the delithiation process (Figure 7). Each nitrogen atom reacts with one Li-ion and one electron during the lithiation/delithiation process. This reversible process enables the electrochemical activity of azo compound in LIBs. Though azobenzene (AB) exhibits electrochemical performance in LIBs, its high solubility in the electrolyte leads to rapid capacity fading. To decrease the solubility of azobenzene, carboxylate group is added into the azobenzene to generate methyl red sodium salt (MRSS) and azobenzene-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid lithium salt (ADALS). The ADALS with two carboxylate groups is insoluble in the electrolyte and, thus, exhibits exceptional electrochemical performance in LIBs. Its charge/discharge plateaus located at 1.5 V, and it delivers a reversible capacity of 190 mAh g–1 after 100 cycles at 0.5 C. Furthermore, it retains reversible capacities of 126 and 93 mAh g–1 for 5000 cycles at the high current density of 10 and 20 C. The long cycle life of ADALS is ascribed to the two carboxylate groups, which prevent the dissolution of azo compound, while the fast charge/discharge capability is attributed to the extended π-conjugated structure of the two benzene rings, which facilitates the electron and lithium ion diffusion. The exceptional electrochemical performance of ADALS demonstrates that the carboxylated azo compounds are promising anode materials for LIBs.
    The research for azo group-based OEMs in LIBs is still in the infant stage. Four selected aromatic azo compounds are listed in Figure 8 with the specific capacity, current density and cycle life. The cyclic stability of aromatic azo compounds is limited by their solubility in the organic electrolyte. AB suffers from fast capacity loss, while 4-(phenylazo) benzoic acid lithium salt (PBALS) with a carboxylate group shows improved cycling stability in 500 cycles. Though MRSS also contains a carboxylate group, the tertiary amine group in MRSS enhances its solubility in the electrolyte, resulting in poor cycle life. To circumvent the high solubility challenge, two carboxylate groups are introduced into the aromatic azo compound to generate ADALS. The excellent electrochemical performance of ADALS is attributed to the salt formation, which increases the polarity of azo compounds. To further boost the battery performance of azo compounds, future research should be devoted to designing and synthesizing low molecular weight azo compounds to enhance the specific capacity, and azo group-based conjugated polymers to increase its electronic conductivity.

    2.4. Carbonyl Reaction

    The carbonyl reaction is based on the reversible electrochemical reaction between lithium ions and carbonyl groups in a conjugated organic framework. Two or more carbonyl groups are required to react with lithium ions, followed with an intramolecular electron transfer in the conjugated organic framework. (41) Considerable research efforts have been devoted to developing organic anodes based on carboxylate derivatives and organic cathodes based on quinone derivatives, which are two types of carbonyl compounds. (42,43) More importantly, the carbonyl compounds can be applied as electrode materials in all kinds of rechargeable batteries, including nonaqueous Li-ion, Na-ion, K-ion, dual-ion, multivalent metal, aqueous, all-solid-state, and redox flow batteries. The extensive applications of carbonyl compounds make them a class of the most promising electrode materials in organic batteries. Herein, this Review mainly discusses three categories of representative carbonyl-based electrode materials: (1) carboxylate-based anodes, (2) quinone-based cathodes, and (3) fast charge/discharge carbonyl-based electrode materials.
    One of the major challenges in the carbonyl group-based small molecules is the high solubility in the organic electrolyte, which can be mitigated by the salt formation. A decade ago, the conjugated dicarboxylate lithium salts, such as dilithium muconate and dilithium terephthalate were introduced as organic anodes for LIBs by Armand et al. (44) Since then, a myriad of carboxylate group-based organic anode materials have been developed for organic batteries because of the low reaction potential, high capacity, and facile structure tunability. In this type of OEMs, two or more carboxylate groups as electrochemical active centers are attached to a conjugated structure such as a benzene ring. The two −C═O in the carboxylate groups of the dilithium terephthalate reversibly react with two Li-ions and two electrons during lithiation/delithiation process (Figure 9a). Meanwhile, an intramolecular electron transfer is triggered in the conjugated structure to rearrange the double bonds. This reversible reaction provides a specific capacity of 234 mAh g–1 after 50 charge/discharge cycles. It sheds light on the development of organic anodes for rechargeable batteries.
    The carbonyl group-based OEMs can also be used as organic cathodes, such as the quinone derivatives. The major challenge of the quinone-based organic cathode is that most of them do not contain lithium source for the redox reaction, so it requires the lithium sources from the anode side. For the few carbonyl group-based organic cathodes with lithium sources, they are air and moisture sensitive, requiring cautious operation for the electrode fabrication. One exception is the air-stable lithiated cathode material based on a 1,4-benzenedisulfonate backbone (Figure 9b). (45) The two sulfonate groups in the compound enhance the reaction potential to ∼3.25 V, and it retains a reversible capacity of 100 mAh g–1 at C/20 for 50 cycles. Another exception is the Mg-substituted carboxyphenolate-based organic cathode material, which is air-stable and exhibits a 0.8 V potential increase after partially replacing Li+ by Mg2+. (46) The partially replacing Li ions by Mg ions tunes the electronic effects in the redox-active organic skeleton, resulting in the potential increase. This material contains two magnesium oxide groups that act as the cathode redox centers and two carboxylate groups that act as the anode redox centers. It was used to make an all-organic symmetric Li-ion cell with an output voltage of 2.5 V and an energy density of 89 Wh kg–1.
    In addition to the salt formation, increasing the molecular weight of carbonyl group-based OEMs to form insoluble polymers is another effective method to overcome the high solubility challenge. Some carbonyl group-based polymers, such as polyanthraquinone, display high cycling stability and fast charge/discharge capability, which are critical for the applications in electric vehicles. (47) The polyanthraquinone cathode exhibits a reversible capacity of ∼120 mAh g–1 for 1000 cycles at 1 and 2 C. It can be charged and discharged at a high current density of 20 C, referring to 3 min per charge/discharge. The fast charge/discharge capability of polyanthraquinone is ascribed to the surface reaction-controlled kinetics of the amorphous quinone polymer. In addition to polyanthraquinone, a number of carbonyl group-based OEMs have shown fast reaction kinetics in LIBs, making them promising cathode materials for multivalent metal batteries, which suffer from sluggish reaction kinetics. More discussion will be provided in the multivalent metal battery section.
    The carbonyl group-based OEMs are extensively investigated in LIBs. Figure 10 lists some selected carbonyl group-based organic and polymer materials with initial capacity, current density, and cycle number. (48−59) Most of the carbonyl group-based organic and polymer cathodes show higher capacity than the inorganic counterparts, but the low redox potential (2–3 V) and lack of Li-ions in the cathode prohibit their practical application. The lithiated organic cathode such as Li4C8H2O6 provides Li-ions for the redox reaction, but it suffers from limited cycle life, low redox potential and high air-sensitivity. (48) To overcome the low redox potential and high air-sensitivity challenges in the lithiated organic cathodes, introducing Mg ions and sulfonate groups into the organic materials offer new opportunities. More work focuses on prolonging the cycle life of the lithiated organic cathode, is required in the future. It could be achieved by optimizing the organic electrolytes and adding protective carbon additives. In addition, carbonyl group-based polymer cathodes display long cycle life (>1000 cycles) and fast charge capability due to the intrinsic insolubility nature of the high molecular weight polymer and long-term conjugated structure. More importantly, porous covalent organic frameworks (COFs) were employed as OEMs in LIBs, recently. The cross-linked COFs are insoluble in the organic electrolytes, resulting in high cyclic stability, while the porous structure benefits the intimate contact between COFs and the liquid electrolyte, leading to fast reaction kinetics. (57−59) Therefore, COF-based cathodes exhibit long cycle life and fast charge capability. More work is required to add more electroactive functional groups into COFs to enhance the specific capacity.

    2.5. Imine Reaction

    The imine reaction is a reversible electrochemical reaction between the nitrogens in the imine group (C═N) and lithium ions. The imine groups are connected by the conjugated structure, such as a benzene ring, and there is intramolecular electron transfer in the conjugated system. An example of the imine-based organic cathode is the π-conjugated quinoxaline-based heteroaromatic molecules (3Q) reported by Peng et al. (60) They synthesized a 3Q molecule that contains six imine groups and used in situ nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) technique and density functional theory (DFT) to investigate the lithiation mechanism. As shown in Figure 11, the reaction is divided into two steps. In the first step, one lithium ion reacts with two nitrogens in the imine groups. The six imine groups could react with three lithium ions so that two nitrogens share a lithium ion to form a N–Li–N structure. In the second step, the lithium ion could further react with the N–Li–N structure to form a Li–N structure so that the two nitrogens share two lithium ions. The six imine groups in 3Q could react with six lithium ions and six electrons to provide a reversible capacity of 395 mAh g–1 under a current density of 400 mA g–1, and 3Q shows high cycling stability for 10 000 cycles, which represents one of the best cycle lives in LIBs. The high capacity and ultralong cycle life of quinoxaline-based cathode offer a new opportunity to design high energy density organic batteries.
    Eight selected imine group-based organic and polymer materials for LIBs are listed in Figure 12 with the first cycle capacity, current density and cycle life. The organic materials, LC, ALX, 2Q, and 3Q, show fast reaction kinetics (>20C) and long cycle life with the assistance of carbon nanotubes and graphene. (60,61) However, a large amount of conductive carbon additive (>50 wt %) is required to prevent organic materials from dissolution and enhance the conductivity and cyclic stability of the organic electrodes, reducing the overall energy density of the organic electrodes. Another method to increase the cyclic stability of the imine group-based OEMs is through polymerization of organic compounds. The resulting polymers, HATNPF1, HATNPF2, P3, and SNW-1, show improved electrochemical performance because of the long-term conjugated and cross-linked structures. (62−64) Generally, the polymers show lower specific capacity than the small molecular weight organic materials because of the existence of more inactive components in the polymers. However, SNW-1 shows ultrahigh capacity of 920 mAh g–1 due to the unique thin-layer 2D structure for the exfoliated covalent organic nanosheets, which facilitates the ion/electron transfer and offers more active redox sites for the lithium storage. Therefore, there are three methods to improve the electrochemical performance of the imine group-based organic and polymer materials: (1) adding a large amount of conductive carbon additive, (2) polymerizing the small molecular weight organic compounds, and (3) synthesizing organic nanomaterials.

    2.6. Superlithiation Reaction

    The superlithiation reaction is based on the conjugated hydrocarbon, such as polyacetylene (PAc), where the unsaturated carbon–carbon bond is converted to a saturated carbon–carbon bond during the discharge. (65) Recently, more work was reported that the unsaturated carbon–carbon group can act as an electroactive site in OEMs when discharging to low potentials. The unsaturated carbon–carbon bond in the OEMs is converted to a saturated carbon–carbon bond and each carbon atom gains a Li-ion and an electron during the discharge. Figure 13 provides an example of the reaction mechanism of the carbonyl- and unsaturated carbon–carbon group-based organic anode. The carbonyl group reacts with the Li-ions and electrons first, then the unsaturated carbon–carbon bonds in naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (NTCDA) further react with Li-ions and electrons at low reaction potentials, providing an ultrahigh capacity of over 1000 mAh g–1. (66)
    The carbonyl- and unsaturated carbon–carbon group-based anodes deliver very high specific capacities in LIBs. Lithium ions not only react with the carbonyl groups, but also react with the conjugated organic framework at low potentials. As shown in Figure 13, NTCDA is reduced by lithium ions via two steps. (66) In the first step, four lithium ions react with the four carbonyl groups in the potential range from 2.61 to 1.04 V, accompanied by the electron transfer in the two benzene rings. In the second step, 14 lithium ions react with the conjugated organic framework to reduce carbon–carbon double bonds to single bonds in the potential range from 1.04 to 0.001 V. The whole lithiation process of NTCDA delivers a high specific capacity of 1800 mAh g–1 at the current density of 20 mA g–1, which is five times higher than that of the commercial graphite anode. Another example is the maleic acid anode, which delivers an ultrahigh specific capacity of 1500 mAh g–1 at the current density of 46.2 mA g–1. (67) The reversible redox reactions of carbonyl groups and the carbon–carbon double bond with four lithium ions and four electrons occur in the maleic acid–based anode, providing a theoretical capacity of 1116.7 mAh g–1. The practical capacity of the maleic acid electrode is even higher than the theoretical capacity, probably owing to the surface adsorption of Li-ions. The ultrahigh capacity of the superlithiation reaction-based anodes makes them very promising anode materials for LIBs.
    As listed in Figure 14, most of the superlithiation reaction-based organic anodes exhibit high initial specific capacity (>1000 mAh g–1), and the lithiation of the unsaturated carbon–carbon bond takes place at low reaction potentials below 1 V, making them ideal anode materials for LIBs. (68−74) More importantly, the extended conjugated structure in the polymers, such as PIAQ, not only react with Li-ions and provide a high specific capacity but also enables the high conductivity and good structure stability, facilitating the reaction kinetics. (72) In general, the superlithiation reaction-based organic anodes show excellent electrochemical performances at ambient temperature. In addition to ambient temperature tests, the application of the superlithiation reaction-based polymers at 50 °C was also investigated. Both PQL and BBL retained a reversible capacity of ∼500 mAh g–1 at the current density of 2.5 and 3 C, respectively, at 50 °C after 1000 cycles. (70,73) The exceptional performance at a high temperature further demonstrates that the superlithiation reaction-based organic anodes are promising anode materials for LIBs.

    3. Applications beyond LIBs and under Extreme Conditions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Up to date, the organic electrode materials have been extensively applied in a large variety of energy storage fields, including nonaqueous Li-ion, Na-ion, K-ion, dual-ion, multivalent metal, aqueous, all-solid-state, redox flow batteries, and extreme conditions. The extensive applications demonstrate the importance of organic and polymer materials in rechargeable batteries. This section will discuss the applications of OEMs beyond LIBs and under extreme conditions in detail.

    3.1. Organic Na-Ion Batteries

    Na-ion batteries (SIBs) are considered as alternatives to LIBs because of the abundance and low cost of sodium sources, and comparable reaction potential to Li (−2.71 V for Na/Na+ vs −3.04 V for Li/Li+). (75) However, the high energy density and stable cycle life of LIBs do not extend to SIBs, due to the 1.4 times larger ion size of Na+ than Li+, which triggers more severe volume change during sodiation/desodiation process, and more complicated intercalation chemistry. (76) To improve the electrochemical performance of SIBs, a large variety of inorganic materials were developed to substitute for graphite and LiCoO2. Nevertheless, none of them can compete with the performance of LIBs. Therefore, OEMs, with the advantages of lightweight, abundance, low cost, high sustainability, and high recyclability, stand out as promising electrode materials for SIBs.
    Wang et al. reported sodium 4,4′-stilbene-dicarboxylate (SSDC) as a fast charge/discharge organic anode for SIBs (Figure 15a). (77) The design strategy of the fast charge/discharge organic anode is to enlarge the conjugated structure of the organic framework. The SSDC delivers a reversible initial capacity of 160 mAh g–1 and retains 112 mAh g–1 after 400 cycles, demonstrating the stable cycle life in SIBs. More importantly, the SSDC could deliver reversible capacities of 90 and 72 mAh g–1 at high current density of 5 and 10 A g–1, demonstrating the fast charge/discharge capability. The fast charge/discharge capability of SSDC is ascribed to the extended π-conjugated system, which improves the charge transport and stabilizes the charged and discharged states of SSDC. To enhance the capacity of organic anode in SIBs, Zhao et al. reported the organic thiocarboxylate electrodes, in which sulfur is used to replace oxygen as the redox centers (Figure 15b). (78) The thiocarboxylate electrodes share the same reaction mechanism as the carboxylate electrodes, but the capacity of the thiocarboxylate electrode could reach as high as 567 mAh g–1 at 50 mA g–1 because of the reaction between the benzene ring and sodium ions. The sulfur doping in the carboxylate electrodes not only increases the battery capacity but also improves the electron density and conductivity. The thiocarboxylate electrode could retain a reversible capacity of ∼300 mAh g–1 even at a high current density of 2 A g–1. As a proof of concept, this OEM is used to make flexible organic batteries (Figure 15b). The exceptional performance and potential application of carboxylate and thiocarboxylate electrodes demonstrates that carboxylate-based organic compounds are promising anodes for SIBs.
    Another type of organic anode in SIBs is the oligomeric-Schiff base reported by López-Herraiz et al. (79) There are four types of functional groups in the oligomers O2–5, which are ––OOC−Φ–C═N–, −N═C−Φ–C═N–, ––OOC−Φ–N═C–, and −C═N−Φ–N═C– (Φ represents the benzene ring). Though all the oligomers exhibit electrochemical behaviors in SIBs, their results indicate that not all the functional groups are electrochemically active. When the nitrogen in the imine group gains an electron and a sodium ion during the sodiation process, the carbon–nitrogen double bond in the imine group will be dissociated into a single bond. Meanwhile, the carbon will become a free radial, which is very active and triggers the intramolecular electron transfer in the conjugated system. To form a stable conjugated structure after the electron transfer, the two carbon free radicals need to be connected in the same conjugated system, so ––OOC−Φ–C═N– and −N═C−Φ–C═N– are electrochemically active, while ––OOC−Φ–N═C– and −C═N−Φ–N═C– are inactive. Therefore, these results not only confirm that the nitrogen is the active site in the imine compound, but also introduce the molecular design strategy for the imine compound. In addition to the Schiff base, the azo compounds also show superb electrochemical performance in SIBs, in terms of long cycle life and fast charge/discharge capability. (80) The azobenzene-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid sodium salt (ADASS) could retain a reversible capacity of 113 mAh g–1 at 10 C for 1000 cycles and a reversible capacity of 98 mAh g–1 at 20 C for 2000 cycles.
    To couple with the organic anodes, a large number of organic cathodes have also been developed for SIBs. One of the high energy organic cathodes is disodium rhodizonate (Na2C6O6). Lee et al. reported that Na2C6O6 achieved a high reversible capacity of 484 mAh g–1, an energy density of 726 Wh kg–1, and energy efficiency above 87% and a good cycle retention by the synergy of the nanostructure and an ether-based electrolyte. (81) The schematic of the sodiation/desodiation process in Figure 16a indicates that Na2C6O6 undergoes the structure change from the α- to the γ-phase, which is kinetically suppressed. It explains the low capacity of Na2C6O6 cathode in the other literatures. However, the reversible phase transformation becomes kinetically favorable by reducing the particle size and using the diethylene glycol dimethyl ether (DEGDME)-based electrolyte. The high capacity and energy density were achieved by cycling the Na2C6O6 nanoelectrode with a DEGDME-based electrolyte in a wide cutoff window from 0.5 to 3.3 V. Another approach to increase the performance of organic cathode is to tailor the π-conjugated system. Tang et al. reported a new quinone-based polymer (poly(pentacenetetrone sulfide, PPTS) with a high capacity (∼290 mAh g–1), fast charge capability (∼160 and 100 mAh g–1 at 10 and 50 A g–1, respectively), and ultralong cycle life (10 000 cycles). (82) The exceptional performance was achieved by enhancing the π–π intermolecular interactions, resulting in insolubility, long-range layer-by-layer π–π stacking, fast-charge transport, extraordinary stability, and ionic conductivity. The excellent electrochemical performance of PPTS renders it a promising cathode material. In addition, Hu et al. reported a high-voltage cathode material (∼3.47 V vs Na+/Na) for SIBs based on pyrene functionalized poly(2,2,6,6-tetramethyl piperidiny-1-oxyl-4-yl methacrylate) (Py-PTMA). (83) To overcome the inferior conductivity and high solubility challenges of this nitroxide radical polymer, a “molecular glue” strategy is used to anchor Py-PTMA on a conductive carbon nanotube (CNT) matrix through the π–π interaction between pyrene and CNTs. The resulting Py-PTMA/CNTs cathode shows fast charge capability and ultrahigh cycling stability in SIBs that it delivers a high capacity of 78 mAh g–1 at a very high current density of 5.5 A g–1 and retains over 92% capacity for 6000 cycles at 2.2 A g–1, representing one of the best high-voltage cathode performances in SIBs to date.
    The above two organic cathodes show superior performances in SIBs, but the weakness is the lack of sodium sources in the cathode. To overcome this challenge, Wang et al. synthesized Na4C8H2O6 with built-in sodium sources in the two sodium-oxide functional groups, while the two sodium carboxylate groups act as electroactive centers in the anode (Figure 16b). (84) An all organic SIB based on Na4C8H2O6 in both cathode and anode was achieved and exhibited exceptional battery performance, in terms of a high capacity (223 mAh g–1), long cycle life (100 cycles) and robust rate capability (up to 5 C). Considerable research efforts have been devoted to developing high energy organic cathode for SIBs. To date, the most successful organic cathodes are carbonyl group-based organic and polymer materials because of the high sustainability and good structure tunability. The future research toward organic SIB cathode should focus on developing air stable and high voltage organic cathodes with build-in sodium sources. One possible way is to introduce more heteroatoms or electron withdrawing functional groups into the OEMs.

    3.2. Organic K-Ion Batteries

    As another alternative to LIBs, potassium ion batteries (KIBs) share similar battery chemistry as LIBs and SIBs, but the larger ion size of K+ than Li+ and Na+ compromises the electrochemical performance of KIBs. (85) Most of inorganic electrode materials, which exhibit excellent performance in LIBs and SIBs, do not extend the high capacity and long cycle life to KIBs. Unlike inorganic electrode materials, OEMs retain the exceptional electrochemical performance in KIBs because of the good structure flexibility and tunability, making OEMs universal electrode materials for alkali-ion batteries. (86−91) As reported by Zhao et al., oxocarbon salts are a class of organic electrodes that can be used in LIBs, SIBs, and KIBs. (92)Figure 17a shows the reaction mechanisms of three types of oxocarbon salts (squaric salts, croconic salts, and rhodizonic salts). The carbonyl groups in oxocarbon salts act as electroactive centers in LIBs, SIBs, and KIBs to reversibly react with Li+, Na+, and K+. The 1.25 M KPF6-dimethoxyethane (DME) electrolyte in KIBs shows higher ionic conductivity than the 1 M LiPF6-ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC) electrolyte in LIBs and 1.25 M NaPF6-DME electrolyte in SIBs, resulting in fast reaction kinetics of potassium rhodizonate (212 mAh g–1 at 0.2 C and 164 mAh g–1 at 10 C). An all-organic K4C6O6/K2C6O6 battery was achieved and displayed an operation voltage of 1.1 V (Figure 17b), corresponding to energy density of 35 Wh kg–1. This work not only proves that OEMs are universal electrodes for alkali-ion batteries but also open up a new way to develop advanced OEMs for KIBs.
    Since then, a large number of OEMs with exceptional electrochemical performance for KIBs are developed. Tian et al. designed and synthesized two 1D linear polymers, polyimide (PI), and polyquinoneimide (PQI), and a 2D conjugated microporous polymer (PI-CMP). (93) The study revealed that the high content of carbonyl groups in the polymer leads to the high initial capacity, but the tight distribution of potassiated carbonyl groups compromises the cycling stability. To enhance the stability, PI-CMP, with an extended π-conjugation structure, exhibits improved cycling stability and rate performance in KIBs. 74% of the initial capacity is retained at a high current density of 1 A g–1 after 1000 cycles. In addition, Tang et al. used PPTS in KIBs, which was also used as a cathode in SIBs. (90) The excellent electrochemical performance of PPTS in SIBs extends to KIBs that a reversible capacity of 190 mAh g–1 is retained at 5 A g–1 after 3000 cycles, further confirming the superior electrochemical performance of carbonyl group-based OEMs as universal electrodes in alkali-ion batteries. Analogous to SIBs, the future research of organic KIBs should focus on developing air stable and high voltage organic cathodes with build-in potassium sources to further improve the performance of all-organic batteries.

    3.3. Organic Multivalent Metal Batteries

    As universal electrodes in alkali-ion batteries, carbonyl group-based OEMs can also be applied in multivalent metal (Mg, Al) batteries, which are other types of alternatives to LIBs. The low cost, abundance, high volumetric energy density of Mg and Al resources, and dendrite-free stripping/plating process of Mg metal attract considerable research interests. (94) However, most of cathode materials in alkali-ion batteries cannot be used in multivalent metal batteries due to the strong interaction of Mg2+ and Al3+ with the host materials. To date, the chevrel phase Mo6S8 is still the most successful cathode for rechargeable magnesium (RMBs) and aluminum (RABs) batteries. However, it suffers from low capacity, poor cycle life and sluggish reaction kinetics. To overcome these challenges, OEMs with the advantages of lightweight, abundance, low cost and high sustainability stand out as the universal cathodes for RMBs and RABs. (95)
    Pan et al. reported polyanthraquinone-based organic cathodes for high performance RMBs (Figure 18a). (96) It was revealed that the carbonyl groups in the anthraquinone can reversibly react with Mg ions with a pair of redox peaks at 1.6–1.7 V. The fast charge/discharge capability of polyanthraquinone in LIBs, which has been discussed in section 2.4, was extended to RMBs. This organic RMB cathode was charged and discharged for 1000 cycles at high current density of 1 (260 mA g–1) and 2 C (520 mA g–1), demonstrating the exceptional performance in RMBs. The use of high rate organic cathodes resolves the sluggish reaction kinetics of RMBs and provides new opportunities for high performance RMBs. Fan et al. reported another ultrafast polymer cathode (polyimides, PI) for RMBs and RABs. (97) With the assistance of carbon nanotube, PI exhibits long cycle life (200 cycles), fast kinetics (20 C), and wide operating temperature range (−40 to 50 °C), confirming that carbonyl group-based polymers are promising cathode materials for multivalent metal batteries.
    In addition to the polymers, low molecular weight organic materials can also be used as cathodes for multivalent metal batteries. Figure 18b shows the reaction mechanism and cycle life of the phenanthrenequinone triangle (PQ-Δ) reported by Kim et al. (98) The triangle structure decreases the solubility of the organic material in the electrolyte and influences the accessibility of chloroaluminate ions, increasing the specific capacity and cyclability of PQ-Δ. An ultralong cycle life of 5000 cycles was achieved in RABs, representing the best cycle life to date. To further improve the performance, a hybrid electrode with graphite flakes was fabricated to ameliorate the low electronic conductivity and limited areal loading. The hybrid electrode retained 94% (114 mAh g–1) of capacity at 2 C after 500 cycles, and preserved 81% of the capacity at 2 C even when increasing the current density to 20 C. Moreover, at high mass loadings of 2 and 9 mg, the hybrid electrodes were still able to maintain their integrity. Therefore, these results demonstrate that adding conductive carbon additives, such as carbon nanotubes and graphite, is an effective method to improve the electrochemical performance of organic multivalent metal batteries.

    3.4. Organic Dual-Ion Batteries

    Organic dual-ion batteries are a type of all-organic full cells, in which both cathode and anode materials are OEMs. In organic dual-ion batteries, the cathodes consist of anion insertion reaction-based OEMs, which reversibly react with anions, such as PF6–, ClO4–, and TFSI–, in the electrolyte, while the anodes are other types of OEMs based on any reaction mechanisms. As discussed in the section 2.2, the OEMs undergo an anion insertion reaction, providing a high voltage above 3 V versus Li. Since the cathode reaction does not require cations, metal-free organic cathodes are used to couple with organic anodes for all-organic full cells. (99)
    There are two types of organic dual-ion batteries, symmetric cells and asymmetric cells, as shown in Figure 19. An example of the first type (Figure 19a) is 4,4′-(phenazine-5,10-diyl)dibenzoate anion (PZDB), which contains two cathode active centers (tertiary amine groups) and two anode active centers (carboxylate groups) in one organic framework. (100) It is used as both cathode and anode to fabricate an all-organic symmetric cell due to the large potential difference between phenazine and benzoate in PZDB. The symmetric cell delivers a high cell voltage of 2.5 V and an energy density of 127 Wh kg–1 at a current density of 1 C. The success of this symmetric cell provides a new opportunity to achieve high sustainability organic batteries as alternatives to LIBs. The other type of organic dual-ion batteries are the asymmetric cells based on two distinct organic anode and cathode. As shown in Figure 19b, an asymmetric dual-ion full cell consists of the polytriphenylamine (PTPAn) cathode and 1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride-derived polyimide (PNTCDA) anode. (101) During the charge and discharge, PTPAn reversibly reacts with TFSI–, and PNTCDA reversibly reacts with Li+, providing a specific capacity of 91 mAh g–1 at 1C. Even at a high current density of 100 C, a specific capacity of 70 mAh g–1 is still retained, demonstrating the fast charge and discharge capability. Apart from room temperature measurements, the low-temperature performance of the organic dual-ion battery is also investigated with a low freezing point ethyl acetate-based electrolyte. 70% of the room temperature capacity is maintained at an ultralow temperature of −70 °C owing to the fast reaction kinetics of the organic dual-ion battery. The outstanding electrochemical performance of organic batteries at both room temperature and ultralow temperature extends the applications of these batteries to areas of low-temperature exploration, such as the north or south poles and outer space.
    Another example of the dual-ion battery is p- and n-type bipolar organic polymers based on nitroxide free radicals. Suga et al. reported two new battery configurations based on (1) a symmetric configuration consisted of bipolar poly(nitronylnitroxylstyrene) for both cathode and anode, and (2) rocking-chair-type battery composed of poly(nitronylnitroxylstyrene) and poly(galvinoxylstyrene) as the anode and cathode. (102) The symmetric cell delivers a charge capacity of 44 mAh g–1, corresponding to 86% of the theoretical capacity. A good cycle life of >250 cycles is achieved at a high current density of 60 C. The asymmetric cell retains 90% of the original capacity at 150 C for over 250 cycles. The bipolar redox polymers with the superior electrochemical performance represent a new type of OEMs for high performance all-organic full cells.

    3.5. Aqueous Organic Batteries

    Rechargeable aqueous batteries attract considerable research interests because of the low cost, nontoxicity, nonflammability, and high sustainability of the water-based electrolyte. However, due to the narrow electrochemical stability window (1.23 V) of water, the stability window of the aqueous electrolyte is much smaller than that of the organic electrolyte (4.5 V), limiting the energy density of aqueous batteries. The high performance of the inorganic electrode materials in nonaqueous LIBs does not extend to the aqueous LIBs. Up to now, considerable research efforts have been devoted to developing new materials and chemistries for aqueous batteries. The organic materials with high structure flexibility and tunability stand out as universal electrodes for aqueous batteries. (103,104)
    Liang et al. reported to use quinone-based organic polymers as universal anodes in aqueous batteries (Figure 20a). (105) The quinone-based anodes exhibit high capacity, long cycle life and fast reaction kinetics in aqueous batteries. More importantly, the quinone-based organic polymer supports the “oxygen cycle” in aqueous batteries, which is a built-in safety mechanism to reduce the oxygen generated from water oxidation by the charged anode. In consequence, the battery can work under extreme conditions such as high pH value (15), low pH value (−1), low temperature (−25 °C), and atmosphere (with/without O2). As shown in Figure 20a, a pyrene-4,5,9,10-tetraone (PTO)–PbO2 acidic battery achieves a long cycle life of 1500 cycles and a fast charge rate up to 20 C, demonstrating superior cycling stability and rate capability. The quinone-based materials can be applied in proton, Li-ion, Na-ion, K-ion, Mg-ion batteries, making them universal anodes for any aqueous battery technology. Recently, the quinone electrodes were also used as cathodes in aqueous Zn batteries as reported by Guo et al. (106) As shown in Figure 20b, PTO is coupled with Zn metal anode to achieve an aqueous PTO/Zn full cell with a high energy density of 186.7 Wh kg–1, stable cycle life (1000 cycles) and fast charge capability (20 A g–1). The use of quinone derivatives as universal electrodes in aqueous batteries offer new opportunities for OEMs.

    3.6. All-Solid-State Organic Batteries

    One of the major challenges for OEMs is the high solubility in the electrolyte, resulting in fast capacity decay of organic batteries. To resolve this challenge, one of the ultimate approaches is to use the solid-state electrolyte to replace the liquid electrolyte in organic batteries. Zhu et al. used composite polymer electrolyte, containing the poly(methacrylate) (PMA)/poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)-LiClO4-3 wt % SiO2, to match with the organic pillar[5]quinone cathode to build an all-solid-state lithium battery (ASSLB). (107) The ASSLB delivers an initial capacity of 409 mAh g–1 at 0.2 C and retains 94.7% of the initial capacity after 50 cycles, demonstrating exceptional electrochemical performance in the composite polymer electrolyte.
    In addition to the polymer electrolyte, the OEMs are also compatible with sulfide-based solid electrolyte. As reported by Luo et al., the azo compounds are compatible with the sulfide-based solid electrolyte (Li3PS4). (108) However, ASSLBs suffer from interfacial contact challenge due to the volume change of azo compounds upon cycling. To circumvent this challenge, a carboxylated azo compound, PBALS, is used as an active material in the ASSLB, because the oxygen in the carboxylate group of PBALS can form ionic bonding with lithium in the Li3PS4 solid electrolyte (Figure 21a). The strong ionic bonding retains the intimate contact between PBALS and the Li3PS4 solid electrolyte upon long-term cycling, resulting in stable cycle life (120 cycles) of the organic ASSLB. Therefore, adding carboxylate groups into the azo compounds and using solid-state electrolyte are two effective methods to mitigate the dissolution challenge. Besides ASSLB, the OEMs can also be applied in the all-solid-state sodium batteries (ASSSBs). Chi et al. proved that the high capacity organic cathode, Na4C6O6, was compatible with the Na3PS4 solid-state electrolyte. (109) As shown in Figure 21b, ASSSBs consist of a Na4C6O6 cathode and a Na15Sn4 anode exhibit excellent electrochemical performance at 60 °C, in terms of a high capacity (172 mAh g–1) and stable cycle life (400 cycles). Recently, the same group reported that another organic cathode material, PTO, was also compatible with the Na3PS4 solid-state electrolyte. (110) For the first time, a reversible active material-electrolyte interfacial resistance evolution during cycling is studied. More importantly, the low-modulus organic materials, which are soft and flexible, are critical to form a favorable electrode–electrolyte interface and maintain the intimate interfacial contact with solid electrolytes during cycling. The PTO-based ASSSBs deliver a high energy density of 587 Wh kg–1 and a long cycle life of 500 cycles. The success of these OEMs in all-solid-state batteries provides a new direction to develop high performance organic batteries.

    3.7. Organic Redox Flow Batteries

    In redox flow batteries (RFBs), electrochemically active materials are dissolved in the electrolyte to form the anolyte and catholyte, and then the anolyte and catholyte are pumped into the flow battery to undergo the electrochemical redox reactions. An ion selective membrane, such as Nafion membrane, is used to separate anolyte and catholyte in the RFBs. Thus, the high solubility challenge of OEMs in solid-state electrodes becomes an advantage in organic RFBs. Moreover, the low cost, abundance, and high sustainability of OEMs also stimulate the development of organic RFBs. Up to date, a number of high solubility small molecules and polymers are reported as electrochemically active materials in RFBs, showing excellent performance for large-scale energy storage. (111)
    In 2014, Huskinson et al. reported a metal-free quinone–bromide aqueous RFB using 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) as the anode material. (112) The low cost, abundance, fast reaction kinetics, and high stability of the quinone-based anode opens up a promising direction for cost-effective, large-scale energy storage. Since then, considerable research interests have been attracted by organic RFBs. To further decrease the cost of organic RFBs, Lin et al. designed a 1.20 V alkaline quinone flow battery based on the hydroxy-substituted anthraquinone and ferrocyanide in an alkaline solution (Figure 22a). (113) In addition to the low cost of organic and organometallic coordination complexes-based electro-active materials, the use of the basic electrolyte rather than an acidic electrolyte in RFBs reduces the corrosivity of the electrolyte, leading to a substantially lower materials cost of the other inactive components in the RFBs. The low cost, nonflammability, and high safety of the alkaline quinone flow battery render it a promising energy storage device for cost-effective stationary storage of renewable energy. Apart from quinone-based small molecules, polymers based on the TEMPO radical and 4,4′-bipyridine derivatives are also developed as catholyte and anolyte in organic RFBs. (114) The use of environmentally benign sodium chloride-based aqueous electrolyte and inexpensive filter membranes dramatically decreases the cost and enhances the safety of organic RFBs. As shown in Figure 22b, the unpumped test cell can be cycled for over 10 000 cycles at 20 mA cm–2, and the pumped test cell is repeatedly cycled at 40 mA cm–2 for over 90 cycles, demonstrating an exceptional battery performance. The polymer-based RFBs represent economical energy-storage devices that use safe, metal-free, and all organic raw materials. Therefore, the application of OEMs in RFBs is promising for the development of affordable, safe, and scalable battery systems for the large-scale renewable energy storage.

    4. Conclusions and Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Significant advance has been achieved in understanding the reaction mechanisms and enhancing the electrochemical performance of organic batteries. The advantages and applications of OEMs are summarized in Figure 23. Up to date, hundreds of inexpensive, environmentally benign, abundant, sustainable, and recyclable OEMs based on the six reaction mechanisms are designed and synthesized for the rechargeable batteries, including nonaqueous Li-ion, Na-ion, K-ion, multivalent metal, dual-ion, aqueous, all-solid-state, and redox flow batteries. Moreover, organic batteries can be used under extreme conditions, such as a wide temperature range (−70 to 150 °C), a wide pH range (−1 to 15), and atmosphere (with/without O2). The extensive applications of OEMs in rechargeable batteries make them promising substitutions for the expensive and toxic inorganic counterparts. Though great success has been achieved for OEMs, there are still two concerns for the large-scale application: (1) the low electronic conductivity and (2) the high solubility in the electrolyte. The proper approaches to alleviate these two challenges are (1) using the strong π–π interaction between OEMs and conductive carbon such as graphene and carbon nanotube to prevent the OEMs from dissolution and enhance the conductivity of the organic electrodes, (2) extending the π-conjugated system in the OEMs to facilitate the Li-ion diffusion and adding carboxylate groups to reduce the solubility, (3) synthesizing organic salt, which increases the polarity of the material and reduces the solubility in the organic electrolyte, (4) polymerizing organic materials to form long chains and cross-links for insoluble polymers, (115) and (5) using solid-state electrolyte to replace the liquid electrolyte in LIBs to ultimately solve the dissolution challenge. With these methods, high rate capability and long cycle life OEMs can be achieved. However, the energy density of organic batteries is still lower than the inorganic counterparts, because the reaction potential of most organic cathodes is lower than that of the inorganic cathodes, and a large amount of conductive but inactive carbon is needed in the organic electrode. Though p-type organic cathodes based on the anion insertion reaction show comparable reaction potentials to inorganic cathodes, the reversible capacity of p-type organic cathodes is too low, limiting the energy density of the organic batteries. Therefore, considering the features of organic batteries, they are more suitable for the applications in the wind/solar power plants and smart grids, where the low cost, high sustainability, long lifespan and high rate capability energy storage devices are required. The future research work toward organic batteries should focus on two aspects (1) enhancing the potential of the Li-ion insertion based organic cathodes by tailoring the molecular structure and introducing the electron-withdrawing functional groups and (2) increasing the capacity of the p-type organic materials by decreasing the molecular weight and introducing more active sites.
    In addition to LIBs, the application of OEMs in multivalent metal batteries is very promising. In multivalent metal batteries, most of inorganic materials are electrochemically inactive, because of the high charge density of Mg2+ and Al3+, and more complicated intercalation chemistry. Up to date, Mo6S8 is still the most successful inorganic cathode for multivalent metal batteries. However, its electrochemical performance is much worse than the organic counterparts. The energy density of multivalent metal batteries is limited by the low electrochemical stability window of nonaqueous electrolytes and low specific capacity of cathode materials. Most of nonaqueous electrolytes in RMBs are not stable above 3.0 V versus Mg, which is ∼3.7 V versus Li. The low redox reaction potentials of OEMs are well fit in the stability window of nonaqueous Mg electrolytes. Moreover, the good molecular structural tunability and abundant structure diversity of OEMs provide more flexibility to achieve high capacity organic cathodes for multivalent metal batteries. The theoretical capacity of organic cathodes can be enhanced by adding more functional groups, such as carbonyl, imine, and azo groups in the organic molecular structure. Another challenge of multivalent metal battery is the sluggish reaction kinetics because of the high charge density of Mg2+ and Al3+. To enhance the reaction kinetics of multivalent metal batteries, the porous polymers and COFs with large surface area and porosity can be used to reduce the interfacial impedance and provide more electrochemical active sites for the redox reaction. The COFs, which exhibit high cyclic stability and fast charge/discharge capability in LIBs, could also be promising OEMs for multivalent metal batteries.
    The application of OEMs in all-solid-state batteries is also a promising research direction. The major challenge in all-solid-state batteries is the inferior interfacial contact induced by the large volume change of electrochemical active materials upon long-term cycling. To circumvent this challenge, the soft and flexible organic and polymer materials provide a new opportunity. To enable the intimate interfacial contact between active materials and solid-state electrolytes, chemical interactions such as ionic bonding between oxygen in carboxylate group and Li-ion in Li3PS4 solid-state electrolyte can be used to retain the interfacial contact. Moreover, OEMs with low-modulus and high flexibility are also effective to maintain intimate interfacial contact with solid electrolytes during cycling. Recently, self-healing chemistry was introduced to the battery field to overcome the particle pulverization challenge in Si and other inorganic electrodes. The crack and pulverization induced interfacial contact challenge in microsized Si particles can be overcome by using self-healing polymers, which self-heal cracks and pulverizations generated during battery charge and discharge via the hydrogen bonding between self-healing polymers. The incorporation of functional groups such as hydroxyl, amino, carbonyl and imine groups could enable hydrogen bonding in OEMs to retain the intimate contact of the all-solid-state electrode by self-healing chemistry. The self-healing chemistry offers a new research pathway to improve the interfacial contact in all-solid-state organic batteries. Therefore, OEMs with good structural tunability and abundant structural diversity are promising electrode materials for low cost, high sustainability, long cycle life, and fast charge/discharge energy storage devices.

    1. 1
      Larcher, D.; Tarascon, J. M. Towards Greener and More Sustainable Batteries for Electrical Energy Storage. Nat. Chem. 2015, 7 (1), 19– 29,  DOI: 10.1038/nchem.2085
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Towards greener and more sustainable batteries for electrical energy storage
      Larcher, D.; Tarascon, J.-M.
      Nature Chemistry (2015), 7 (1), 19-29CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Ever-growing energy needs and depleting fossil-fuel resources demand the pursuit of sustainable energy alternatives, including both renewable energy sources and sustainable storage technologies. It is therefore essential to incorporate material abundance, eco-efficient synthetic processes and life-cycle anal. into the design of new electrochem. storage systems. At present, a few existing technologies address these issues, but in each case, fundamental and technol. hurdles remain to be overcome. Here the authors provide an overview of the current state of energy storage from a sustainability perspective. The authors introduce the notion of sustainability through discussion of the energy and environmental costs of state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries, considering elemental abundance, toxicity, synthetic methods and scalability. With the same themes in mind, the authors also highlight current and future electrochem. storage systems beyond Li-ion batteries. The complexity and importance of recycling battery materials is also discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvFKlsrjF&md5=977f0fc171bb41af30457715fc0ded72

      Chen, H.; Armand, M.; Demailly, G.; Dolhem, F.; Poizot, P.; Tarascon, J. M. From Biomass to a Renewable LixC6O6 Organic Electrode for Sustainable Li-Ion Batteries. ChemSusChem 2008, 1 (4), 348– 355,  DOI: 10.1002/cssc.200700161
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      From biomass to a renewable LixC6O6 organic electrode for sustainable Li-ion batteries
      Chen, Haiyan; Armand, Michel; Demailly, Gilles; Dolhem, Franck; Poizot, Philippe; Tarascon, Jean-Marie
      ChemSusChem (2008), 1 (4), 348-355CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Li-ion batteries presently operate on inorg. insertion compds. The abundance and materials life-cycle costs of such batteries may present issues in the long term with foreseeable large-scale applications. To address the issue of sustainability of electrode materials, a radically different approach from the conventional route was adopted to develop new org. electrode materials. The oxo-carbon salt Li2C6O6 was synthesized through potentially low-cost processes free of toxic solvents and by using natural org. sources (CO2-harvesting entities). It contains carbonyl groups as redox centers and can electrochem. react with 4 Li ions per formula unit. Such battery processing comes close to both sustainable and green chem. concepts, which are not currently present in Li-ion cell technol. The consideration of renewable resources in designing electrode materials can enable the realization of green and sustainable batteries in the next decade.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXlvFelu7g%253D&md5=874ac2c12a86254b610be73dbdc6cab3

      Xu, Z.; Ye, H.; Li, H.; Xu, Y.; Wang, C.; Yin, J.; Zhu, H. Enhanced Lithium Ion Storage Performance of Tannic Acid in LiTFSI Electrolyte. ACS Omega 2017, 2 (4), 1273– 1278,  DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.6b00504
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Enhanced Lithium Ion Storage Performance of Tannic Acid in LiTFSI Electrolyte
      Xu, Zheng; Ye, Haijun; Li, Hongqin; Xu, Yazhou; Wang, Chuanyi; Yin, Jiao; Zhu, Hui
      ACS Omega (2017), 2 (4), 1273-1278CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
      In this article, tannic acid (TA), as an earth-abundant natural polymer, has been creatively proposed as a desirable org. anode material for lithium ion batteries (LIBs). Most importantly, it has been obsd. that the substitution of different concns. of lithium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) for lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) can significantly restrain the dissoln. of TA. This fact implies that LiTFSI, esp. at high concns., is beneficial to accelerate electrochem. kinetics, enlarge the specific capacity, improve the rate performance, and prolong the cycling life for org. LIBs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXlsVCmsLo%253D&md5=fb4b335d708dbc1d2e923142b00c41d2
    4. 4
      Mao, M.; Luo, C.; Pollard, T. P.; Hou, S.; Gao, T.; Fan, X.; Cui, C.; Yue, J.; Tong, Y.; Yang, G.; Deng, T.; Zhang, M.; Ma, J.; Suo, L.; Borodin, O.; Wang, C. A Pyrazine-Based Polymer for Fast-Charge Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2019, 58 (49), 17820– 17826,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201910916
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      A Pyrazine-Based Polymer for Fast-Charge Batteries
      Mao, Minglei; Luo, Chao; Pollard, Travis P.; Hou, Singyuk; Gao, Tao; Fan, Xiulin; Cui, Chunyu; Yue, Jinming; Tong, Yuxin; Yang, Gaojing; Deng, Tao; Zhang, Ming; Ma, Jianmin; Suo, Liumin; Borodin, Oleg; Wang, Chunsheng
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2019), 58 (49), 17820-17826CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The lack of high-power and stable cathodes prohibits the development of rechargeable metal (Na, Mg, Al) batteries. Herein, poly(hexaazatrinaphthalene) (PHATN), an environmentally benign, abundant and sustainable polymer, is employed as a universal cathode material for these batteries. In Na-ion batteries (NIBs), PHATN delivers a reversible capacity of 220 mAh g-1 at 50 mA g-1, corresponding to the energy d. of 440 Wh kg-1, and still retains 100 mAh g-1 at 10 Ag-1 after 50 000 cycles, which is among the best performances in NIBs. Such an exceptional performance is also obsd. in more challenging Mg and Al batteries. PHATN retains reversible capacities of 110 mAh g-1 after 200 cycles in Mg batteries and 92 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles in Al batteries. DFT calcns., XPS, Raman, and FTIR show that the electron-deficient pyrazine sites in PHATN are the redox centers to reversibly react with metal ions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXitValurjF&md5=182b996cbe68c4a61e9b965b9a33e2ab

      Gao, H.; Xue, L.; Xin, S.; Goodenough, J. B. A High-Energy-Density Potassium Battery with a Polymer-Gel Electrolyte and a Polyaniline Cathode. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2018, 57 (19), 5449– 5453,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201802248
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      A High-Energy-Density Potassium Battery with a Polymer-Gel Electrolyte and a Polyaniline Cathode
      Gao, Hongcai; Xue, Leigang; Xin, Sen; Goodenough, John B.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (19), 5449-5453CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A safe, rechargeable potassium battery of high energy d. and excellent cycling stability was developed. The anion component of the electrolyte salt is inserted into a polyaniline cathode upon charging and extd. from it during discharging while the K+ ion of the KPF6 salt is plated/stripped on the potassium-metal anode. The use of a p-type polymer cathode increases the cell voltage. By replacing the org.-liq. electrolyte in a glass-fiber separator with a polymer-gel electrolyte of cross-linked poly(Me methacrylate), a dendrite-free potassium anode can be plated/stripped, and the electrode/electrolyte interface is stabilized. The potassium anode wets the polymer, and the cross-linked architecture provides small pores of adjustable sizes to stabilize a solid-electrolyte interphase formed at the anode/electrolyte interface. This alternative electrolyte/cathode strategy offers a promising new approach to low-cost potassium batteries for the stationary storage of elec. power.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXntFOksbs%253D&md5=69736ce7003cd932be3a09a85042d6a0
    8. 8
      Li, W.; Chen, L.; Sun, Y.; Wang, C.; Wang, Y.; Xia, Y. All-Solid-State Secondary Lithium Battery Using Solid Polymer Electrolyte and Anthraquinone Cathode. Solid State Ionics 2017, 300, 114– 119,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ssi.2016.12.013
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      All-solid-state secondary lithium battery using solid polymer electrolyte and anthraquinone cathode
      Li, Wangyu; Chen, Long; Sun, Yunhe; Wang, Congxiao; Wang, Yonggang; Xia, Yongyao
      Solid State Ionics (2017), 300 (), 114-119CODEN: SSIOD3; ISSN:0167-2738. (Elsevier B.V.)
      An all-solid-state battery was fabricated by using a PEO-base solid polymer as electrolyte and an org. material anthraquinone (AQ) as cathode. The anthraquinone delivers a specific discharge capacity of 183 mAh g- 1 at first cycle at c.d. of 20 mA g- 1 at 65 °C. The use of solid polymer electrolyte reduces the dissoln. of org. active material greatly, improving the cycle performance of the battery. Therefore, the all-solid-state battery delivers a better cycling property. It can still retain a capacity of 136 mAh g- 1 after 50 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention of 74%, while capacity retention of the cell using liq. electrolyte was only 28% after 20 cycles. The all-solid-state battery shows more stable interfacial resistance during charge-discharge process. It displays good rate ability and a better thermal stability.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFClur7O&md5=15d72944c75abffff777d294f72f1f3d
