      Polyacetylene and polyphenylene as anode materials for nonaqueous secondary batteries
      Shacklette, L. W.; Toth, J. E.; Murthy, N. S.; Baughman, R. H.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (1985), 132 (7), 1529-35CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651.
      The conjugated polymers polyacetylene (PA) [25067-58-7] and poly(p-phenylene) (PPP) [25190-62-9] were examd. for their possible use as anodes in nonaq. secondary batteries. Cathodically stable electrolytes were identified which allow high redn. levels for these polymers, and charge-storage capacities of 0.34 A-h/g for PA and 0.15 A-h/g for PPP were demonstrated. Structural evolution of these polymers during cation insertion and extn. has a significant effect on their electrochem. behavior. Several new stoichiometric phases were identified.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2MXkvFSgsbo%253D&md5=d5104938c169119df3d48afc0dc492eb

      Han, X.; Qing, G.; Sun, J.; Sun, T. How Many Lithium Ions Can Be Inserted onto Fused C6 Aromatic Ring Systems?. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2012, 51 (21), 5147– 5151,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201109187
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      66
      How Many Lithium Ions Can Be Inserted Onto Fused C6 Aromatic Ring Systems?
      Han, Xiaoyan; Qing, Guangyan; Sun, Jutang; Sun, Taolei
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2012), 51 (21), 5147-5151, S5147/1-S5147/13CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The authors studied the electrochem. Li ion insertion/de-insertion properties of 1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic di-anhydride (NTCDA) using model test cells with Li metal as the counter electrode. The working electrode consisted of NTCDA, acetylene black (AB), and polytetrafluoroethylene binders in a wt. ratio of about 60:35:5. The cells were initially cycled by discharging (Li ion insertion) and charging (Li ion de-insertion) repeatedly in a potential range of 0.001-3.0 V vs. Li/Li+ at a moderate current rate of 100 mA/g. The first discharge and charge capacities are 1273 and 724 mAh/g, resp. (coulombic efficiency CE ∼ 57%) and in second cycle are 923 and 809 mAh/g, resp., with CE ∼ 88%. With further cycles, the discharge capacity does not change significantly, while the charge capacity continues to gradually increase to a max. of 933 mAh/g (CE = 98%) in the eighth cycle. The charge capacity then slowly decreases to about 899 mAh/g by the 30th cycle (CE remains at 98%). XRD, NMR, and IR spectroscopy were used to get information on structural changes assocd. with insertion/desertion. The possible electrochem. process for Li ion insertion includes 2 major steps: the addn. of lithium through enolization of the carbonyl groups at potentials above 1.04 V (plateaus 1-3) and then the electrochem. lithium addn. reaction to the unsatd. carbons to form 1:1 Li/C complexes at potentials below 1.04 V (plateaus 4-5). Results of discharge expts. under the same conditions on other multi-ring arom. compds. show that 3,4,9,10-perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (PTCDA) also exhibits a large discharge capacity, whereas the performance efficiencies of other compds. tested are much lower. Results clearly demonstrate a novel Li ion insertion model that differs significantly from other mechanisms for org. compds. and provides a Li ion insertion capacity several times higher than any previously reported. Results indicate that each C6 ring can reversibly accept 6 Li ions to form a 1:1 Li/C complex, giving discharge capacities of up to nearly 2000 mAh/g.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xls1ensb8%253D&md5=5d746ca32e31350a0024e45fcb45a2c2
    67. 67
      Wang, Y.; Deng, Y.; Qu, Q.; Zheng, X.; Zhang, J.; Liu, G.; Battaglia, V. S.; Zheng, H. Ultrahigh-Capacity Organic Anode with High-Rate Capability and Long Cycle Life for Lithium-Ion Batteries. ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2 (9), 2140– 2148,  DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.7b00622
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      67
      Ultrahigh-Capacity Organic Anode with High-Rate Capability and Long Cycle Life for Lithium-Ion Batteries
      Wang, Yan; Deng, Yonghong; Qu, Qunting; Zheng, Xueying; Zhang, Jingyu; Liu, Gao; Battaglia, Vincent S.; Zheng, Honghe
      ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (9), 2140-2148CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      Org. rechargeable batteries have attracted extensive attention as a potential alternative for the current lithium-ion batteries. However, most of the reports are limited to org. macromols. or modified small org. mols. which exhibit low reversible capacity, poor rate capability, and very limited cycle life. Herein, a small org. compd., maleic acid, is adopted as the anode for lithium ion batteries without any modification. It exhibits an ultrahigh reversible capacity of ca. 1500 mAh g-1 at 46.2 mA g-1 c.d. Even at a high c.d. of 46.2 A g-1, the electrode still delivers a capacity of 570.8 mAh g-1. When cycled at 2.31 A g-1, a capacity retention of 98.1% is obtained after 500 cycles. The excellent performance of the maleic acid org. anode is ascribed to its small vol. effect and unique lithium-ion storage mechanisms. This new type of org. anode material may have a great opportunity for large-scale energy-storage systems with high-power properties.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtlKnt73F&md5=5dabf14c9c873931a51fc70e3ee32f8a

      Superlithiation of Organic Electrode Materials: The Case of Dilithium Benzenedipropiolate
      Renault, Steven; Oltean, Viorica Alina; Araujo, C. Moyses; Grigoriev, Anton; Edstroem, Kristina; Brandell, Daniel
      Chemistry of Materials (2016), 28 (6), 1920-1926CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      Dilithium benzenedipropiolate was prepd. and investigated as a potential neg. electrode material for secondary lithium-ion batteries. In addn. to the expected redn. of its carbonyls, this material can reduce and reversibly oxidize its unsatd. carbon-carbon bonds leading to a Li/C ratio of 1/1 and a specific capacity as high as 1363 mAh g-1: the highest ever reported for a lithium carboxylate. D. functional theory calcns. suggest that the lithiation is preferential on the propiolate carbons.

      Pushing Up Lithium Storage through Nanostructured Polyazaacene Analogues as Anode
      Wu, Jiansheng; Rui, Xianhong; Long, Guankui; Chen, Wangqiao; Yan, Qingyu; Zhang, Qichun
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (25), 7354-7358CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      According to the evidence from both theor. calcns. and exptl. findings, conjugated ladder polymers contg. large π-conjugated structure, a high no. of nitrogen heteroatoms, and a multiring arom. system, could be an ideal org. anode candidate for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). In this report, it is demonstrated that the nanostructured polyazaacene analog poly(1,6-dihydropyrazino[2,3g]quinoxaline-2,3,8-triyl-7-(2H)-ylidene-7,8-dimethylidene) (PQL) shows high performance as anode materials in LIBs: high capacity (1750 mAh g-1, 0.05C), good rate performance (303 mAh g-1, 5C), and excellent cycle life (1000 cycles), esp. at high temp. of 50 °C. The results suggest nanostructured conjugated ladder polymers could be alternative electrode materials for the practical application of LIBs.

      Electrochromic Poly(chalcogenoviologen)s as Anode Materials for High-Performance Organic Radical Lithium-Ion Batteries
      Li, Guoping; Zhang, Bingjie; Wang, Jianwei; Zhao, Hongyang; Ma, Wenqiang; Xu, Letian; Zhang, Weidong; Zhou, Kun; Du, Yaping; He, Gang
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2019), 58 (25), 8468-8473CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Electrochromic electron-accepting poly(chalcogenoviologen)s with multiple, stable, and reversible redox centers were used as anodic materials in org. radical Li-ion batteries (ORLIBs). The introduction of heavy atoms (S, Se, and Te) into the viologen scaffold significantly improved the capacity and cycling stability of the ORLIBs. Notably, the poly(Te-BnV) anode was able to intercalate 20 Li ions and showed higher cond. and insoly. in the electrolyte, thus contributing to a reversible capacity of 502 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 when the Coulombic efficiency approached 100%. The charged/discharged state of flexible electrochromic batteries fabricated from these anodic materials could be monitored visually owing to the unique electrochromic and redox properties of the materials. This study opens a promising avenue for the development of org. polymer-based electrodes for flexible hybrid visual electronics.

      High-performance lithium-organic batteries by achieving 16 lithium storage in poly(imine-anthraquinone)
      Man, Zengming; Li, Peng; Zhou, Dong; Zang, Rui; Wang, Shijian; Li, Pengxin; Liu, Shuaishuai; Li, Xuemei; Wu, Yuhan; Liang, Xiaohui; Wang, Guoxiu
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2019), 7 (5), 2368-2375CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Org. materials have attracted intensive research interest in lithium ion batteries (LIBs) due to their advantages of structural diversity, low cost and sustainability in nature. Here we report a highly conjugated org. framework, poly(imine-anthraquinone) (PIAQ), as the anode material of LIBs. It was synthesized by a green and environmentally friendly in situ solvothermal condensation reaction. When applied in LIBs, the PIAQ exhibits an outstanding reversible specific capacity (1231 mA h g-1 at 200 mA g-1), excellent long-term cycle stability (486 mA h g-1, 1000 cycles at 1 A g-1), and good rate performance. As further revealed by d. functional theory (DFT) calcns., the Li storage mechanism of PIAQ is a reversible process assocd. with a six-step insertion/deintercalation of 16 Li+ per mol., which is well consistent with the exptl. results. Both the structural stability and excellent performance of PIAQ make it one of the most promising org. electrode materials for next-generation LIBs.

      Boosting lithium storage in covalent organic framework via activation of 14-electron redox chemistry
      Lei Zhendong; Yang Qinsi; Xu Yi; Guo Siyu; Liu Hao; Wang Yong; Lei Zhendong; Sun Weiwei; Lv Li-Ping; Zhang Yong
      Nature communications (2018), 9 (1), 576 ISSN:.
      Conjugated polymeric molecules have been heralded as promising electrode materials for the next-generation energy-storage technologies owing to their chemical flexibility at the molecular level, environmental benefit, and cost advantage. However, before any practical implementation takes place, the low capacity, poor structural stability, and sluggish ion/electron diffusion kinetics remain the obstacles that have to be overcome. Here, we report the synthesis of a few-layered two-dimensional covalent organic framework trapped by carbon nanotubes as the anode of lithium-ion batteries. Remarkably, upon activation, this organic electrode delivers a large reversible capacity of 1536 mAh g(-1) and can sustain 500 cycles at 100 mA g(-1). Aided by theoretical calculations and electrochemical probing of the electrochemical behavior at different stages of cycling, the storage mechanism is revealed to be governed by 14-electron redox chemistry for a covalent organic framework monomer with one lithium ion per C=N group and six lithium ions per benzene ring. This work may pave the way to the development of high-capacity electrodes for organic rechargeable batteries.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1MvpsFekuw%253D%253D&md5=c5f604808815d9de68a8456c1578d1f7

      Luo, C.; Fan, X.; Ma, Z.; Gao, T.; Wang, C. Self-Healing Chemistry between Organic Material and Binder for Stable Sodium-Ion Batteries. Chem. 2017, 3 (6), 1050– 1062,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chempr.2017.09.004
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      75
      Self-Healing Chemistry between Organic Material and Binder for Stable Sodium-Ion Batteries
      Luo, Chao; Fan, Xiulin; Ma, Zhaohui; Gao, Tao; Wang, Chunsheng
      Chem (2017), 3 (6), 1050-1062CODEN: CHEMVE; ISSN:2451-9294. (Cell Press)
      One of the major challenges for high-energy sodium-ion batteries is the mech. fracture triggered by large vol. change. To circumvent pulverization-induced capacity decay, self-healing chem. between binder and active material is crit. but is never reported. Here, we report a self-healing electrode with hydrogen bonding between an oxygen-rich active material, sodium rhodizonate dibasic (SRD), and a hydroxyl-rich binder, sodium alginate (SA). During the sodiation of microsized SRD, cracks induced by vol. expansion expose a new oxygen-rich surface, whereas the SA binder fills these cracks under pressure generated by vol. expansion and binds the pulverized SRD together by hydrogen bonding between SRD and SA. Self-healing between hydroxyl-rich binder and oxygen-rich active material is a universal strategy for mitigating the pulverization-induced capacity decay of active materials, as demonstrated by the longer cycle life of the SRD electrode with other hydroxyl-rich binders, polyacrylic acid, and xanthan gum than with hydroxyl-free polytetrafluoroethylene binder.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvF2lsb%252FN&md5=6cc512dcf26e75d291bd0c7d4481cc48

      Luo, C.; Zhu, Y.; Xu, Y.; Liu, Y.; Gao, T.; Wang, J.; Wang, C. Graphene Oxide Wrapped Croconic Acid Disodium Salt for Sodium Ion Battery Electrodes. J. Power Sources 2014, 250, 372– 378,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2013.10.131
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      76
      Graphene oxide wrapped croconic acid disodium salt for sodium ion battery electrodes
      Luo, Chao; Zhu, Yujie; Xu, Yunhua; Liu, Yihang; Gao, Tao; Wang, Jing; Wang, Chunsheng
      Journal of Power Sources (2014), 250 (), 372-378CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Croconic acid disodium salt (CADS), a renewable or recyclable org. compd., is studied as an anode material in Na ion battery for the 1st time. The pristine micro-sized CADS delivers a high capacity of 246.7 mA h g-1, but it suffers from fast capacity decay during charge/discharge cycles. The detailed study reveals that the severe capacity loss is mainly attributed to the pulverization of CADS particles induced by the large vol. change during sodiation/de-sodiation rather than the generally believed dissoln. of CADS in the org. electrolyte. Minimizing the particle size can effectively suppress the pulverization, thus improving the cycling stability. Wrapping CADS with graphene oxide by ultrasonic spray pyrolysis can enhance the integration and cond. of CADS electrodes, thus providing a high capacity of 293 mA h g-1.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvFOitL7P&md5=adafe5a015bc9a32e3766eed0062ea58

      Extended π-Conjugated System for Fast-Charge and -Discharge Sodium-Ion Batteries
      Wang, Chengliang; Xu, Yang; Fang, Yaoguo; Zhou, Min; Liang, Liying; Singh, Sukhdeep; Zhao, Huaping; Schober, Andreas; Lei, Yong
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2015), 137 (8), 3124-3130CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Org. sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are potential alternatives of current com. inorg. lithium-ion batteries for portable electronics (esp. wearable electronics) because of their low cost and flexibility, making them possible to meet the future flexible and large-scale requirements. However, only a few org. SIBs have been reported so far, and most of them either were tested in a very slow rate or suffered significant performance degrdn. when cycled under high rate. Here, we are focusing on the mol. design for improving the battery performance and addressing the current challenge of fast-charge and -discharge. Through reasonable mol. design strategy, we demonstrate that the extension of the π-conjugated system is an efficient way to improve the high rate performance, leading to much enhanced capacity and cyclability with full recovery even after cycled under c.d. as high as 10 A g-1.

      78
      Organic Thiocarboxylate Electrodes for a Room-Temperature Sodium-Ion Battery Delivering an Ultrahigh Capacity
      Zhao, Hongyang; Wang, Jianwei; Zheng, Yuheng; Li, Ju; Han, Xiaogang; He, Gang; Du, Yaping
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2017), 56 (48), 15334-15338CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Org. room-temp. sodium-ion battery electrodes with carboxylate and carbonyl groups have been widely studied. Herein, for the first time, we report a family of sodium-ion battery electrodes obtained by replacing stepwise the oxygen atoms with sulfur atoms in the carboxylate groups of sodium terephthalate which improves electron delocalization, elec. cond. and sodium uptake capacity. The versatile strategy based on mol. engineering greatly enhances the specific capacity of org. electrodes with the same carbon scaffold. By introducing two sulfur atoms to a single carboxylate scaffold, the mol. solid reaches a reversible capacity of 466 mAh g-1 at a c.d. of 50 mA g-1. When four sulfur atoms are introduced, the capacity increases to 567 mAh g-1 at a c.d. of 50 mA g-1, which is the highest capacity value reported for org. sodium-ion battery anodes until now.

      López-Herraiz, M.; Castillo-Martínez, E.; Carretero-González, J.; Carrasco, J.; Rojo, T.; Armand, M. Oligomeric-Schiff Bases as Negative Electrodes for Sodium Ion Batteries: Unveiling the Nature of Their Active Redox Centers. Energy Environ. Sci. 2015, 8 (11), 3233– 3241,  DOI: 10.1039/C5EE01832C
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      79
      Oligomeric-Schiff bases as negative electrodes for sodium ion batteries: unveiling the nature of their active redox centers
      Lopez-Herraiz, Maria; Castillo-Martinez, Elizabeth; Carretero-Gonzalez, Javier; Carrasco, Javier; Rojo, Teofilo; Armand, Michel
      Energy & Environmental Science (2015), 8 (11), 3233-3241CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Oligomeric Schiff bases with carboxylate end-groups are cryst., electrochem. active materials at voltages below 1.2 V vs. Na+/Na. This low redox voltage along with delivered capacities up to 340 mA h g-1 makes them potential anode materials for sodium ion batteries. The electrochem. performance is optimized by maximizing the no. of active units with respect to the total chain length. We report for the first time the electrochem. activity of the 10-π-electron end group (--OOC-.vphi.-C=N-) (.vphi. refers to the Ph group) and central (-N=C-.vphi.-C=N-) Huckel units. This enhanced activity is due to the larger stability of planar mol. regions with respect to out-of-plane inactive (--OOC-.vphi.-N=C-) and (-C=N-.vphi.-N=C-), as confirmed by DFT calcns.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtlyjtLjP&md5=30cfea7ed20bc049681a872b862495a9

      Reversible Redox Chemistry of Azo Compounds for Sodium-Ion Batteries
      Luo, Chao; Xu, Gui-Liang; Ji, Xiao; Hou, Singyuk; Chen, Long; Wang, Fei; Jiang, Jianjun; Chen, Zonghai; Ren, Yang; Amine, Khalil; Wang, Chunsheng
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (11), 2879-2883CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Sustainable sodium-ion batteries (SSIBs) using renewable org. electrodes are promising alternatives to lithium-ion batteries for the large-scale renewable energy storage. However, the lack of high-performance anode material impedes the development of SSIBs. Herein, we report a new type of org. anode material based on azo group for SSIBs. Azobenzene-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid sodium salt is used as a model to investigate the electrochem. behaviors and reaction mechanism of azo compd. It exhibits a reversible capacity of 170 mAh g-1 at 0.2C. When c.d. is increased to 20C, the reversible capacities of 98 mAh g-1 can be retained for 2000 cycles, demonstrating excellent cycling stability and high rate capability. The detailed characterizations reveal that azo group acts as an electrochem. active site to reversibly bond with Na+. The reversible redox chem. between azo compd. and Na ions offer opportunities for developing long-cycle-life and high-rate SSIBs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFektr8%253D&md5=23f9ac4cd12c95cf0be16499442bbe9a
    81. 81
      Lee, M.; Hong, J.; Lopez, J.; Sun, Y.; Feng, D.; Lim, K.; Chueh, W. C.; Toney, M. F.; Cui, Y.; Bao, Z. High-Performance Sodium-Organic Battery by Realizing Four-Sodium Storage in Disodium Rhodizonate. Nat. Energy 2017, 2 (11), 861– 868,  DOI: 10.1038/s41560-017-0014-y
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      High-performance sodium-organic battery by realizing four-sodium storage in disodium rhodizonate
      Lee, Minah; Hong, Jihyun; Lopez, Jeffrey; Sun, Yongming; Feng, Dawei; Lim, Kipil; Chueh, William C.; Toney, Michael F.; Cui, Yi; Bao, Zhenan
      Nature Energy (2017), 2 (11), 861-868CODEN: NEANFD; ISSN:2058-7546. (Nature Research)
      Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) for grid-scale applications need active materials that combine a high energy d. with sustainability. Given the high theor. specific capacity 501 mAh g-1, and Earth abundance of disodium rhodizonate (Na2C6O6), it is one of the most promising cathodes for SIBs. However, substantially lower reversible capacities have been obtained compared with the theor. value and the understanding of this discrepancy has been limited. Here, we reveal that irreversible phase transformation of Na2C6O6 during cycling is the origin of the deteriorating redox activity of Na2C6O6. The active-particle size and electrolyte conditions were identified as key factors to decrease the activation barrier of the phase transformation during desodiation. On the basis of this understanding, we achieved four-sodium storage in a Na2C6O6 electrode with a reversible capacity of 484 mAh g-1, an energy d. of 726 Wh kg-1cathode, an energy efficiency above 87% and a good cycle retention.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitVehu78%253D&md5=c2538a0394fd8a1b89f4465c052003f5
    82. 82
      Tang, M.; Zhu, S.; Liu, Z.; Jiang, C.; Wu, Y.; Li, H.; Wang, B.; Wang, E.; Ma, J.; Wang, C. Tailoring π-Conjugated Systems: From π-π Stacking to High-Rate-Performance Organic Cathodes. Chem. 2018, 4 (11), 2600– 2614,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chempr.2018.08.014
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      82
      Tailoring π-Conjugated Systems: From π-π Stacking to High-Rate-Performance Organic Cathodes
      Tang, Mi; Zhu, Shaolong; Liu, Ziteng; Jiang, Cheng; Wu, Yanchao; Li, Hongyang; Wang, Bo; Wang, Erjing; Ma, Jing; Wang, Chengliang
      Chem (2018), 4 (11), 2600-2614CODEN: CHEMVE; ISSN:2451-9294. (Cell Press)
      Org. sodium-ion batteries (OSIBs) have numerous promising advantages for foreseeable large-scale applications, particularly including the convenience of performance optimization through mol. design. However, the reported org. cathodes still suffer from limited capacity, low cyclability, and poor rate performance. The tailoring of the π-conjugated system reported here can enhance the π-π intermol. interactions, leading to insoly., long-range layer-by-layer π-π stacking, fast-charge transport, and extraordinary stability and ionic cond. (10-9 cm2 s-1). Consequently, the obtained cathodes delivered high electrochem. performance with high capacity (∼290 mAh g-1), superior fast-charge-discharge ability (∼160 and 100 mAh g-1 at 10 and 50 A g-1, resp.), and ultra-long cycle life (capacity as high as 97 mAh g-1 after 10,000 cycles at 50 A g-1).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitFGgtb3N&md5=0d98e6f7053c76ac3b610118c394f04b

      Hu, Y.; Zhang, K.; Hu, H.; Wang, S.; Ye, D.; Monteiro, M. J.; Jia, Z.; Wang, L. Molecular-Level Anchoring of Polymer Cathodes on Carbon Nanotubes towards Rapid-Rate and Long-Cycle Sodium-Ion Storage. Mater. Chem. Front. 2018, 2 (10), 1805– 1810,  DOI: 10.1039/C8QM00163D
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      83
      Molecular-level anchoring of polymer cathodes on carbon nanotubes towards rapid-rate and long-cycle sodium-ion storage
      Hu, Yuxiang; Zhang, Kai; Hu, Han; Wang, Songcan; Ye, Delai; Monteiro, Michael J.; Jia, Zhongfan; Wang, Lianzhou
      Materials Chemistry Frontiers (2018), 2 (10), 1805-1810CODEN: MCFAC5; ISSN:2052-1537. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Nitroxide radical polymers (NRPs) have attracted increasing research interest as promising cathode materials for sodium ion batteries, primarily owing to their high-voltage (ca. 3.47 V vs. Na+/Na), environment compatibility, low-cost, and rich resources. However, such NRP cathodes are subjected to low rate-capacity and poor cycling stability because of their inferior cond. and dissol. in the electrolyte. Herein, we report a "mol. glue" strategy to anchor pyrene functionalized NRPs on a highly conductive carbon nanotube (CNT) matrix through π-π interactions between the pyrene functional groups and CNTs. As such, the NRP layer is homogeneously "glued" on the carbon substrates and the non-covalent interaction with CNTs drastically improves the insoly. and elec. cond. of the composite. Benefiting from these structural merits, the new nanocomposite exhibits a record cyclability (92% capacity retention at a high c.d. of 2.2 A g-1 after 6000 cycles) and remarkable rate capability (78 mA h g-1 at 5.5 A g-1) when evaluated as a high-voltage cathode material for SIBs. This work demonstrates the importance of rational hybridization of radical polymers and carbon substrates for enhanced electrochem. performance and provides insightful guides for designing high-performance polymer-based composites for energy storage applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXht1yrsbjI&md5=bedea7a385744ecb093d4c208774dc7a

      Wang, S.; Wang, L.; Zhu, Z.; Hu, Z.; Zhao, Q.; Chen, J. All Organic Sodium-Ion Batteries with Na4C8H2O6. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2014, 53 (23), 5892– 5896,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201400032
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      All Organic Sodium-Ion Batteries with Na4C8H2O6
      Wang, Shiwen; Wang, Lijiang; Zhu, Zhiqiang; Hu, Zhe; Zhao, Qing; Chen, Jun
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2014), 53 (23), 5892-5896CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Developing org. compds. with multifunctional groups to be used as electrode materials for rechargeable sodium-ion batteries is very important. The org. tetrasodium salt of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (Na4DHTPA; Na4C8H2O6), which was prepd. through a green one-pot method, was investigated at potential windows of 1.6-2.8 V as the pos. electrode or 0.1-1.8 V as the neg. electrode (vs. Na+/Na), each delivering compatible and stable capacities of ca. 180 mAh g-1 with excellent cycling. A combination of electrochem., spectroscopic and computational studies revealed that reversible uptake/removal of two Na+ ions is assocd. with the enolate groups at 1.6-2.8 V (Na2C8H2O6/Na4C8H2O6) and the carboxylate groups at 0.1-1.8 V (Na4C8H2O6/Na6C8H2O6). The use of Na4C8H2O6 as the initial active materials for both electrodes provided the first example of all-org. rocking-chair SIBs with an av. operation voltage of 1.8 V and a practical energy d. of about 65 Wh kg-1.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXjtVGmsro%253D&md5=53c2fd61d52e21867a1cba20336404ca

      Organic electrode for non-aqueous potassium-ion batteries
      Chen, Yanan; Luo, Wei; Carter, Marcus; Zhou, Lihui; Dai, Jiaqi; Fu, Kun; Lacey, Steven; Li, Tian; Wan, Jiayu; Han, Xiaogang; Bao, Yanping; Hu, Liangbing
      Nano Energy (2015), 18 (), 205-211CODEN: NEANCA; ISSN:2211-2855. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Potassium-ion (K-ion) batteries can be an attractive alternative for grid-scale energy storage due to the abundance of K resources. For the first time, we designed and fabricated a non-aq. K-ion battery (KIB) by employing 3,4,9,10-perylene-tetracarboxylicacid-dianhydride (PTCDA) as the cathode. The PTCDA electrode exhibits a high capacity of 131 mA h g-1 in the potential range of 1.5-3.5 V vs. K/K+, which corresponds to the insertion of two K ions per PTCDA mol. The PTCDA cathode also shows great cycling performance, with a capacity retention of 66.1% over 200 cycles. Furthermore, K11PTCDA can be obtained when discharging PTCDA to 0.01 V vs. K/K+, which delivers a high capacity of 753 mA h g-1. The excellent electrochem. performance makes PTCDA a promising org. electrode based on K-ion chem. for grid-scale energy storage.

      Poly(anthraquinonyl sulfide) cathode for potassium-ion batteries
      Jian, Zelang; Liang, Yanliang; Perez, Ismael A. Rodriguez; Yao, Yan; Ji, Xiulei
      Electrochemistry Communications (2016), 71 (), 5-8CODEN: ECCMF9; ISSN:1388-2481. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) are a promising sustainable energy storage technol. due to the high abundance and low cost of potassium. Carbon anode materials for KIBs have seen great successes, but the development of cathode materials is yet to catch up. In this study, poly(anthraquinonyl sulfide) (PAQS) is evaluated as a cathode material for KIBs. It exhibits a high reversible capacity of 200 mAh/g, which is the highest value for a potassium storage cathode material. The cell shows two slopes averaged at 2.1 and 1.6 V vs. K+/K. It shows a good cycling performance with the capacity retention of 75% after 50 cycles at a rate of C/10. These preliminary results indicate that PAQS is a promising cathode material for KIBs.

      Few-Layered Boronic Ester Based Covalent Organic Frameworks/Carbon Nanotube Composites for High-Performance K-Organic Batteries
      Chen, Xiudong; Zhang, Hang; Ci, Chenggang; Sun, Weiwei; Wang, Yong
      ACS Nano (2019), 13 (3), 3600-3607CODEN: ANCAC3; ISSN:1936-0851. (American Chemical Society)
      Org. electrodes for low-cost potassium ion batteries (PIBs) are attracting more interest by virtue of their mol. diversity, environmental friendliness, and operation safety. But the sluggish potassium diffusion kinetics, dissoln. in org. electrolyte, poor electronic cond., and low reversible capacities are several drawbacks compared with inorg. counterparts. Herein, the boronic ester based covalent org. framework (COF) material is successfully prepd. on the exterior surface of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) via rational design of the org. condensation reaction and used as an anode material for PIBs. The few-layered structure of [email protected] can provide more exposed active sites and fast K+ kinetics. It exhibits ultrahigh potassium storage performances (large reversible capacities of 288 mAh g-1 after 500 cycles at 0.1 A g-1 and 161 mAh g-1 after 4000 cycles at 1 A g-1), which is superior to previous org. electrodes and most inorg. electrodes. Moreover, the K-storage mechanism is proposed to be π-cation interaction between K+ and conjugated π-electrons of benzene rings.

      A small-molecule organic cathode with fast charge-discharge capability for K-ion batteries
      Xiong, Ming; Tang, Wu; Cao, Bei; Yang, Chuluo; Fan, Cong
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2019), 7 (35), 20127-20131CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Perylene-3,4,9,10-tetracarboxylic diimide (PTCDI, 137 mA h g-1) is initially exploited as a new org. cathode for K-ion batteries. In half cells, it can deliver stable capacities of ∼120 mA h g-1 (600 cycles) at 4 A g-1 and ∼80 mA h g-1 at 10 A g-1. In full cells with a working voltage of above 1 V, PTCDI can display an av. capacity of ∼127 mA h g-1 at 50 mA g-1 over 30 cycles.

      An organic cathode with high capacities for fast-charge potassium-ion batteries
      Tang, Mi; Wu, Yanchao; Chen, Yuan; Jiang, Cheng; Zhu, Shaolong; Zhuo, Shuming; Wang, Chengliang
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2019), 7 (2), 486-492CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) are promising candidates for future large-scale energy storage due to the high abundance of potassium and comparable electrode potential to that of lithium. However, most of the reported cathodes of PIBs still suffer from limited capacity, low cyclability and poor rate performance probably due to the bulky size of K-ions. In this work, we report the application of poly(pentacenetetrone sulfide) (PPTS) as a cathode for PIBs. The PPTS cathode exhibited high reversible capacity (∼260 mAh g-1 at 0.1 A g-1), fast-discharge/charge ability (∼160 mAh g-1 at a c.d. of 10 A g-1) and long cycle life (capacity higher than 190 mAh g-1 even after 3000 cycles at 5 A g-1). To the best of our knowledge, these performances are among the best results of all the reported inorg./org. materials for potassium-ion batteries. We also systematically studied methods for inhibiting potassium dendrites. This work will stimulate growing interest in org. cathodes for PIBs, provide practical pathways toward safe K metal anodes and pave the way to achieve PIBs for large-scale applications.

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Vitamin K as a high-performance organic anode material for rechargeable potassium ion batteries
      Xue, Qing; Li, Dongning; Huang, Yongxin; Zhang, Xiaoxiao; Ye, Yusheng; Fan, Ersha; Li, Li; Wu, Feng; Chen, Renjie
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2018), 6 (26), 12559-12564CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Potassium ion batteries (PIBs) have drawn considerable attention owing to the low cost and high natural abundance of potassium. However, risks assocd. with the extremely high activity of potassium metal have motivated the search for alternative anode materials with high performance and good safety. Herein, an essential element of the human body, vitamin K, is applied as an org. redox-active electrode material for PIBs. This biomol. has a quinone structure with two active redox carbonyl groups, which can provide a theor. specific capacity of 313.5 mA h g-1. After hybridization with graphene nanotubes (GNTs), the composite delivered a high reversible capacity of 300 mA h g-1 and maintained 222.3 mA h g-1 after 100 cycles at a c.d. of 100 mA g-1 with a coulombic efficiency of ∼99%. Moreover, at higher current densities of 200, 500, and 1000 mA g-1, it maintained high discharge capacities of 203, 181, and 165 mA h g-1, resp. The enhanced electrochem. performance of the composite might be attributed to the improved electronic cond. and inhibition of vitamin K dissoln. into the org. electrolyte. This biomol.-based electrode offers a new alternative approach to the development of PIBs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Zhao, Q.; Wang, J.; Lu, Y.; Li, Y.; Liang, G.; Chen, J. Oxocarbon Salts for Fast Rechargeable Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55 (40), 12528– 12532,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201607194
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Oxocarbon Salts for Fast Rechargeable Batteries
      Zhao, Qing; Wang, Jianbin; Lu, Yong; Li, Yixin; Liang, Guangxin; Chen, Jun
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (40), 12528-12532CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Oxocarbon salts (M2(CO)n) prepd. through one-pot proton exchange reactions with different metal ions (M =Li, Na, K) and frameworks (n =4, 5, 6) have been rationally designed and used as electrodes in rechargeable Li, Na, and K-ion batteries. The results show that M2(CO)5/M2(CO)6 salts can insert 2-4 metal ions reversibly, while M2(CO)4 shows less electrochem. activity. We discovered that the K2C6O6 electrode enables ultrafast potassium-ion insertion/extn. with 212 mAh/g at 0.2 C and 164 mAh/g at 10 C. This behavior can be ascribed to the natural semiconductor property of K2C6O6 with a narrow band gap close to 0.9 eV, the high ionic cond. of the K-ion electrolyte, and the facilitated K-ion diffusion process. A 1st example of a K-ion battery with a rocking-chair reaction mechanism of K2C6O6 as cathode and K4C6O6 as anode is introduced, displaying an operation voltage of 1.1 V and an energy d. of 35 Wh/Kg. This work provides an interesting strategy for constructing rapid K-ion batteries with renewable and abundant potassium materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhsVymtLnP&md5=55cb35502b8b27f7c3d19a4a6c1c8a8c
    93. 93
      Tian, B.; Zheng, J.; Zhao, C.; Liu, C.; Su, C.; Tang, W.; Li, X.; Ning, G. H. Carbonyl-Based Polyimide and Polyquinoneimide for Potassium-Ion Batteries. J. Mater. Chem. A 2019, 7 (16), 9997– 10003,  DOI: 10.1039/C9TA00647H
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      93
      Carbonyl-based polyimide and polyquinoneimide for potassium-ion batteries
      Tian, Bingbing; Zheng, Ji; Zhao, Chenxi; Liu, Cuibo; Su, Chenliang; Tang, Wei; Li, Xing; Ning, Guo-Hong
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2019), 7 (16), 9997-10003CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Although potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) are potentially alternative energy storage systems to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), only few org. materials can be used as candidate electrodes for KIBs. Herein, we synthesized a class of carbonyl-based org. polymers including two 1D linear polymers, namely polyimide (PI) and polyquinoneimide (PQI), and a 2D conjugated microporous polymer (PI-CMP) as stable org. cathode materials for KIBs. The investigation of their electrochem. performance revealed the structure-property relationship. For instance, the direct connection between two electrochem. active org. mols. could increase the initial capacity; however, the tight distribution of potassiated carbonyl groups might cause rapid capacity fading. In addn., the extended π-conjugation could improve the cycling stability and rate performance. Furthermore, the redox mechanisms with potassium have been fully investigated utilizing FTIR, XPS measurements and DFT calcns., suggesting that the carbonyl group is the potassium-ion binding site with excellent reversibility for KIBs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXlslenurg%253D&md5=b547aef3c81f104dc606c176ff31596f

      Pan, B.; Zhou, D.; Huang, J.; Zhang, L.; Burrell, A. K.; Vaughey, J. T.; Zhang, Z.; Liao, C. 2,5-Dimethoxy-1,4-Benzoquinone (DMBQ) as Organic Cathode for Rechargeable Magnesium-Ion Batteries. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (3), A580– A583,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0021605jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      2,5-Dimethoxy-1,4-Benzoquinone (DMBQ) as Organic Cathode for Rechargeable Magnesium-Ion Batteries
      Pan, Baofei; Zhou, Dehua; Huang, Jinhua; Zhang, Lu; Burrell, Anthony K.; Vaughey, John T.; Zhang, Zhengcheng; Liao, Chen
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (3), A580-A583CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      2,5-Dimethoxy-1,4-benzoquinone (DMBQ) was restudied as a cathode material with Mg electrolytes that are capable of plating/stripping Mg for rechargeable Mg-ion batteries. Two electrolytes, the Mg bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide mixed with MgCl2 in dimethoxyethane (Mg(TFSI)2-2MgCl2 in DME) electrolyte, and the Mg(TFSI)2 in diglyme were selected. The Mg(TFSI)2-2MgCl2 in DME enabled Mg-DMBQ batteries with a discharge potentials >2.0 V vs. Mg/Mg2+, which is superior to the previous reported potential in Mg-DMBQ batteries with conventional Mg salt-based electrolytes (1.1 V, vs. Mg/Mg2+), and also excels the known Chevrel phase Mo6S8 in Mg-ion batteries (1.2 V, vs. Mg/Mg2+).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xos1WrsQ%253D%253D&md5=4b79275ac0030845043877888b03a6a4
    95. 95
      Rodríguez-Pérez, I. A.; Yuan, Y.; Bommier, C.; Wang, X.; Ma, L.; Leonard, D. P.; Lerner, M. M.; Carter, R. G.; Wu, T.; Greaney, P. A.; Lu, J.; Ji, X. Mg-Ion Battery Electrode: An Organic Solid’s Herringbone Structure Squeezed upon Mg-Ion Insertion. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2017, 139 (37), 13031– 13037,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.7b06313
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      95
      Mg-Ion Battery Electrode: An Organic Solid's Herringbone Structure Squeezed upon Mg-Ion Insertion
      Rodriguez-Perez, Ismael A.; Yuan, Yifei; Bommier, Clement; Wang, Xingfeng; Ma, Lu; Leonard, Daniel P.; Lerner, Michael M.; Carter, Rich G.; Wu, Tianpin; Greaney, P. Alex; Lu, Jun; Ji, Xiulei
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (37), 13031-13037CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      We report that cryst. 3,4,9,10-perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (PTCDA), an org. solid, is highly amenable to host divalent metal ions, i.e., Mg2+ and Ca2+, in aq. electrolytes, where the van der Waals structure is intrinsically superior in hosting charge-dense ions. We observe that the divalent nature of Mg2+ causes unique squeezing deformation of the electrode structure, where it contracts and expands in different crystallog. directions when hosting the inserted Mg-ions. This phenomenon is revealed exptl. by ex situ X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy, and is investigated theor. by first-principles calcns. Interestingly, hosting one Mg2+ ion requires the coordination from three PTCDA mols. in adjacent columns of stacked mols., which rotates the columns, thus reducing the (011) spacing but increasing the (021) spacing. We demonstrate that a PTCDA Mg-ion electrode delivers a reversible capacity of 125 mA h g-1, which may include a minor contribution of hydronium storage, a good rate capability by retaining 75 mA h g-1 at 500 mA g-1 (or 3.7 C), and a stable cycle life. We also report Ca2+ storage in PTCDA, where a reversible capacity of over 80 mA h g-1 is delivered.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtlKhurrL&md5=6fdf9399b3ff6a57c00ac24347e9feb9
    96. 96
      Pan, B.; Huang, J.; Feng, Z.; Zeng, L.; He, M.; Zhang, L.; Vaughey, J. T.; Bedzyk, M. J.; Fenter, P.; Zhang, Z.; Burrell, A. K.; Liao, C. Polyanthraquinone-Based Organic Cathode for High-Performance Rechargeable Magnesium-Ion Batteries. Adv. Energy Mater. 2016, 6 (14), 1600140,  DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201600140
      [Crossref], Google Scholar

    97. 97
      Fan, X.; Wang, F.; Ji, X.; Wang, R.; Gao, T.; Hou, S.; Chen, J.; Deng, T.; Li, X.; Chen, L.; Luo, C.; Wang, L.; Wang, C. A Universal Organic Cathode for Ultrafast Lithium and Multivalent Metal Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2018, 57 (24), 7146– 7150,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201803703
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      A Universal Organic Cathode for Ultrafast Lithium- and Multivalent Metal Batteries
      Fan, Xiulin; Wang, Fei; Ji, Xiao; Wang, Ruixing; Gao, Tao; Hou, Singyuk; Chen, Ji; Deng, Tao; Li, Xiaogang; Chen, Long; Luo, Chao; Wang, Luning; Wang, Chunsheng
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (24), 7146-7150CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Low-cost multivalent battery chemistries (Mg2+, Al3+) were extensively investigated for large-scale energy storage applications. However, their commercialization is plagued by the poor power d. and cycle life of cathodes. A universal [email protected] ([email protected]) cathode is now presented that can reversibly store various cations with different valences (Li+, Mg2+, Al3+) at an extremely fast rate. The ion-coordination charge storage mechanism of [email protected] is systemically investigated. Full cells using [email protected] cathodes and corresponding metal anodes exhibit long cycle life (>10000 cycles), fast kinetics (>20 C), and wide operating temp. range (-40 to 50°), making the low-cost industrial polyimides universal cathodes for different multivalent metal batteries. The stable ion-coordinated mechanism opens a new foundation for the development of high-energy and high-power multivalent batteries.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXpsVOltLs%253D&md5=e27dc9d2bc644af0f0c64b7a85edda92
    98. 98
      Kim, D. J.; Yoo, D. J.; Otley, M. T.; Prokofjevs, A.; Pezzato, C.; Owczarek, M.; Lee, S. J.; Choi, J. W.; Stoddart, J. F. Rechargeable Aluminium Organic Batteries. Nat. Energy 2019, 4 (1), 51– 59,  DOI: 10.1038/s41560-018-0291-0
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      98
      Rechargeable aluminium organic batteries
      Kim, Dong Jun; Yoo, Dong-Joo; Otley, Michael T.; Prokofjevs, Aleksandrs; Pezzato, Cristian; Owczarek, Magdalena; Lee, Seung Jong; Choi, Jang Wook; Stoddart, J. Fraser
      Nature Energy (2019), 4 (1), 51-59CODEN: NEANFD; ISSN:2058-7546. (Nature Research)
      Since aluminum is one of the most widely available elements in Earth's crust, developing rechargeable aluminum batteries offers an ideal opportunity to deliver cells with high energy-to-price ratios. Nevertheless, finding appropriate host electrodes for insertion of aluminum (complex) ions remains a fundamental challenge. Here, we demonstrate a strategy for designing active materials for rechargeable aluminum batteries. This strategy entails the use of redox-active triangular phenanthrenequinone-based macrocycles, which form layered superstructures resulting in the reversible insertion and extn. of a cationic aluminum complex. This architecture exhibits an outstanding electrochem. performance with a reversible capacity of 110 mA h g-1 along with a superior cyclability of up to 5,000 cycles. Furthermore, electrodes composed of these macrocycles blended with graphite flakes result in higher specific capacity, electronic cond. and areal loading. These findings constitute a major advance in the design of rechargeable aluminum batteries and represent a good starting point for addressing affordable large-scale energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFSgurvJ&md5=aa31238a17b46dad82f3a40b01ab3aaa

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Magnesium ion based organic secondary batteries
      Lu, Deng; Liu, Haiqing; Huang, Tao; Xu, Zhixiao; Ma, Lie; Yang, Peng; Qiang, Peirong; Zhang, Fan; Wu, Dongqing
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2018), 6 (36), 17297-17302CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A magnesium ion based org. secondary battery (MIOB) is fabricated by using polytriphenylamine as the cathode, perylene diimide-ethylene diamine as the anode and an anhyd. acetonitrile soln. of magnesium perchlorate as the electrolyte. Based on a dual-ion battery mechanism, the MIOB manifests high capacities and good cycling stability. Moreover, the good electrochem. properties of the MIOB can still be reserved even at low temps. and in flexible pouch cells. The excellent battery performance of the MIOB can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the dual-ion energy storage mechanism and the utilization of org. electrode materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsFKqsLbO&md5=eb05037104a185eace04f7f498d5e51d

      A dual-ion organic symmetric battery constructed from phenazine-based artificial bipolar molecules
      Dai, Gaole; He, Yan; Niu, Zhihui; He, Ping; Zhang, Changkun; Zhao, Yu; Zhang, Xiaohong; Zhou, Haoshen
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2019), 58 (29), 9902-9906CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Sym. batteries received an increasing research interest in the past few years because of their simplified fabrication process and reduced manufg. cost. In this study, we propose the first dual-ion org. sym. cell based on a mol. anion of 4,4'-(phenazine-5,10-diyl)dibenzoate. The alkali salt of 4,4'-(phenazine-5,10-diyl)dibenzoate allows a facile transport of cations and large anions, and remains stable in both oxidized and reduced states. The large p.d. between phenazine and benzoate results in a high cell voltage of 2.5 V and an energy d. of 127 Wh kg-1 at a current rate of 1 C. The introduction of bipolar org. materials may further consolidate the development of sym. batteries that are fabricated from abundant elements and environmentally friendly materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXosFKjur0%253D&md5=f87429b816de7bab9d9f77200bd7b9c4

      Dong, X.; Guo, Z.; Guo, Z.; Wang, Y.; Xia, Y. Organic Batteries Operated at −70°C. Joule 2018, 2 (5), 902– 913,  DOI: 10.1016/j.joule.2018.01.017
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      101
      Organic Batteries Operated at -70°C
      Dong, Xiaoli; Guo, Zhaowei; Guo, Ziyang; Wang, Yonggang; Xia, Yongyao
      Joule (2018), 2 (5), 902-913CODEN: JOULBR; ISSN:2542-4351. (Cell Press)
      Low-temp. operation is a great challenge facing rechargeable batteries, and insufficient ionic cond. and freezing of electrolyte are generally considered as the main reasons for this issue. Herein, an Et acetate-based electrolyte with a sufficient ionic cond. of 0.2 mS cm-1 at the ultra-low temp. of -70°C is first used to fabricate intercalation compds.-based Li-ion batteries (LIBs) and an org. electrodes-based rechargeable battery, resp., to clarify their low-temp. behavior. It is demonstrated that the LIBs cannot work at -70°C because of the sluggish desolvation of Li+. However, the rechargeable battery using org. electrodes can work well at such low temp. and retains ∼70% of capacity at room temp., owing to the fast kinetics of charge storage on the surface groups or in the large interstitial space of org. solids. These results indicate a new way for developing low-temp. batteries.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtVSmtLjE&md5=6adf6192b4718113b5e1fd007d58ac55

      p- and n-Type bipolar redox-active radical polymer: toward totally organic polymer-based rechargeable devices with variable configuration
      Suga, Takeo; Sugita, Shuhei; Ohshiro, Hiroki; Oyaizu, Kenichi; Nishide, Hiroyuki
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2011), 23 (6), 751-754CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Poly(nitronylnitroxylstyrene) was proven to be a new class of bipolar redox polymer and enabled a totally org.-based rechargeable battery with simple, sym. configuration (poleless battery) and rocking-chair configuration in conjunction with n-type poly(galvinoxyl-styrene). Beside shape flexibility and reduced environmental impact of such plastic-based batteries, bipolar redox-active radical polymers will promise potential applications such as actuators, org. complementary circuits, and org. transistors. Our strategy in developing poly(nitronylnitroxylstyrene), redox stabilization by π-conjugated structure and an org. base, also highlights a new approach for the mol. design of bipolar redox polymers.

      Universal quinone electrodes for long cycle life aqueous rechargeable batteries
      Liang, Yanliang; Jing, Yan; Gheytani, Saman; Lee, Kuan-Yi; Liu, Ping; Facchetti, Antonio; Yao, Yan
      Nature Materials (2017), 16 (8), 841-848CODEN: NMAACR; ISSN:1476-1122. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Aq. rechargeable batteries provide the safety, robustness, affordability, and environmental friendliness necessary for grid storage and elec. vehicle operations, but their adoption is plagued by poor cycle life due to the structural and chem. instability of the anode materials. We report quinones as stable anode materials by exploiting their structurally stable ion-coordination charge storage mechanism and chem. inertness towards aq. electrolytes. Upon rational selection/design of quinone structures, we demonstrate three systems that coupled with industrially established cathodes and electrolytes exhibit long cycle life (≤3000 cycles/3500 h), fast kinetics (≥20C), high anode specific capacity (up to 200-395 mAh/g), and several examples of state-of-the-art specific energy/energy d. (up to 76-92 Wh/Kg/161-208 Wh/L) for several operational pH values (-1 to 15), charge carrier species (H+, Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+), temp. (-35 to 25 °C), and atm. (with/without O), making them a universal anode approach for any aq. battery technol.

      An Environmentally Friendly and Flexible Aqueous Zinc Battery Using an Organic Cathode
      Guo, Zhaowei; Ma, Yuanyuan; Dong, Xiaoli; Huang, Jianhang; Wang, Yonggang; Xia, Yongyao
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (36), 11737-11741CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Rechargeable batteries have been used to power various elec. devices and store energy from renewables, but their toxic components (namely, electrode materials, electrolyte, and separator) generally cause serious environment issues when disused. Such toxicity characteristic makes them difficult to power future wearable electronic devices. Now an environmentally friendly and highly safe rechargeable battery, based on a pyrene-4,5,9,10-tetraone (PTO) cathode and zinc anode in mild aq. electrolyte is presented. The PTO-cathode shows a high specific capacity (336 mAh g-1) for Zn2+ storage with fast kinetics and high reversibility. Thus, the PTO//Zn full cell exhibits a high energy d. (186.7 Wh kg-1), supercapacitor-like power behavior and long-term lifespan (over 1000 cycles). Moreover, a belt-shaped PTO//Zn battery with robust mech. durability and remarkable flexibility is first fabricated to clarify its potential application in wearable electronic devices.

      All-Solid-State Lithium Organic Battery with Composite Polymer Electrolyte and Pillar[5]quinone Cathode
      Zhu, Zhiqiang; Hong, Meiling; Guo, Dongsheng; Shi, Jifu; Tao, Zhanliang; Chen, Jun
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (47), 16461-16464CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The cathode capacity of common lithium ion batteries (LIBs) using inorg. electrodes and liq. electrolytes must be further improved. Alternatively, all-solid-state lithium batteries comprising the electrode of org. compds. can offer much higher capacity. Herein, an all-solid-state lithium battery based on org. pillar[5]quinone (C35H20O10) cathode and composite polymer electrolyte (CPE) is fabricated. The poly(methacrylate) (PMA)/poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)-LiClO4-3 wt. % SiO2 CPE has an optimum ionic cond. of 0.26 mS cm-1 at room temp. Furthermore, pillar[5]quinine cathode in all-solid-state battery rendered an av. operation voltage of ∼2.6 V and a high initial capacity of 418 mAh g-1 with a stable cyclability (94.7% capacity retention after 50 cycles at 0.2C rate) through the reversible redox reactions of enolate/quinonid carbonyl groups, showing favorable prospect for the device application with high capacity.

      Luo, C.; Ji, X.; Chen, J.; Gaskell, K. J.; He, X.; Liang, Y.; Jiang, J.; Wang, C. Solid-State Electrolyte Anchored with a Carboxylated Azo Compound for All-Solid-State Lithium Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2018, 57 (28), 8567– 8571,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201804068

      Solid-State Electrolyte Anchored with a Carboxylated Azo Compound for All-Solid-State Lithium Batteries
      Luo, Chao; Ji, Xiao; Chen, Ji; Gaskell, Karen J.; He, Xinzi; Liang, Yujia; Jiang, Jianjun; Wang, Chunsheng
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (28), 8567-8571CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Org. electrode materials are promising for green and sustainable lithium-ion batteries. However, the high soly. of org. materials in the liq. electrolyte results in the shuttle reaction and fast capacity decay. Herein, azo compds. are firstly applied in all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLB) to suppress the dissoln. challenge. Due to the high compatibility of azobenzene (AB) based compds. to Li3PS4 (LPS) solid electrolyte, the LPS solid electrolyte is used to prevent the dissoln. and shuttle reaction of AB. To maintain the low interface resistance during the large vol. change upon cycling, a carboxylate group is added into AB to provide 4-(phenylazo) benzoic acid lithium salt (PBALS), which could bond with LPS solid electrolyte via the ionic bonding between oxygen in PBALS and lithium ion in LPS. The ionic bonding between the active material and solid electrolyte stabilizes the contact interface and enables the stable cycle life of PBALS in ASSLB.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtVyksLvI&md5=8a2395cc388178db94292a276dc4adee

      Chi, X.; Liang, Y.; Hao, F.; Zhang, Y.; Whiteley, J.; Dong, H.; Hu, P.; Lee, S.; Yao, Y. Tailored Organic Electrode Material Compatible with Sulfide Electrolyte for Stable All-Solid-State Sodium Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2018, 57 (10), 2630– 2634,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201712895
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Tailored Organic Electrode Material Compatible with Sulfide Electrolyte for Stable All-Solid-State Sodium Batteries
      Chi, Xiaowei; Liang, Yanliang; Hao, Fang; Zhang, Ye; Whiteley, Justin; Dong, Hui; Hu, Pu; Lee, Sehee; Yao, Yan
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (10), 2630-2634CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      All-solid-state sodium batteries (ASSSBs) with nonflammable electrolytes and ubiquitous sodium resource are a promising soln. to the safety and cost concerns for lithium-ion batteries. However, the intrinsic mismatch between low anodic decompn. potential of superionic sulfide electrolytes and high operating potentials of sodium-ion cathodes leads to a volatile cathode-electrolyte interface and undesirable cell performance. Here we report a high-capacity org. cathode, Na4C6O6, that is chem. and electrochem. compatible with sulfide electrolytes. A bulk-type ASSSB shows high specific capacity (184 mAh g-1) and one of the highest specific energies (395 Wh kg-1) among intercalation compd.-based ASSSBs. The capacity retentions of 76 % after 100 cycles at 0.1 C and 70 % after 400 cycles at 0.2 C represent the record stability for ASSSBs. Addnl., Na4C6O6 functions as a capable anode material, enabling a sym. all-org. ASSSB with Na4C6O6 as both cathode and anode materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFentrY%253D&md5=75ad4c1ffc5e6c0b8df343698bda9acb
    110. 110
      Hao, F.; Chi, X.; Liang, Y.; Zhang, Y.; Xu, R.; Guo, H.; Terlier, T.; Dong, H.; Zhao, K.; Lou, J.; Yao, Y. Taming Active Material-Solid Electrolyte Interfaces with Organic Cathode for All-Solid-State Batteries. Joule 2019, 3 (5), 1349– 1359,  DOI: 10.1016/j.joule.2019.03.017
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      110
      Taming Active Material-Solid Electrolyte Interfaces with Organic Cathode for All-Solid-State Batteries
      Hao, Fang; Chi, Xiaowei; Liang, Yanliang; Zhang, Ye; Xu, Rong; Guo, Hua; Terlier, Tanguy; Dong, Hui; Zhao, Kejie; Lou, Jun; Yao, Yan
      Joule (2019), 3 (5), 1349-1359CODEN: JOULBR; ISSN:2542-4351. (Cell Press)
      Attaining stable active material-solid electrolyte interfaces is a great challenge in sulfide-based all-solid-state sodium batteries (ASSSBs). A resistive layer forms at the interface upon charging above the anodic stability potential of sulfide electrolytes. In addn., contact failure at the interface during cycling is long known, but a fundamental soln. is not yet available. Herein, we use an org. cathode material, pyrene-4,5,9,10-tetraone (PTO), to enable high-performance ASSSBs. We report, for the first time, a reversible active material-electrolyte interfacial resistance evolution during cycling. We further show for the first time that a low-modulus cathode material such as PTO maintains intimate interfacial contact with solid electrolytes during cycling, thus improving cycle life. The PTO-based cells exhibit a high specific energy (587 Wh kg-1) and a record cycling stability (500 cycles) among ASSSBs. This work reveals an effective cathode material design strategy toward compatibility with solid electrolytes and thus high-performance ASSSBs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtVKgurzL&md5=aca024182fcb793e7090b7aa83f50c0a
    111. 111
      Lin, K.; Gómez-Bombarelli, R.; Beh, E. S.; Tong, L.; Chen, Q.; Valle, A.; Aspuru-Guzik, A.; Aziz, M. J.; Gordon, R. G. A Redox-Flow Battery with an Alloxazine-Based Organic Electrolyte. Nat. Energy 2016, 1 (9), 16102,  DOI: 10.1038/nenergy.2016.102
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      111
      A redox-flow battery with an alloxazine-based organic electrolyte
      Lin, Kaixiang; Gomez-Bombarelli, Rafael; Beh, Eugene S.; Tong, Liuchuan; Chen, Qing; Valle, Alvaro; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Aziz, Michael J.; Gordon, Roy G.
      Nature Energy (2016), 1 (9), 16102CODEN: NEANFD; ISSN:2058-7546. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Redox-flow batteries (RFBs) can store large amts. of elec. energy from variable sources, such as solar and wind. Recently, redox-active org. mols. in aq. RFBs have drawn substantial attention due to their rapid kinetics and low membrane crossover rates. Drawing inspiration from nature, here we report a high-performance aq. RFB utilizing an org. redox compd., alloxazine, which is a tautomer of the isoalloxazine backbone of vitamin B2. It can be synthesized in high yield at room temp. by single-step coupling of inexpensive o-phenylenediamine derivs. and alloxan. The highly alk.-sol. alloxazine 7/8-carboxylic acid produces a RFB exhibiting open-circuit voltage approaching 1.2 V and current efficiency and capacity retention exceeding 99.7% and 99.98% per cycle, resp. Theor. studies indicate that structural modification of alloxazine with electron-donating groups should allow further increases in battery voltage. As an aza-arom. mol. that undergoes reversible redox cycling in aq. electrolyte, alloxazine represents a class of radical-free redox-active orgs. for use in large-scale energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVersrY%253D&md5=1bdb2e213c96396bad489b2404fbc367
    112. 112
      Huskinson, B.; Marshak, M. P.; Suh, C.; Er, S.; Gerhardt, M. R.; Galvin, C. J.; Chen, X.; Aspuru-Guzik, A.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J. A Metal-Free Organic-Inorganic Aqueous Flow Battery. Nature 2014, 505 (7482), 195– 198,  DOI: 10.1038/nature12909
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      112
      A metal-free organic-inorganic aqueous flow battery
      Huskinson, Brian; Marshak, Michael P.; Suh, Changwon; Er, Sueleyman; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Galvin, Cooper J.; Chen, Xudong; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2014), 505 (7482), 195-198CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A class of energy storage materials that exploits the favorable chem. and electrochem. properties of a family of mols. known as quinones is described. The metal-free flow battery based on the redox chem. of 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) is demonstrated. AQDS undergoes extremely rapid and reversible 2-electron 2-proton redn. on a glassy C electrode in H2SO4. An aq. flow battery with inexpensive C electrodes, combining the quinone/hydroquinone couple with the Br2/Br- redox couple, yields a peak galvanic power d. exceeding 0.6 W cm-2 at 1.3 A cm-2. Cycling of this quinone-bromide flow battery showed >99% storage capacity retention per cycle. The org. anthraquinone species can be synthesized from inexpensive commodity chems. This org. approach permits tuning of important properties such as the redn. potential and soly. by adding functional groups: for example, the addn. of 2 hydroxy groups to AQDS increases the open circuit potential of the cell by 11% and a pathway for further increases in cell voltage is described. The use of π-arom. redox-active org. mols. instead of redox-active metals represents a new and promising direction for realizing massive elec. energy storage at greatly reduced cost.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXltVeisg%253D%253D&md5=1b7dd54b61bf90746959bb51e671c7a5
    113. 113
      Lin, K.; Chen, Q.; Gerhardt, M. R.; Tong, L.; Kim, S. B.; Eisenach, L.; Valle, A. W.; Hardee, D.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J.; Marshak, M. P. Alkaline Quinone Flow Battery. Science 2015, 349 (6255), 1529– 1532,  DOI: 10.1126/science.aab3033
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      113
      Alkaline quinone flow battery
      Lin, Kaixiang; Chen, Qing; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Tong, Liuchuan; Kim, Sang Bok; Eisenach, Louise; Valle, Alvaro W.; Hardee, David; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.; Marshak, Michael P.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2015), 349 (6255), 1529-1532CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Storage of photovoltaic and wind electricity in batteries could solve the mismatch problem between the intermittent supply of these renewable resources and variable demand. Flow batteries permit more economical long-duration discharge than solid-electrode batteries by using liq. electrolytes stored outside of the battery. We report an alk. flow battery based on redox-active org. mols. that are composed entirely of Earth-abundant elements and are nontoxic, nonflammable, and safe for use in residential and com. environments. The battery operates efficiently with high power d. near room temp. These results demonstrate the stability and performance of redox-active org. mols. in alk. flow batteries, potentially enabling cost-effective stationary storage of renewable energy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFCrtbjN&md5=03e98c7de27aa2f1cfe9c71b6e9823bc
    114. 114
      Janoschka, T.; Martin, N.; Martin, U.; Friebe, C.; Morgenstern, S.; Hiller, H.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. An Aqueous, Polymer-Based Redox-Flow Battery Using Non-Corrosive, Safe, and Low-Cost Materials. Nature 2015, 527 (7576), 78– 81,  DOI: 10.1038/nature15746
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      114
      An aqueous, polymer-based redox-flow battery using non-corrosive, safe, and low-cost materials
      Janoschka, Tobias; Martin, Norbert; Martin, Udo; Friebe, Christian; Morgenstern, Sabine; Hiller, Hannes; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2015), 527 (7576), 78-81CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      For renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and hydroelec. to be effectively used in the grid of the future, flexible and scalable energy-storage solns. are necessary to mitigate output fluctuations. Redox-flow batteries (RFBs) were 1st built in the 1940s and are considered a promising large-scale energy-storage technol. A limited no. of redox-active materials-mainly metal salts, corrosive halogens, and low-molar-mass org. compds.-have been studied as active materials, and only a few membrane materials, such as Nafion, have been considered for RFBs. However, for systems that are intended for both domestic and large-scale use, safety and cost must be taken into account as well as energy d. and capacity, particularly regarding long-term access to metal resources, which places limits on the Li-ion-based and V-based RFB development. Here the authors describe an affordable, safe, and scalable battery system, which uses org. polymers as the charge-storage material in combination with inexpensive dialysis membranes, which sep. the anode and the cathode by the retention of the nonmetallic, active (macro-mol.) species, and an aq. NaCl soln. as the electrolyte. This H2O- and polymer-based RFB has an energy d. of 10 W hours per L, current densities of up to 100 mA/cm2 and stable long-term cycling capability. The polymer-based RFB the authors present uses an environmentally benign NaCl soln. and cheap, com. available filter membranes instead of highly corrosive acid electrolytes and expensive membrane materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhslynurrN&md5=44665f9a301a89114033ab1fbf7683dd
    115. 115
      Zhang, K.; Hu, Y.; Wang, L.; Fan, J.; Monteiro, M. J.; Jia, Z. The Impact of the Molecular Weight on the Electrochemical Properties of Poly(TEMPO Methacrylate). Polym. Chem. 2017, 8 (11), 1815– 1823,  DOI: 10.1039/C7PY00151G
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      115
      The impact of the molecular weight on the electrochemical properties of poly(TEMPO methacrylate)
      Zhang, Kai; Hu, Yuxiang; Wang, Lianzhou; Fan, Jiyu; Monteiro, Michael J.; Jia, Zhongfan
      Polymer Chemistry (2017), 8 (11), 1815-1823CODEN: PCOHC2; ISSN:1759-9962. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Synthesis of TEMPO-contg. polymers by 'living' radical polymn. provides opportunities to investigate the impact of the mol. wt. on their electrochem. properties. In this work, we utilized single electron transfer-living radical polymn. (SET-LRP) to synthesize poly(2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine methacrylate) (PTMPM) with ds.p. ranging from 66 to 703, and after oxidn. producing poly(TEMPO methacrylate) (PTMA) with the highest mol. wt. of 169 kDa and dispersity of 1.35. Three different techniques were used to quantify the radical d. and calc. the theor. capacity of PTMA polymers. These PTMA polymers, as active materials with 25 wt% in the electrode composite, showed strong mol. wt. dependence on the electrochem. properties. The higher mol. wt. PTMA polymers showed higher specific discharging capacities and better cycling stability due to their lower soly. in the electrolyte.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      This article references 115 other publications.

      1. 1
        Larcher, D.; Tarascon, J. M. Towards Greener and More Sustainable Batteries for Electrical Energy Storage. Nat. Chem. 2015, 7 (1), 19– 29,  DOI: 10.1038/nchem.2085
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Towards greener and more sustainable batteries for electrical energy storage
        Larcher, D.; Tarascon, J.-M.
        Nature Chemistry (2015), 7 (1), 19-29CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. Ever-growing energy needs and depleting fossil-fuel resources demand the pursuit of sustainable energy alternatives, including both renewable energy sources and sustainable storage technologies. It is therefore essential to incorporate material abundance, eco-efficient synthetic processes and life-cycle anal. into the design of new electrochem. storage systems. At present, a few existing technologies address these issues, but in each case, fundamental and technol. hurdles remain to be overcome. Here the authors provide an overview of the current state of energy storage from a sustainability perspective. The authors introduce the notion of sustainability through discussion of the energy and environmental costs of state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries, considering elemental abundance, toxicity, synthetic methods and scalability. With the same themes in mind, the authors also highlight current and future electrochem. storage systems beyond Li-ion batteries. The complexity and importance of recycling battery materials is also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvFKlsrjF&md5=977f0fc171bb41af30457715fc0ded72
      2. 2
        Chen, H.; Armand, M.; Demailly, G.; Dolhem, F.; Poizot, P.; Tarascon, J. M. From Biomass to a Renewable LixC6O6 Organic Electrode for Sustainable Li-Ion Batteries. ChemSusChem 2008, 1 (4), 348– 355,  DOI: 10.1002/cssc.200700161
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        From biomass to a renewable LixC6O6 organic electrode for sustainable Li-ion batteries
        Chen, Haiyan; Armand, Michel; Demailly, Gilles; Dolhem, Franck; Poizot, Philippe; Tarascon, Jean-Marie
        ChemSusChem (2008), 1 (4), 348-355CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Li-ion batteries presently operate on inorg. insertion compds. The abundance and materials life-cycle costs of such batteries may present issues in the long term with foreseeable large-scale applications. To address the issue of sustainability of electrode materials, a radically different approach from the conventional route was adopted to develop new org. electrode materials. The oxo-carbon salt Li2C6O6 was synthesized through potentially low-cost processes free of toxic solvents and by using natural org. sources (CO2-harvesting entities). It contains carbonyl groups as redox centers and can electrochem. react with 4 Li ions per formula unit. Such battery processing comes close to both sustainable and green chem. concepts, which are not currently present in Li-ion cell technol. The consideration of renewable resources in designing electrode materials can enable the realization of green and sustainable batteries in the next decade.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXlvFelu7g%253D&md5=874ac2c12a86254b610be73dbdc6cab3
      3. 3
        Xu, Z.; Ye, H.; Li, H.; Xu, Y.; Wang, C.; Yin, J.; Zhu, H. Enhanced Lithium Ion Storage Performance of Tannic Acid in LiTFSI Electrolyte. ACS Omega 2017, 2 (4), 1273– 1278,  DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.6b00504
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        Enhanced Lithium Ion Storage Performance of Tannic Acid in LiTFSI Electrolyte
        Xu, Zheng; Ye, Haijun; Li, Hongqin; Xu, Yazhou; Wang, Chuanyi; Yin, Jiao; Zhu, Hui
        ACS Omega (2017), 2 (4), 1273-1278CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        In this article, tannic acid (TA), as an earth-abundant natural polymer, has been creatively proposed as a desirable org. anode material for lithium ion batteries (LIBs). Most importantly, it has been obsd. that the substitution of different concns. of lithium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) for lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) can significantly restrain the dissoln. of TA. This fact implies that LiTFSI, esp. at high concns., is beneficial to accelerate electrochem. kinetics, enlarge the specific capacity, improve the rate performance, and prolong the cycling life for org. LIBs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXlsVCmsLo%253D&md5=fb4b335d708dbc1d2e923142b00c41d2
      4. 4
        Mao, M.; Luo, C.; Pollard, T. P.; Hou, S.; Gao, T.; Fan, X.; Cui, C.; Yue, J.; Tong, Y.; Yang, G.; Deng, T.; Zhang, M.; Ma, J.; Suo, L.; Borodin, O.; Wang, C. A Pyrazine-Based Polymer for Fast-Charge Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2019, 58 (49), 17820– 17826,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201910916
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        A Pyrazine-Based Polymer for Fast-Charge Batteries
        Mao, Minglei; Luo, Chao; Pollard, Travis P.; Hou, Singyuk; Gao, Tao; Fan, Xiulin; Cui, Chunyu; Yue, Jinming; Tong, Yuxin; Yang, Gaojing; Deng, Tao; Zhang, Ming; Ma, Jianmin; Suo, Liumin; Borodin, Oleg; Wang, Chunsheng
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2019), 58 (49), 17820-17826CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The lack of high-power and stable cathodes prohibits the development of rechargeable metal (Na, Mg, Al) batteries. Herein, poly(hexaazatrinaphthalene) (PHATN), an environmentally benign, abundant and sustainable polymer, is employed as a universal cathode material for these batteries. In Na-ion batteries (NIBs), PHATN delivers a reversible capacity of 220 mAh g-1 at 50 mA g-1, corresponding to the energy d. of 440 Wh kg-1, and still retains 100 mAh g-1 at 10 Ag-1 after 50 000 cycles, which is among the best performances in NIBs. Such an exceptional performance is also obsd. in more challenging Mg and Al batteries. PHATN retains reversible capacities of 110 mAh g-1 after 200 cycles in Mg batteries and 92 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles in Al batteries. DFT calcns., XPS, Raman, and FTIR show that the electron-deficient pyrazine sites in PHATN are the redox centers to reversibly react with metal ions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXitValurjF&md5=182b996cbe68c4a61e9b965b9a33e2ab
      5. 5
        Perticarari, S.; Sayed-Ahmad-Baraza, Y.; Ewels, C.; Moreau, P.; Guyomard, D.; Poizot, P.; Odobel, F.; Gaubicher, J. Dual Anion-Cation Reversible Insertion in a Bipyridinium–Diamide Triad as the Negative Electrode for Aqueous Batteries. Adv. Energy Mater. 2018, 8 (8), 1701988,  DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201701988
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
