      7. 7
        Gao, H.; Xue, L.; Xin, S.; Goodenough, J. B. A High-Energy-Density Potassium Battery with a Polymer-Gel Electrolyte and a Polyaniline Cathode. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2018, 57 (19), 5449– 5453,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201802248
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        A High-Energy-Density Potassium Battery with a Polymer-Gel Electrolyte and a Polyaniline Cathode
        Gao, Hongcai; Xue, Leigang; Xin, Sen; Goodenough, John B.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (19), 5449-5453CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A safe, rechargeable potassium battery of high energy d. and excellent cycling stability was developed. The anion component of the electrolyte salt is inserted into a polyaniline cathode upon charging and extd. from it during discharging while the K+ ion of the KPF6 salt is plated/stripped on the potassium-metal anode. The use of a p-type polymer cathode increases the cell voltage. By replacing the org.-liq. electrolyte in a glass-fiber separator with a polymer-gel electrolyte of cross-linked poly(Me methacrylate), a dendrite-free potassium anode can be plated/stripped, and the electrode/electrolyte interface is stabilized. The potassium anode wets the polymer, and the cross-linked architecture provides small pores of adjustable sizes to stabilize a solid-electrolyte interphase formed at the anode/electrolyte interface. This alternative electrolyte/cathode strategy offers a promising new approach to low-cost potassium batteries for the stationary storage of elec. power.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXntFOksbs%253D&md5=69736ce7003cd932be3a09a85042d6a0
      8. 8
        Li, W.; Chen, L.; Sun, Y.; Wang, C.; Wang, Y.; Xia, Y. All-Solid-State Secondary Lithium Battery Using Solid Polymer Electrolyte and Anthraquinone Cathode. Solid State Ionics 2017, 300, 114– 119,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ssi.2016.12.013
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8
        All-solid-state secondary lithium battery using solid polymer electrolyte and anthraquinone cathode
        Li, Wangyu; Chen, Long; Sun, Yunhe; Wang, Congxiao; Wang, Yonggang; Xia, Yongyao
        Solid State Ionics (2017), 300 (), 114-119CODEN: SSIOD3; ISSN:0167-2738. (Elsevier B.V.)
        An all-solid-state battery was fabricated by using a PEO-base solid polymer as electrolyte and an org. material anthraquinone (AQ) as cathode. The anthraquinone delivers a specific discharge capacity of 183 mAh g- 1 at first cycle at c.d. of 20 mA g- 1 at 65 °C. The use of solid polymer electrolyte reduces the dissoln. of org. active material greatly, improving the cycle performance of the battery. Therefore, the all-solid-state battery delivers a better cycling property. It can still retain a capacity of 136 mAh g- 1 after 50 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention of 74%, while capacity retention of the cell using liq. electrolyte was only 28% after 20 cycles. The all-solid-state battery shows more stable interfacial resistance during charge-discharge process. It displays good rate ability and a better thermal stability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFClur7O&md5=15d72944c75abffff777d294f72f1f3d
      9. 9
        Su, Y.; Liu, Y.; Liu, P.; Wu, D.; Zhuang, X.; Zhang, F.; Feng, X. Compact Coupled Graphene and Porous Polyaryltriazine-Derived Frameworks as High Performance Cathodes for Lithium-Ion Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2015, 54 (6), 1812– 1816,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201410154
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Compact Coupled Graphene and Porous Polyaryltriazine-Derived Frameworks as High Performance Cathodes for Lithium-Ion Batteries
        Su, Yuezeng; Liu, Yuxin; Liu, Ping; Wu, Dongqing; Zhuang, Xiaodong; Zhang, Fan; Feng, Xinliang
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (6), 1812-1816CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        It is highly desirable to develop electroactive org. materials and their derivs. as green alternatives of cathodes for sustainable and cost-effective lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in energy storage fields. Herein, compact two-dimensional coupled graphene and porous polyaryltriazine-derived frameworks with tailormade pore structures are fabricated by using various mol. building blocks under ionothermal conditions. The porous nanosheets display nanoscale thickness, high sp. surface area, and strong coupling of electroactive polyaryltriazine-derived frameworks with graphene. All these features make it possible to efficiently depress the dissoln. of redox moieties in electrolytes and to boost the elec. cond. of whole electrode. When employed as a cathode in LIBs, the two-dimensional porous nanosheets exhibit outstanding cycle stability of 395 mAh g-1 at 5 A g-1 for more than 5100 cycles and excellent rate capability of 135 mAh g-1 at a high c.d. of 15 A g-1.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXitFWjsr7K&md5=2ffb3775942cb142738587e272cc8172
      10. 10
        Zhang, C.; Lu, C.; Zhang, F.; Qiu, F.; Zhuang, X.; Feng, X. Two-Dimensional Organic Cathode Materials for Alkali-Metal-Ion Batteries. J. Energy Chem. 2018, 27 (1), 86– 98,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jechem.2017.11.008
        [Crossref], Google Scholar

      11. 11
        Zheng, C.; Zhu, J.; Yang, C.; Lu, C.; Chen, Z.; Zhuang, X. The Art of Two-Dimensional Soft Nanomaterials. Sci. China: Chem. 2019, 62 (9), 1145– 1193,  DOI: 10.1007/s11426-019-9477-y
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        The art of two-dimensional soft nanomaterials
        Zheng, Caini; Zhu, Jinhui; Yang, Chongqing; Lu, Chenbao; Chen, Zhenying; Zhuang, Xiaodong
        Science China: Chemistry (2019), 62 (9), 1145-1193CODEN: SCCCCS; ISSN:1869-1870. (Science China Press)
        The discovery of graphene has triggered the explosive development of two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials, including both inorg. and org. species. Benefiting from the simple elemental compn., inorg. 2D nanomaterials were the center research in the past decade, which has long shadowed the research of 2D org. (or soft) nanomaterials. Although many kinds of 2D soft nanomaterials have been successfully prepd., a unified definition for them is still impossible due to the complicate and quite different chem. structures between each other and even relying on totally different techniques to distinguish them. Since our first review on 2D soft nanomaterials in 2015, this field has moved forward with big success. In this review, we will focus on the development of 2D soft nanomaterials after 2015. In order to deliver better overview of this field, new and comprehensive classification is used in this review: 2D arom. mols., graphene and graphene nanoribbons, graphyne and graphdiyne, BxCyNz nanosheets, 2D polymers, 2D supramols., cryst. 2D assemblies, 2D covalent org. frameworks, 2D metal-org. frameworks, sandwich-like 2D porous polymers, 2D polymer nanosheets, etc. The focus of this review lies on synthetic strategies and the challenges of characterization, definition and fundamental understanding.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtFKqtLbJ&md5=23f1d729a692d25e31800b05ed4cfafb
      12. 12
        Muench, S.; Wild, A.; Friebe, C.; Häupler, B.; Janoschka, T.; Schubert, U. S. Polymer-Based Organic Batteries. Chem. Rev. 2016, 116 (16), 9438– 9484,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00070
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        Polymer-Based Organic Batteries
        Muench, Simon; Wild, Andreas; Friebe, Christian; Haeupler, Bernhard; Janoschka, Tobias; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2016), 116 (16), 9438-9484CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        The storage of elec. energy is of ever growing importance for our modern, technol.-based society, and novel battery systems are in the focus of research. The substitution of conventional metals as redox-active material by org. materials offers a promising alternative for the next generation of rechargeable batteries since these org. batteries are excelling in charging speed and cycling stability. This review provides a comprehensive overview of these systems and discusses the numerous classes of org., polymer-based active materials as well as auxiliary components of the battery, like additives or electrolytes. Moreover, a definition of important cell characteristics and an introduction to selected characterization techniques is provided, completed by the discussion of potential socio-economic impacts.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xht1Ggtr7J&md5=46d082a2643ad0c4b2828e08bd4fcdbe
      13. 13
        Zhang, K.; Monteiro, M. J.; Jia, Z. Stable Organic Radical Polymers: Synthesis and Applications. Polym. Chem. 2016, 7 (36), 5589– 5614,  DOI: 10.1039/C6PY00996D
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        Stable organic radical polymers: synthesis and applications
        Zhang, Kai; Monteiro, Michael J.; Jia, Zhongfan
        Polymer Chemistry (2016), 7 (36), 5589-5614CODEN: PCOHC2; ISSN:1759-9962. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        There has been a resurgence in the development of new synthetic methods to produce stable org. radical polymers (ORPs) with control over chem. compn. and structures. This has resulted from the new applications (e.g. electrochem. energy storage to synergistic therapy in drug delivery) that require sophisticated control over the polymer structural properties to compete in the market. Here, we provide a comprehensive overview of the synthetic strategies for making ORPs, discuss the synthesis-structure-property relationship and summarise the main applications of ORPs found in the literature so far. We envisage that the future development on ORPs will be to create ORP based smart materials through advanced macromol. design and synthesis for better practical performance in diverse applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhtlaltb%252FL&md5=75e9901b4e8d0dcfdf210ab521146f89
      14. 14
        Heiska, J.; Nisula, M.; Karppinen, M. Organic Electrode Materials with Solid-State Battery Technology. J. Mater. Chem. A 2019, 7 (32), 18735– 18758,  DOI: 10.1039/C9TA04328D
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        Organic electrode materials with solid-state battery technology
        Heiska, Juho; Nisula, Mikko; Karppinen, Maarit
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2019), 7 (32), 18735-18758CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The quest for next-generation sustainable (resource-wise, safe and eco-friendly), high performance (light-wt. and energy/power dense) and cost-efficient rechargeable energy storage devices has been catalyzing the research on new battery chemistries. In this research rush, org. electrode materials have ticked many of the wish-list boxes, but there are also a few obstacles to overcome, the two major ones being their intrinsically poor electronic cond. and instantaneous dissoln. into liq. electrolytes. In this crit. review, we first provide the readers with a brief account of the various org. material families considered for electrode materials, with their particular benefits and problems. Then, using some basic concepts borrowed from the field of org. electronics we aim to gain a deeper insight into the cond. of orgs. in electrochem. systems - an issue little discussed so far. To address the soly. issue we discuss - with some illustrative examples - the benefits and challenges possibly emerging by combining the org. electrodes with a solid electrolyte instead of the conventional liq. electrolyte. As one of the highlights we discuss thin-film microbatteries fabricated using the at./mol. layer deposition (ALD/MLD) technique, where ultrathin layers of the LiPON electrolyte are combined with lithium quinone and terephthalate electrodes. Such a thin-film configuration is intriguing in the sense that it does not contain any additives, thus serving as an ideal model system for fundamental studies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsVKgu7%252FL&md5=baabdeb0f43d0814887f40c756a5c6b3
      15. 15
        Mauger, A.; Julien, C.; Paolella, A.; Armand, M.; Zaghib, K. Recent Progress on Organic Electrodes Materials for Rechargeable Batteries and Supercapacitors. Materials 2019, 12 (11), 1770,  DOI: 10.3390/ma12111770
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Recent progress on organic electrodes materials for rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors
        Mauger, Alain; Julien, Christian; Paolella, Andrea; Armand, Michel; Zaghib, Karim
        Materials (2019), 12 (11), 1770CODEN: MATEG9; ISSN:1996-1944. (MDPI AG)
        Rechargeable batteries are essential elements for many applications, ranging from portable use up to elec. vehicles. Among them, lithium-ion batteries have taken an increasing importance in the day life. However, they suffer of several limitations: safety concerns and risks of thermal runaway, cost, and high carbon footprint, starting with the extn. of the transition metals in ores with low metal content. These limitations were the motivation for an intensive research to replace the inorg. electrodes by org. electrodes. Subsequently, the disadvantages that are mentioned above are overcome, but are replaced by new ones, including the soly. of the org. mols. in the electrolytes and lower operational voltage. However, recent progress has been made. The lower voltage, even though it is partly compensated by a larger capacity d., may preclude the use of org. electrodes for elec. vehicles, but the very long cycling lives and the fast kinetics reached recently suggest their use in grid storage and regulation, and possibly in hybrid elec. vehicles (HEVs). The purpose of this work is to review the different results and strategies that are currently being used to obtain org. electrodes that make them competitive with lithium-ion batteries for such applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXitlyiurY%253D&md5=49b6c07229e76d2aa02653b43c8f96ac
      16. 16
        Liang, Y.; Tao, Z.; Chen, J. Organic Electrode Materials for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries. Adv. Energy Mater. 2012, 2 (7), 742– 769,  DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201100795
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16
        Organic electrode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries
        Liang, Yanliang; Tao, Zhanliang; Chen, Jun
        Advanced Energy Materials (2012), 2 (7), 742-769CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        A review. Org. compds. offer new possibilities for high energy/power d., cost-effective, environmentally friendly, and functional rechargeable lithium batteries. For a long time, they have not constituted an important class of electrode materials, partly because of the large success and rapid development of inorg. intercalation compds. In recent years, however, exciting progress has been made, bringing org. electrodes to the attention of the energy storage community. Herein thirty years' research efforts in the field of org. compds. for rechargeable lithium batteries are summarized. The working principles, development history, and design strategies of these materials, including organosulfur compds., org. free radical compds., org. carbonyl compds., conducting polymers, non-conjugated redox polymers, and layered org. compds. are presented. The cell performances of these materials are compared, providing a comprehensive overview of the area, and straightforwardly revealing the advantages/disadvantages of each class of materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVOrtLnP&md5=1a37e1faec914ba6e286b1ea1b281a77
      17. 17
        Visco, S. J.; Maiihe, C. C.; De Jonghe, L. C.; Armand, M. B. A Novel Class of Organosulfur Electrodes for Energy Storage. J. Electrochem. Soc. 1989, 136 (3), 661– 664,  DOI: 10.1149/1.2096706
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        A novel class of organosulfur electrodes for energy storage
        Visco, Steven J.; Mailhe, Catherine C.; De Jonghe, Lutgard C.; Armand, Michel B.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (1989), 136 (3), 661-4CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651.
        Cathodes based on organosulfur compds. can operate between ambient temp. and 150°, are inexpensive and inert to many metals, and the material physicochem. and electrochem. properties can be varied in a predictable way. Batteries based on organosulfur compd. cathodes and Na anodes have a theor. energy d. of 350-600 W-h/kg. A Na/tetraethylthiuram disulfide battery had a theor. energy d. of 360 W-h/kg, and open-circuit voltage of 2.3 V. Exptl. batteries cycled between 10 and 90% of available capacity, had a power d. of 6 W-h/kg, an energy d. of 80 W-h/kg, and an overall energy efficiency of 75%; some batteries delivered peak power d. of 40-60 W/kg for ≥1 min. Test batteries with simple alkyl disulfide cathodes completed full charge/discharge cycles at c.d. of 10 mA/cm2 and 105°.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXhsFOlt7c%253D&md5=5ed8029412b8a478dc4e3f36dd1f670d

        Xue, L. J.; Li, J. X.; Hu, S. Q.; Zhang, M. X.; Zhou, Y. H.; Zhan, C. M. Anthracene Based Organodisulfide Positive Active Materials for Lithium Secondary Battery. Electrochem. Commun. 2003, 5 (10), 903– 906,  DOI: 10.1016/j.elecom.2003.08.018
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18
        Anthracene based organotrisulfide positive active materials for lithium secondary battery
        Xue, L. J.; Li, J. X.; Hu, S. Q.; Zhang, M. X.; Zhou, Y. H.; Zhan, C. M.
        Electrochemistry Communications (2003), 5 (10), 903-906CODEN: ECCMF9; ISSN:1388-2481. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        From a facile prepn. method and available low-cost raw materials, the authors synthesized a novel kind of organo-trisulfide cathode material for lithium secondary batteries based on anthracene - anthra[1',9',8'-b,c,d,e][4',10',5'-b',c',d',e']bis-[1,6,6a(6a-SIV) trithia]pentalene (ABTH) and its homopolymer (PABTH), and studied the application of the organo-trisulfides to pos. active material for lithium secondary batteries. Two routes to ABTH were used, and polymers from both products were prepd. and tested. The organo-trisulfides were characterized by FTIR, XPS, and elemental anal. The cyclic voltammetry tests reveal that the redox reaction of the ABTHs was processed in two steps. The polymer has the specific capacity of 300 mAh/g at 2nd cycle and 250 mAh/g at the 5th cycle.

        Liu, Z. J.; Kong, L. B.; Zhou, Y. H.; Zhan, C. M.         19
        Polyanthra[1,9,8-b,c,d,e][4,10,5-b,c,d,e]bis-[1,6,6a(6a-S) trithia]pentalene-active material for cathode of lithium secondary battery with unusually high specific capacity
        Liu, Z. J.; Kong, L. B.; Zhou, Y. H.; Zhan, C. M.
        Journal of Power Sources (2006), 161 (2), 1302-1306CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Polyanthra[1,9,8-b,c,d,e][4,10,5-b,c,d,e]bis-[1,6,6a(6a-S)trithia]pentalene (PABTP) was prepd. and investigated as cathode active material for lithium secondary batteries. The org. disulfide polymer was prepd. by the direct sulfurization of anthracene and the oxidative coupling polymn. of the sulfide anthracene, characterized by FT-IR, Raman, elemental anal., XPS and XRD. The polymer was used as cathode active material and the lithium secondary batteries were assembled and tested. The polymer had high specific capacity up to 1500 mAh g-1, which remained the value of 800 mAh g-1 at the 77th cycle, and kept high charge-discharge efficiency of 85% in the whole test.

        Su, Y. Z.; Dong, W.; Zhang, J. H.; Song, J. H.; Zhang, Y. H.; Gong, K. C. Poly[Bis(2-Aminophenyloxy)Disulfide]: A Polyaniline Derivative Containing Disulfide Bonds as a Cathode Material for Lithium Battery. Polymer 2007, 48 (1), 165– 173,  DOI: 10.1016/j.polymer.2006.10.044
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        Poly[bis(2-aminophenyloxy)disulfide]: a polyaniline derivative containing disulfide bonds as a cathode material for lithium battery
        Su, Yu-Zhi; Dong, Wen; Zhang, Jian-Hua; Song, Jian-Hua; Zhang, Yong-Hua; Gong, Ke-Cheng
        Polymer (2007), 48 (1), 165-173CODEN: POLMAG; ISSN:0032-3861. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A new conductive polyaniline deriv. contg. disulfide bonds, poly[bis(2-aminophenyloxy)disulfide] (PAPOD), has been proposed as a high energy-storage material. PAPOD was synthesized using a moderate oxidant ferric chloride and characterized by elemental anal., XPS, FT-IR, FT-Raman, and UV-vis spectroscopy. The cyclic voltammograms of this polymer showed that the intramol. self-catalysis occurred between the conductive main-chain polyaniline (doping/undoping processes of the π-conjugated system) and side-chain disulfide bonds (scission/reformation processes of the S-S bonds) in PAPOD. Because the redox reaction of conductive main-chain polyaniline occurs in the same potential range as that of the side-chain disulfide bonds of this polymer, the Li/PAPOD test cell displayed a charge capacity of 230 mAh/g-cathode and an energy d. of 460 mWh/g cathode, which is about 2-3 times higher than those of inorg. intercalation compds.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtlGqtrfE&md5=7a7b8cade5698456aca3984e0a1fb176
      21. 21
        Hu, P.; He, X.; Ng, M.-F.; Ye, J.; Zhao, C.; Wang, S.; Tan, K.; Chaturvedi, A.; Jiang, H.; Kloc, C.; Hu, W.; Long, Y. Trisulfide-Bond Acenes for Organic Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2019, 58 (38), 13513– 13521,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201906301
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Trisulfide-Bond Acenes for Organic Batteries
        Hu, Peng; He, Xuexia; Ng, Man-Fai; Ye, Jun; Zhao, Chenyang; Wang, Shancheng; Tan, Kejie; Chaturvedi, Apoorva; Jiang, Hui; Kloc, Christian; Hu, Wenping; Long, Yi
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2019), 58 (38), 13513-13521CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The mol. design of org. battery electrodes is a big challenge. Here, we synthesize two metal-free organosulfur acenes and shed insight into battery properties using first-principles calcns. A new zone-melting chem.-vapor-transport (ZM-CVT) app. was fabricated to provide a simple, solvent-free, and continuous synthetic protocol, and produce single crystals of tetrathiotetracene (TTT) and hexathiapentacene (HTP) at a large scale. Single crystals of HTP showed better Li-ion battery performance and higher cycling stability than those of TTT. A two-step, three-electron lithiation mechanism instead of the commonly depicted two-electron mechanism is proposed for the HTP Li-ion battery. The superior performance of HTP is linked to unique trisulfide bonding scenarios, which are also responsible for the formation of empty channels along the stacking direction. In-depth theor. anal. suggests that organosulfur acenes are potential prototypes for org. battery materials with tunable properties, and that the tuning of sulfur bonds is crit. in designing these new materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsFChsLjO&md5=3b097d39809ae0150dcd7957ddc1657e
      22. 22
        Kim, J. K.; Kim, Y.; Park, S.; Ko, H.; Kim, Y. Encapsulation of Organic Active Materials in Carbon Nanotubes for Application to High-Electrochemical-Performance Sodium Batteries. Energy Environ. Sci. 2016, 9 (4), 1264– 1269,  DOI: 10.1039/C5EE02806J
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22
        Encapsulation of organic active materials in carbon nanotubes for application to high-electrochemical-performance sodium batteries
        Kim, Jae-Kwang; Kim, Yongil; Park, Seungyoung; Ko, Hyunhyub; Kim, Youngsik
        Energy & Environmental Science (2016), 9 (4), 1264-1269CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Sodium (Na) ion batteries are interesting candidates for replacing lithium (Li) ion batteries, primarily due to the abundance of Na in the environment. However, the performance and energy d. of a Na-ion battery are inferior to those of a Li-ion battery. Org. active materials can help overcome the drawbacks assocd. with Na-ion batteries because of their many advantages. However, such org. polymer electrodes are subjected to a high self-discharge and low practical capacity because the polymer electrode easily dissolves in an org. electrolyte and forms an insulating layer. Therefore, in this study, we have designed a unique org. electrode in which an active polymer is encapsulated into a carbon nanotube (CNT) to form an electrode with high polymer content. The CNT is able to retain the active polymer within the electrode structure, providing an effective electronic conduction path. Moreover, the CNT can contain large amts. of active polymer and therefore exhibits superior electrochem. properties without self-discharge, making it well suited for use as a cathode material in a Na-ion battery.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVegtb%252FJ&md5=701277d112d673063eb320cc7d5cb55f
      23. 23
        Hansen, K. A.; Nerkar, J.; Thomas, K.; Bottle, S. E.; O’Mullane, A. P.; Talbot, P. C.; Blinco, J. P. New Spin on Organic Radical Batteries-An Isoindoline Nitroxide-Based High-Voltage Cathode Material. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2018, 10 (9), 7982– 7988,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.7b18252
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        New Spin on Organic Radical Batteries-An Isoindoline Nitroxide-Based High-Voltage Cathode Material
        Hansen, Kai-Anders; Nerkar, Jawahar; Thomas, Komba; Bottle, Steven E.; O'Mullane, Anthony P.; Talbot, Peter C.; Blinco, James P.
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2018), 10 (9), 7982-7988CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        Org. electrode materials are a highly promising and environmentally benign class of battery materials with radical polymers being at the forefront of this research. Herein, we report the first example of the 1,1,3,3-tetramethylisoindolin-2-yloxyl class of nitroxides as an org. electrode material and the synthesis and application of a novel styrenic nitroxide polymer, poly(5-vinyl-1,1,3,3-tetramethylisoindolin-2-yloxyl) (PVTMIO). The polymer was synthesized from the precursor monomer, 2-methoxy-5-vinyl-1,1,3,3-tetramethylisoindoline, and subsequent oxidative deprotection yielded the electroactive radical species. Cyclic voltammetry revealed a high oxidn. potential of 3.7 V vs. Li, placing it among the top of the nitroxide class of electrode materials. The suitability of PVTMIO for utilization in a high-voltage org. radical battery was confirmed with a discharge capacity of 104.7 mAh g-1, high rate performance, and stability under cycling conditions (90% capacity retention after 100 cycles), making it one of the highest reported org. p-dopable cathode materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXit1ykt7c%253D&md5=7308f5d144d602ae5b34926ed123cd8c
      24. 24
        Choi, W.; Ohtani, S.; Oyaizu, K.; Nishide, H.; Geckeler, K. E. Radical Polymer-Wrapped SWNTs at a Molecular Level: High-Rate Redox Mediation through a Percolation Network for a Transparent Charge-Storage Material. Adv. Mater. 2011, 23 (38), 4440– 4443,  DOI: 10.1002/adma.201102372
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24
        Radical Polymer-Wrapped SWNTs at a Molecular Level: High-Rate Redox Mediation Through a Percolation Network for a Transparent Charge-Storage Material
        Choi, Wonsung; Ohtani, Shota; Oyaizu, Kenichi; Nishide, Hiroyuki; Geckeler, Kurt E.
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2011), 23 (38), 4440-4443CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Composites of the radical polymer PTMA and SWNTs were prepd. via polymer-wrapping process using a combination of ultrasonication and ultracentrifugation without any surfactants. The TEM image anal. supports the efficient wrapping on a mol. level with a single-chain conformation of the PTMA polymer. The network of individualized SWNTs enhanced the charge propagation in the PTMA, thus providing a quant. charge-storage capacity at a high rate. As far as we know, the amt. of conductive material is the smallest to form conductive pathway allowing the quant. formula-based redox capacity. This fact suggests that this method is not only advantageous to a cathode-active material of so called "radical battery" but also in other potential applications such as rechargeable devices, counter electrodes for electrochromic devices, and wet-type devices.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Redox polymer layers with 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxyl-4-yl (TEMPO) groups showed Nernstian adsorbate-like electrochem. behaviors up to submicrometer thicknesses, based on a fast charge propagation within the bulk layer and persistency in electrolyte solns.

      26. 26
        Li, Y.; Jian, Z.; Lang, M.; Zhang, C.; Huang, X. Covalently Functionalized Graphene by Radical Polymers for Graphene-Based High-Performance Cathode Materials. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2016, 8 (27), 17352– 17359,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b05271
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26
        Covalently Functionalized Graphene by Radical Polymers for Graphene-Based High-Performance Cathode Materials
        Li, Yongjun; Jian, Zukai; Lang, Meidong; Zhang, Chunming; Huang, Xiaoyu
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2016), 8 (27), 17352-17359CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        Polymer-functionalized graphene sheets play an important role in graphene-contg. composite materials. Herein, functionalized graphene sheets covalently linked with radical polymer, graphene-graft-poly(2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxyl-4-yl methacrylate) (G-g-PTMA), were prepd. via surface-initiated atom transfer radical polymn. (SI-ATRP). A composite cathode with G-g-PTMA as major active material and reduced graphene oxide (RGO) as conductive additive was fabricated via a simple dispersing-depositing process, and this composite cathode exhibited a relatively high specific capacity up to 466 mAh g-1 based on the mass of PTMA, which is much higher than the theor. capacity of PTMA. This extraordinary electrochem. performance is attributed to the fast one-electron redox reaction of G-g-PTMA and surface Faradaic reaction of RGO boosted by G-g-PTMA, which suggested that G-g-PTMA sheets play a dual role in the composite materials, i.e., on the one hand provided the fast one-electron redox reaction of PTMA and on the other hand worked as nanofiller for facilitating the surface Faradaic reaction-based lithium storage of RGO.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVCjtrzI&md5=a2ae7d66cb674bc9a7d0aaecf49f0fa9
      27. 27
        Wen, L.; Li, F.; Cheng, H. M. Carbon Nanotubes and Graphene for Flexible Electrochemical Energy Storage: From Materials to Devices. Adv. Mater. 2016, 28 (22), 4306– 4337,  DOI: 10.1002/adma.201504225
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27
        Carbon Nanotubes and Graphene for Flexible Electrochemical Energy Storage: from Materials to Devices
        Wen, Lei; Li, Feng; Cheng, Hui-Ming
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2016), 28 (22), 4306-4337CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Flexible electrochem. energy storage (FEES) devices have received great attention as a promising power source for the emerging field of flexible and wearable electronic devices. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene have many excellent properties that make them ideally suited for use in FEES devices. A brief definition of FEES devices is provided, followed by a detailed overview of various structural models for achieving different FEES devices. The latest research developments on the use of CNTs and graphene in FEES devices are summarized. Finally, future prospects and important research directions in the areas of CNT- and graphene-based flexible electrode synthesis and device integration are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xlt1Wmtg%253D%253D&md5=5819739be2f386ec495d4aedc7b682fc
      28. 28
        Zhang, K.; Hu, Y.; Wang, L.; Monteiro, M. J.; Jia, Z. Pyrene-Functionalized PTMA by NRC for Greater π–π Stacking with RGO and Enhanced Electrochemical Properties. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2017, 9 (40), 34900– 34908,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.7b09604
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        28
        Pyrene-Functionalized PTMA by NRC for Greater π-π Stacking with rGO and Enhanced Electrochemical Properties
        Zhang, Kai; Hu, Yuxiang; Wang, Lianzhou; Monteiro, Michael J.; Jia, Zhongfan
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2017), 9 (40), 34900-34908CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        Nitroxide radical polymers can undergo both excellent electrochem. redox reactions and a rapid "click" coupling reaction with carbon-centered radicals (i.e., nitroxide radical coupling (NRC) reaction). In this work, we report a strategy to functionalize poly(2,2,6,6,-tetramethylpiperidinyl-1-oxyl methacrylate) (PTMA) with pyrene side groups through a rapid and near quant. NRC reaction. This resulted in P(TMA-co-PyMA) random copolymers with near quant. amts. of pyrene along the PTMA chain for greater π-π interaction with rGO, while the nitroxide radicals on the polymer could simultaneously be used for energy storage. These copolymers can bind with reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and form layered composites through noncovalent π-π stacking, attaining mol.-level dispersion. Electrochem. performance of the composites with different polymer contents (24, 35, and 45 wt %), tested in lithium ion batteries, indicated that the layered structures consisting of P(TMA-co-PyMA) maintained greater capacities at high C-rates. This simple and efficient strategy to synthesize pyrene-functionalized polymers will provide new opportunities to fabricate many other polymer composite electrodes for desired electrochem. performance.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhsFKht7fN&md5=1cb754d7b1306df656a0f1192a02a96d
      29. 29
        Lee, M.; Hong, J.; Lee, B.; Ku, K.; Lee, S.; Park, C. B.; Kang, K. Multi-Electron Redox Phenazine for Ready-to-Charge Organic Batteries. Green Chem. 2017, 19 (13), 2980– 2985,  DOI: 10.1039/C7GC00849J
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29
        Multi-electron redox phenazine for ready-to-charge organic batteries
        Lee, Minah; Hong, Jihyun; Lee, Byungju; Ku, Kyojin; Lee, Sechan; Park, Chan Beum; Kang, Kisuk
        Green Chemistry (2017), 19 (13), 2980-2985CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Org. redox compds. represent an emerging class of cathode materials in rechargeable batteries for low-cost and sustainable energy storage. However, the low operating voltage (<3 V) and necessity of using Li-contg. anodes have significantly limited their practical applicability to battery systems. We introduce a new class of p-type org. redox centers based on N,N'-substituted phenazine (NSPZ) to build ready-to-charge org. batteries. In the absence of Li-contg. anodes, NSPZ cathodes facilitate reversible 2-electron transfer at 3.7 and 3.1 V accompanying anion assocn., which results in a specific energy of 622 Wh/Kg in dual-ion batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXntlWgu7Y%253D&md5=6bbc9fafbf6449d8c7a52958ee1422a9
      30. 30
        Deunf, É.; Moreau, P.; Quarez, É.; Guyomard, D.; Dolhem, F.; Poizot, P. Reversible Anion Intercalation in a Layered Aromatic Amine: A High-Voltage Host Structure for Organic Batteries. J. Mater. Chem. A 2016, 4 (16), 6131– 6139,  DOI: 10.1039/C6TA02356H
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        Reversible anion intercalation in a layered aromatic amine: a high-voltage host structure for organic batteries
        Deunf, Elise; Moreau, Philippe; Quarez, Eric; Guyomard, Dominique; Dolhem, Franck; Poizot, Philippe
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2016), 4 (16), 6131-6139CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Cation insertion reactions in inorg. host frameworks are well-established phenomena. Over the last 40 years, a myriad of examples have been documented, which have given rise to key applications such as for electrochem. storage devices. By contrast, materials able to reversibly insert anions into their host lattice are rare, and consist essentially of graphite intercalation compds. (GICs), thus limiting their potential use. Org. materials, conversely, if properly designed, could pave the way for future developments in anionic insertion electrochem., by virtue of the rational incorporation of p-type redox-active org. moieties. Here, we report the discovery of a p-type org. host lattice based on a simple crystd. arom. diamine. The reversible anion insertion process relies on the electrochem. activity of neutral secondary amino groups incorporated into a robust terephthalate backbone. XRD, TEM and EELS studies reveal the attainment of a unique lamellar structure conducive to the oxidative insertion of anions (including the bulky TFSI-). In a dual-ion cell configuration using lithium as the neg. electrode, this org. structure can react reversibly at high operating potential (〈E〉 ≈ 3.22 V vs. Li+/Li) with good cycling performance even without carbon addn., hence generating further avenues for the development of org. batteries and more generally, the field of intercalation chem.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XkvVeqsbs%253D&md5=62d377b0592279d04a89dd7c4f3a0c3a
      31. 31
        Rodríguez-Pérez, I. A.; Ji, X. Anion Hosting Cathodes in Dual-Ion Batteries. ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2 (8), 1762– 1770,  DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.7b00321
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        31
        Anion Hosting Cathodes in Dual-Ion Batteries
        Rodriguez-Perez, Ismael A.; Ji, Xiulei
        ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (8), 1762-1770CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Dual-ion batteries operate on two intercalants: anions for the cathode and cations for the anode. This battery was initially known as a dual-graphite battery, where both electrodes are graphitic carbon. The primary challenge of dual-graphite batteries is the very high operation potential of the cathode, often requiring an upper cutoff potential above 5 V vs Li+/Li. Such a potential readily oxidizes alkyl and alkylene carbonate-based electrolytes. The anode side, in fact, can employ any anode of most metal-ion batteries, although, to date, the focus has still been the Li-graphite anode. Recent progress has significantly advanced the technol. readiness level for this battery. Additives or ionic liq. electrolytes help mitigate cathode irreversibility; nongraphite anodes, such as aluminum, allow new carbonate electrolytes that lack the necessity of ethylene carbonate; nongraphite cathodes, including metal-org. frameworks and polycyclic arom. hydrocarbons have exhibited a remarkable potential. This Perspective highlights the challenges, summarizes the recent progress, and attempts to point out future directions in the field.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtFemsbvF&md5=74bf8a9d824386f439016df4ca704cf4

        Wild, A.; Strumpf, M.; Häupler, B.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. All-Organic Battery Composed of Thianthrene- and TCAQ-Based Polymers. Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 7 (5), 1601415,  DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201601415

      33. 33
        Kolek, M.; Otteny, F.; Becking, J.; Winter, M.; Esser, B.; Bieker, P. Mechanism of Charge/Discharge of Poly(Vinylphenothiazine)-Based Li-Organic Batteries. Chem. Mater. 2018, 30 (18), 6307– 6317,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.8b02015
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        Mechanism of Charge/Discharge of Poly(vinylphenothiazine)-Based Li-Organic Batteries
        Kolek, Martin; Otteny, Fabian; Becking, Jens; Winter, Martin; Esser, Birgit; Bieker, Peter
        Chemistry of Materials (2018), 30 (18), 6307-6317CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Org. electrode materials are among the promising next generation compds. for battery energy storage as a greener and cheaper alternative to transition-metal-based electrodes. A prominent class among them are redox polymers, which can reversibly store energy and can be capable of fast redox processes. Nevertheless, drawbacks are their often low specific energy and lifetime. A main challenge is their soly. in battery electrolytes, which is detrimental to cell performance. Herein, the soly. properties of a polyvinyl-based redox polymer with a methylphenothiazine side group (PVMPT) in org.-solvent-based battery electrolytes and generate new insights into the mechanism of the redeposition process of dissolved active material are discussed. The authors addressed the mechanistic studies of this polymer-electrolyte cross-talk with microscopic and spectroscopic methods. These findings are important for the mol. design of new org. electrode materials, since the redeposited polymer showed improved cycling performance and outstanding cycling stabilities. The authors herein aim to draw a bigger picture of the soly. of redox polymers and its consequences and motivate the scientific community to reconsider the common conception of the deteriorating nature of the soly. of org. battery electrode materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhs1WitbnK&md5=ef7056004684acf5cabbd2a7639d63a8

        Thianthrene-functionalized polynorbornenes as high-voltage materials for organic cathode-based dual-ion batteries

        Thianthrene-functionalized polynorbornenes were investigated as high-voltage org. cathode materials for dual-ion cells. The polymers show reversible oxidn. reactions in soln. and as a solid in composite electrodes. Const. current investigations displayed a capacity of up to 66 mA h g-1 at a high potential of 4.1 V vs. Li/Li+.

        Deunf, É.; Jiménez, P.; Guyomard, D.; Dolhem, F.; Poizot, P. A Dual-Ion Battery Using Diamino-Rubicene as Anion-Inserting Positive Electrode Material. Electrochem. Commun. 2016, 72, 64– 68,  DOI: 10.1016/j.elecom.2016.09.002

        35
        A dual-ion battery using diamino-rubicene as anion-inserting positive electrode material
        Deunf, Elise; Jimenez, Pablo; Guyomard, Dominique; Dolhem, Franck; Poizot, Philippe
        Electrochemistry Communications (2016), 72 (), 64-68CODEN: ECCMF9; ISSN:1388-2481. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A novel and non-polymeric anion-inserting electrode material has been designed and prepd. for promoting research on mol. ion rechargeable batteries: 5,12-diaminorubicene (DARb). The apolar core structure of a rubicene mol. has been coupled to two amino-groups for producing an original conjugated primary diamine exhibiting low affinity for polar solvents such as common carbonate-based battery electrolytes. The electrochem. reactivity of this org. mol. has been probed in a dual-ion cell configuration (vs. Li) using six different electrolyte formulations in terms of solvent (PC, EC-DMC) and lithium salt (LiPF6, LiClO4, LiTFSI). This diamino-rubicene material systematically showed a reversible electroactivity and promising performances when using 1 M LiPF6 in EC:DMC (1:1 vol.%) as the electrolyte, such as an av. potential of ∼ 3.4 V vs. Li+/Li0, an initial capacity of 115 mAh·g- 1 and a good capacity retention over 60 cycles without any optimization.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Vaid, T. P.; Easton, M. E.; Rogers, R. D. Polythianthrene Ladder Oligomers Function as an Organic Battery Electrode with a High Oxidation Potential. Synth. Met. 2017, 231 (July), 44– 50,  DOI: 10.1016/j.synthmet.2017.06.011
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Polythianthrene ladder oligomers function as an organic battery electrode with a high oxidation potential
        Vaid, Thomas P.; Easton, Max E.; Rogers, Robin D.
        Synthetic Metals (2017), 231 (), 44-50CODEN: SYMEDZ; ISSN:0379-6779. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The electrochem. characterization is reported of a polythianthrene ladder polymer as a promising pos. electrode active material for org. polymer batteries. Polythianthrene was synthesized as a distribution of relatively short oligomers (n = 3 to ∼20) by the condensation of diphenylsulfide catalyzed by AlCl3, and its likely solid-state structure was detd. by mol. modeling in combination with X-ray powder diffraction. Polythianthrene functions as the active material in an anion-insertion pos. battery electrode with a highly pos. potential of +0.87 V vs. ferrocene+/0, or approx. 4.1 V vs. Li/Li+. It has a specific capacity of 71 mAh/g, which may be improved toward a theor. capacity of 194 mAh/g for one-electron redox per repeat unit. The polythianthrene ladder polymer thus has both a high capacity and high voltage relative to other org. materials, and is a promising material for use as a pos. electrode in a dual-ion battery.

        Zhan, L.; Song, Z.; Shan, N.; Zhang, J.; Tang, J.; Zhan, H.; Zhou, Y.; Li, Z.; Zhan, C. Poly(Tetrahydrobenzodithiophene): High Discharge Specific Capacity as Cathode Material for Lithium Batteries. J. Power Sources 2009, 193 (2), 859– 863,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2009.05.015
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Poly(tetrahydrobenzodithiophene): High discharge specific capacity as cathode material for lithium batteries
        Zhan, Lizhi; Song, Zhiping; Shan, Ning; Zhang, Jingyu; Tang, Jing; Zhan, Hui; Zhou, Yunhong; Li, Zaoying; Zhan, Caimao
        Journal of Power Sources (2009), 193 (2), 859-863CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A novel thioether contg. conjugative polymer, poly(tetrahydrobenzodithiophene) (PTBDT), with high discharge specific capacity as the cathode material for lithium batteries, has been synthesized chem. The polymer has been characterized by elemental anal., XPS, Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and thermogravimetric anal. (TGA). The cyclic voltammogram of the polymer shows multiple redox peaks. The charge-discharge tests show stable discharge specific capacity about 560 mAh g-1 and the maximal capacity of 820 mAh g-1, and discharge voltage about 2.3 V. The results indicate that the thioether bonds of the polymer are involved in the electrode reaction. It is tentatively proposed that the thioether cations are formed during the redox reaction on the cathode. The reversible redox reaction on thioether bonds that is a multi-electron process offers a high specific capacity, and low discharge voltages.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXotVKhs78%253D&md5=7d899038b7761bebc8519dfc98b29b62

        Kolek, M.; Otteny, F.; Schmidt, P.; Mück-Lichtenfeld, C.; Einholz, C.; Becking, J.; Schleicher, E.; Winter, M.; Bieker, P.; Esser, B. Ultra-High Cycling Stability of Poly(Vinylphenothiazine) as a Battery Cathode Material Resulting from π-π Interactions. Energy Environ. Sci. 2017, 10 (11), 2334– 2341,  DOI: 10.1039/C7EE01473B
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        Ultra-high cycling stability of poly(vinylphenothiazine) as a battery cathode material resulting from π-π interactions
        Kolek, M.; Otteny, F.; Schmidt, P.; Mueck-Lichtenfeld, C.; Einholz, C.; Becking, J.; Schleicher, E.; Winter, M.; Bieker, P.; Esser, B.
        Energy & Environmental Science (2017), 10 (11), 2334-2341CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Org. cathode materials are promising candidates for a new generation of "green batteries", since they have low toxicity and can be produced from renewable resources or from oil. Esp. suitable are org. redox polymers that can be reversibly oxidized and reduced. Because of their often-insulating nature, however, many redox polymers have limited rate capabilities. Their cycling stabilities, which are of high importance for the long cycle-life of a battery cell, rarely exceed 1000 cycles. Here, we present a new concept for redox polymers as cathode materials, in which the oxidized states are stabilized through π-π interactions between redox-active groups. We found that due to these interactions poly(3-vinyl-N-methylphenothiazine) showed excellent cycling stability (after 10,000 cycles at a 10C rate, 93% of the initial capacity was retained) in addn. to a high rate capability because of supramol. hole transport. We propose this concept to be used in the future design of redox polymers for batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXht1Omtb7E&md5=4f9cc3f266faa02c4c819f32d72f4979

        Luo, C.; Borodin, O.; Ji, X.; Hou, S.; Gaskell, K. J.; Fan, X.; Chen, J.; Deng, T.; Wang, R.; Jiang, J.; Wang, C. Azo Compounds as a Family of Organic Electrode Materials for Alkali-Ion Batteries. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2018, 115 (9), 2004– 2009,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1717892115
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        39
        Azo compounds as a family of organic electrode materials for alkali-ion batteries
        Luo, Chao; Borodin, Oleg; Ji, Xiao; Hou, Singyuk; Gaskell, Karen J.; Fan, Xiulin; Chen, Ji; Deng, Tao; Wang, Ruixing; Jiang, Jianjun; Wang, Chunsheng
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2018), 115 (9), 2004-2009CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        Org. compds. are desirable for sustainable Li-ion batteries (LIBs), but the poor cycle stability and low power d. limit their large-scale application. Here we report a family of org. compds. contg. azo group (N=N) for reversible lithiation/delithiation. Azobenzene-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid lithium salt (ADALS) with an azo group in the center of the conjugated structure is used as a model azo compd. to investigate the electrochem. behaviors and reaction mechanism of azo compds. In LIBs, ADALS can provide a capacity of 190 mAh g-1 at 0.5 C (corresponding to c.d. of 95 mA g-1) and still retain 90%, 71%, and 56% of the capacity when the c.d. is increased to 2 C, 10 C, and 20 C, resp. Moreover, ADALS retains 89% of initial capacity after 5,000 cycles at 20 C with a slow capacity decay rate of 0.0023% per cycle, representing one of the best performances in all org. compds. Superior electrochem. behavior of ADALS is also obsd. in Na-ion batteries, demonstrating that azo compds. are universal electrode materials for alkali-ion batteries. The highly reversible redox chem. of azo compds. to alkali ions was confirmed by d.-functional theory (DFT) calcns. It provides opportunities for developing sustainable batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Wu, Y. L.; Horwitz, N. E.; Chen, K. S.; Gomez-Gualdron, D. A.; Luu, N. S.; Ma, L.; Wang, T. C.; Hersam, M. C.; Hupp, J. T.; Farha, O. K.; Snurr, R. Q.; Wasielewski, M. R. G-Quadruplex Organic Frameworks. Nat. Chem. 2017, 9 (5), 466– 472,  DOI: 10.1038/nchem.2689

        G-quadruplex organic frameworks
        Wu, Yi-Lin; Horwitz, Noah E.; Chen, Kan-Sheng; Gomez-Gualdron, Diego A.; Luu, Norman S.; Ma, Lin; Wang, Timothy C.; Hersam, Mark C.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.; Snurr, Randall Q.; Wasielewski, Michael R.
        Nature Chemistry (2017), 9 (5), 466-472CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Two-dimensional covalent org. frameworks often π stack into cryst. solids that allow precise spatial positioning of mol. building blocks. Inspired by the hydrogen-bonded G-quadruplexes found frequently in guanine-rich DNA, here we show that this structural motif can be exploited to guide the self-assembly of naphthalene diimide and perylene diimide electron acceptors end-capped with two guanine electron donors into cryst. G-quadruplex-based org. frameworks, wherein the electron donors and acceptors form ordered, segregated π-stacked arrays. Time-resolved optical and ESR spectroscopies show that photogenerated holes and electrons in the frameworks have long lifetimes and display recombination kinetics typical of dissocd. charge carriers. Moreover, the reduced acceptors form polarons in which the electron is shared over several mols. The G-quadruplex frameworks also demonstrate potential as cathode materials in Li-ion batteries because of the favorable electron- and Li-ion-transporting capacity provided by the ordered rylene diimide arrays and G-quadruplex structures, resp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFamt73L&md5=bfc92607943eb6ae34453298f1bae46d

Most impressively, this work provides a promising and effective strategy for developing org. energy storage devices from natural sources.

        Armand, M.; Grugeon, S.; Vezin, H.; Laruelle, S.; Ribière, P.; Poizot, P.; Tarascon, J. M. Conjugated Dicarboxylate Anodes for Li-Ion Batteries. Nat. Mater. 2009, 8 (2), 120– 125,  DOI: 10.1038/nmat2372

        44
        Conjugated dicarboxylate anodes for Li-ion batteries
        Armand, M.; Grugeon, S.; Vezin, H.; Laruelle, S.; Ribiere, P.; Poizot, P.; Tarascon, J.-M.
        Nature Materials (2009), 8 (2), 120-125CODEN: NMAACR; ISSN:1476-1122. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Present Li-ion batteries for portable electronics are based on inorg. electrodes. For new large-scale applications materials made through eco-efficient processes, such as renewable org. electrodes, is crucial. Two org. salts, Li2C8H4O4 (Li terephthalate) and Li2C6H4O4 (Li trans-trans-muconate), with carboxylate groups conjugated within the mol. core, which are resp. capable of reacting with 2 and one extra Li per formula unit at potentials of 0.8 and 1.4 V, give reversible capacities of 300 and 150 mA-h/g. The activity is maintained at 80° with polyethylene oxide-based electrolytes. A noteworthy advantage of the Li2C8H4O4 and Li2C6H4O4 anodes is their enhanced thermal stability over C electrodes in 1 M LiPF6 ethylene carbonate-dimethyl carbonate electrolytes, which should result in safer Li-ion cells. Also, as bio-inspired materials, both compds. are the metabolites of arom. hydrocarbon oxidn., and terephthalic acid is available in abundance from the recycling of polyethylene terephthalate.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

An Air-Stable Lithiated Cathode Material Based on a 1,4-Benzenedisulfonate Backbone for Organic Li-Ion Batteries. J. Mater. Chem. A 2018, 6 (39), 19182– 19189,  DOI: 10.1039/C8TA07097K

        An air-stable lithiated cathode material based on a 1,4-benzenedisulfonate backbone for organic Li-ion batteries
        Lakraychi, A. E.; Deunf, E.; Fahsi, K.; Jimenez, P.; Bonnet, J.-P.; Djedaini-Pilard, F.; Becuwe, M.; Poizot, P.; Dolhem, F.
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2018), 6 (39), 19182-19189CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        To meet current market demands as well as emerging environmental concerns there is a need to develop less polluting battery technologies. Org. electrode materials could offer the possibility of prepg. electrode materials from naturally more abundant elements and eco-friendly processes coupled with simplified recycling management. However, the potential use of org. electrode materials for energy storage is still challenging and a lot of developments remain to be achieved. For instance, promoting high-energy Li-ion org. batteries inevitably requires the development of lithiated org. electrode materials which are able to be charged (delithiated) at a high enough potential (>3 V vs. Li+/Li0) - a challenging point rarely discussed in the literature. Here, we evaluate tetralithium 2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-benzenedisulfonate as an air-stable lithiated cathode material for the first time and its reversible Li+ electrochem. extn. Quite interestingly, in comparison with the dicarboxylate counterpart, it was obsd. that the theor. two-electron reaction is readily reached with this org. structure and at an av. operating potential of 650 mV higher.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhs1ygu73N&md5=b0ab9828ef83772835f2de7c203365c2
      46. 46
        Jouhara, A.; Dupré, N.; Gaillot, A. C.; Guyomard, D.; Dolhem, F.; Poizot, P. Raising the Redox Potential in Carboxyphenolate-Based Positive Organic Materials via Cation Substitution. Nat. Commun. 2018, 9 (1), 4401,  DOI: 10.1038/s41467-018-06708-x
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        46
        Raising the redox potential in carboxyphenolate-based positive organic materials via cation substitution
        Jouhara Alia; Dupre Nicolas; Gaillot Anne-Claire; Guyomard Dominique; Poizot Philippe; Dolhem Franck; Dolhem Franck; Poizot Philippe
        Nature communications (2018), 9 (1), 4401 ISSN:.
        Meeting the ever-growing demand for electrical storage devices requires both superior and "greener" battery technologies. Nearly 40 years after the discovery of conductive polymers, long cycling stability in lithium organic batteries has now been achieved. However, the synthesis of high-voltage lithiated organic cathode materials is rather challenging, so very few examples of all-organic lithium-ion cells currently exist. Herein, we present an inventive chemical approach leading to a significant increase of the redox potential of lithiated organic electrode materials. This is achieved by tuning the electronic effects in the redox-active organic skeleton thanks to the permanent presence of a spectator cation in the host structure exhibiting a high ionic potential (or electronegativity). Thus, substituting magnesium (2,5-dilithium-oxy)-terephthalate for lithium (2,5-dilithium-oxy)-terephthalate enables a voltage gain of nearly +800 mV. This compound being also able to act as negative electrode via the carboxylate functional groups, an all-organic symmetric lithium-ion cell exhibiting an output voltage of 2.5 V is demonstrated.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3cvisFSksw%253D%253D&md5=2f90466929cb683d5fc6a0207443cff6
      47. 47
        Song, Z.; Qian, Y.; Gordin, M. L.; Tang, D.; Xu, T.; Otani, M.; Zhan, H.; Zhou, H.; Wang, D. Polyanthraquinone as a Reliable Organic Electrode for Stable and Fast Lithium Storage. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2015, 54 (47), 13947– 13951,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201506673
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        47
        Polyanthraquinone as a Reliable Organic Electrode for Stable and Fast Lithium Storage
        Song, Zhiping; Qian, Yumin; Gordin, Mikhail L.; Tang, Duihai; Xu, Terrence; Otani, Minoru; Zhan, Hui; Zhou, Haoshen; Wang, Donghai
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (47), 13947-13951CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        In spite of recent progress, there is still a lack of reliable org. electrodes for Li storage with high comprehensive performance, esp. in terms of long-term cycling stability. An ideal polymer electrode based on anthraquinone, namely, polyanthraquinone (PAQ), or specifically, poly(1,4-anthraquinone) (P14AQ) and poly(1,5-anthraquinone) (P15AQ) was synthesized. As a lithium-storage cathode, P14AQ showed exceptional performance, including reversible capacity almost equal to the theor. value (260 mA h g-1; >257 mA h g-1 for AQ), a very small voltage gap between the charge and discharge curves (2.18-2.14=0.04 V), stable cycling performance (99.4 % capacity retention after 1000 cycles), and fast-discharge/charge ability (release of 69 % of the low-rate capacity or 64 % of the energy in just 2 min). Exploration of the structure-performance relationship between P14AQ and related materials also provided us with deeper understanding for the design of org. electrodes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFOkt73K&md5=9c7dd23d724ca7ef8a12396186f61d49

        Wang, S.; Wang, L.; Zhang, K.; Zhu, Z.; Tao, Z.; Chen, J. Organic Li4C8H2O6 Nanosheets for Lithium-Ion Batteries. Nano Lett. 2013, 13 (9), 4404– 4409,  DOI: 10.1021/nl402239p
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48
        Organic Li4C8H2O6 Nanosheets for Lithium-Ion Batteries
        Wang, Shiwen; Wang, Lijiang; Zhang, Kai; Zhu, Zhiqiang; Tao, Zhanliang; Chen, Jun
        Nano Letters (2013), 13 (9), 4404-4409CODEN: NALEFD; ISSN:1530-6984. (American Chemical Society)
        Org. tetralithium salts of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (Li4C8H2O6) with the morphologies of bulk, nanoparticles, and nanosheets were studied as the active materials of either pos. or neg. electrode of rechargeable lithium-ion batteries. In the electrolyte of LiPF6 dissolved in ethylene carbonate (EC) and di-Me carbonate (DMC), reversible two-Li-ion electrochem. reactions are taking place with redox Li4C8H2O6/Li2C8H2O6 at ∼2.6 V for a pos. electrode and Li4C8H2O6/Li6C8H2O6 at ∼0.8 V for a neg. electrode, resp. In the obsd. system, the electrochem. performance of high to low order is nanosheets > nanoparticles > bulk. Remarkably, Li4C8H2O6 nanosheets show the discharge capacities of 223 and 145 mAh/g at 0.1 and 5 C rates, resp. A capacity retention of 95% is sustained after 50 cycles at 0.1 C rate charge/discharge and room temp. Also, charging the sym. cells with Li4C8H2O6 nanosheets as the initial active materials of both pos. and neg. electrodes produces all-org. LIBs with an av. operation voltage of 1.8 V and an energy d. of ∼130 Wh/kg, enlightening the design and application of org. Li-reservoir compds. with nanostructures for all org. LIBs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlChsrrL&md5=d7e91827ab31cac4416d0479d5f3e09e
      49. 49
        Luo, C.; Huang, R.; Kevorkyants, R.; Pavanello, M.; He, H.; Wang, C. Self-Assembled Organic Nanowires for High Power Density Lithium Ion Batteries. Nano Lett. 2014, 14 (3), 1596– 1602,  DOI: 10.1021/nl500026j
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        49
        Self-Assembled Organic Nanowires for High Power Density Lithium Ion Batteries
        Luo, Chao; Huang, Ruiming; Kevorkyants, Ruslan; Pavanello, Michele; He, Huixin; Wang, Chunsheng
        Nano Letters (2014), 14 (3), 1596-1602CODEN: NALEFD; ISSN:1530-6984. (American Chemical Society)
        The electroactive org. materials are promising alternatives to inorg. electrode materials for the new generation of green Li-ion batteries due to their sustainability, environmental benignity, and low cost. Croconic acid disodium salt (CADS) was used as Li-ion battery electrode, and CADS org. wires with different diams. were fabricated through a facile synthetic route using antisolvent crystn. method to overcome the challenges of low electronic cond. of CADS and lithiation induced strain. The CADS nanowire exhibits much better electrochem. performance than its crystal bulk material and microwire counterpart. CADS nanowire with a diam. of 150 nm delivers a reversible capability of 177 mA-h g-1 at a c.d. of 0.2 C and retains capacity of 170 mA-h g-1 after 110 charge/discharge cycles. The nanowire structure also remarkably enhances the kinetics of croconic acid disodium salt. The CADS nanowire retains 50% of the 0.1 C capacity even when the c.d. increases to 6 C. But the crystal bulk and microwire material completely lose their capacities when the c.d. merely increases to 2 C. Such a high rate performance of CADS nanowire is attributed to its short ion diffusion pathway and large surface area, which enable fast ion and electron transport in the electrode. The theor. calcn. suggests that lithiation of CADS experiences an ion exchange process. The Na ions in CADS will be gradually replaced by Li ions during the lithiation and delithiation of CADS electrode, which is confirmed by inductively coupled plasma test.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXis1ejsbs%253D&md5=58e87286214bf8361bbd79224bd73bec
      50. 50
        Lu, Y.; Hou, X.; Miao, L.; Li, L.; Shi, R.; Liu, L.; Chen, J. Cyclohexanehexone with Ultrahigh Capacity as Cathode Materials for Lithium-Ion Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2019, 58 (21), 7020– 7024,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201902185
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Cyclohexanehexone with Ultrahigh Capacity as Cathode Materials for Lithium-Ion Batteries
        Lu, Yong; Hou, Xuesen; Miao, Licheng; Li, Lin; Shi, Ruijuan; Liu, Luojia; Chen, Jun
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2019), 58 (21), 7020-7024CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Org. carbonyl compds. show potential as cathode materials for Li-ion batteries (LIBs) but the limited capacities (<600 mA h g-1) and high soly. in electrolyte restrict their further applications. Herein the authors report the synthesis and application of cyclohexanehexone (C6O6), which exhibits an ultrahigh capacity of 902 mA h g-1 with an av. voltage of 1.7 V at 20 mA g-1 in LIBs (corresponding to a high energy d. of 1533 Wh kg-1C6O6). A preliminary cycling test shows that C6O6 displays a capacity retention of 82% after 100 cycles at 50 mA g-1 because of the limited soly. in high-polarity ionic liq. electrolyte. Also, the combination of DFT calcns. and exptl. techniques, such as Raman and IR spectroscopy, demonstrates the electrochem. active C=O groups during discharge and charge processes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXnslehsb4%253D&md5=f65f03bb60af4493e7c7dfb471fab6e4
      51. 51
        Kwon, J. E.; Hyun, C. S.; Ryu, Y. J.; Lee, J.; Min, D. J.; Park, M. J.; An, B. K.; Park, S. Y. Triptycene-Based Quinone Molecules Showing Multi-Electron Redox Reactions for Large Capacity and High Energy Organic Cathode Materials in Li-Ion Batteries. J. Mater. Chem. A 2018, 6 (7), 3134– 3140,  DOI: 10.1039/C7TA09968A
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        51
        Triptycene-based quinone molecules showing multi-electron redox reactions for large capacity and high energy organic cathode materials in Li-ion batteries
        Kwon, Ji Eon; Hyun, Chang-Seok; Ryu, Young Jun; Lee, Joungphil; Min, Dong Joo; Park, Moon Jeong; An, Byeong-Kwan; Park, Soo Young
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2018), 6 (7), 3134-3140CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Org. redox-active mols. have attracted great attention for next generation electrode materials due to their promising advantages of low cost, natural abundance, environmental friendliness, and structural diversity. Here we propose a new mol. design strategy to achieve both large specific capacity and high energy org. cathode materials for Li-ion batteries using a triptycene scaffold as a minimal linker between the redox-active units. The triptycene mol. bearing three benzoquinone (BQ) units in a rigid tripod structure exhibits five-electron redox reactions that practically provide a specific capacity as high as 387 mA h/g in Li-ion coin cells. By combining electrochem. analyses with theor. DFT calcns., we figure out that the 3-D arrangements of BQ units in triptycene not only facilitate a highly reversible access to a large no. of redox states but also raise the redox potential. Due to the large capacity and the increased redox potential, the triptycene electrode can deliver a specific energy up to 1032 W h/kg at 0.1C-rate, which is close to two times the specific energy of the conventional inorg. cathode materials. It is also demonstrated that the cycling performance of triptycenes can be greatly improved by fabricating nanocomposite materials with the ordered mesoporous carbon CMK3.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtVKkt7g%253D&md5=a50f62cdb71b55f562e41f4040aaed52
      52. 52
        Lee, J.; Kim, H.; Park, M. J. Long-Life, High-Rate Lithium-Organic Batteries Based on Naphthoquinone Derivatives. Chem. Mater. 2016, 28 (7), 2408– 2416,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b00624
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52
        Long-Life, High-Rate Lithium-Organic Batteries Based on Naphthoquinone Derivatives
        Lee, Joungphil; Kim, Hoon; Park, Moon Jeong
        Chemistry of Materials (2016), 28 (7), 2408-2416CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        We report the facile synthesis of new naphthoquinone (NQ) derivs. for use in lithium-org. batteries to improve performance. The rational design of these NQ derivs. is based on theor. calcns. Our lithium-org. batteries demonstrate remarkable charge-discharge properties, for example, a high discharge capacity of 250 mAh g-1 (363 mAh cm-3), discharge potential plateaus in the range of 2.3-2.5 V, and 99% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 0.2C. In particular, the batteries had excellent rate performance up to 50C with reversible redox behavior, unlike most other org. cathode materials. The key to success was a simple mol. substitution, addn. of amino groups at the 2- and 3- positions of the NQ ring, yielding 2,3-diamino-1,4-naphthoquinone (DANQ). DANQ has an exceptionally low band gap of 2.7 eV and greater than 20-fold enhancement in the lithium diffusion rate compared to unmodified NQ. The fundamental shortcoming of the org. mols., i.e., their soly. in the electrolyte, was resolved by covalent linking of the amino groups to the surfaces of the cathode framework. The cyclization of amino groups in DANQ yielded 1H-naphtho[2,3-d]imidazole-4,9-dione (IMNQ), enabled us to achieve a 0.15 V enhancement in the redox potential owing to the delocalized electron distribution in the heteroarom. ring. Our work suggests that NQ derivs. with modulated charge/ion transport properties are a viable alternative to the more widely studied lithium metal oxides.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XktFaqtL4%253D&md5=e18f6937d01edece20d0df9b0377af4f
      53. 53
        Song, Z.; Zhan, H.; Zhou, Y. Polyimides: Promising Energy-Storage Materials. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2010, 49 (45), 8444– 8448,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201002439
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        53
        Polyimides: promising energy-storage materials
        Song, Zhiping; Zhan, Hui; Zhou, Yunhong
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (45), 8444-8448, S8444/1-S8444/3CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Use of polyimides as cathode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries was proposed for the first time. Although they are regarded as insulators, the five polyimide samples are all electrochem. active; they all benefit from the good reaction reversibility of the imide group and the stable polymer framework. The two-electron transfer of each monomer unit results in a specific discharge capacity of around 200 mAhg-1, a discharge voltage of 2.0-2.5 V, and a coulomb efficiency close to 100%. Moreover, the intrinsic stability and insoly. of the polyimide ensures that it is not dissolved in the electrolyte, and thus allows cyclability. Since polyimide is hydrolyzable under specified conditions, it is environmentally friendly and conforms to the requirements of a "green battery".
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtlGmsrjI&md5=669fe050d3ed05336fbcaf88f529628f

      55. 55
        Pirnat, K.; Bitenc, J.; Vizintin, A.; Krajnc, A.; Tchernychova, E. Indirect Synthesis Route toward Cross-Coupled Polymers for High Voltage Organic Positive Electrodes. Chem. Mater. 2018, 30 (16), 5726– 5732,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.8b02329
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        55
        Indirect Synthesis Route toward Cross-Coupled Polymers for High Voltage Organic Positive Electrodes
        Pirnat, Klemen; Bitenc, Jan; Vizintin, Alen; Krajnc, Andraz; Tchernychova, Elena
        Chemistry of Materials (2018), 30 (16), 5726-5732CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Cross-coupling polymn. using Ni(COD)2 is a simple method to obtain redox active polymers. It requires readily available dihalogenated quinones as starting compds. The authors propose a new synthesis route to obtain a high voltage redox active polymer, poly(9,10-phenanthrenequinone) (PFQ), as a pos. electrode material, because direct polymn. with Ni(COD)2 cannot be used for synthesis of high voltage quinone polymers. Thus, the authors protected the quinone groups with acetyl groups before polymn. reaction, developing an indirect synthesis route. As a pos. electrode material in a Li battery, PFQ shows 400 mV higher voltage (2.54 V vs. Li/Li+) compared to the more known para counterparts, due to the ortho quinone structure. PFQ was tested in several electrolytes, and the best performance was obtained in 1 M trifluoromethanesulfonimide Li salt dissolved in a mixt. of 1,3-dioxolane and dimethoxyethane (1 M LiTFSI/DOL+DME). Also, PFQ redox use was improved by the addn. of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) during polymn. (PFQ/rGO) to obtain 153 mAh/g of specific capacity. The PFQ/rGO composite showed very good capacity retention; 91% of starting capacity was retained after 500 cycles at C/5 coupled with good rate capability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsVChtbrF&md5=3c749de13a081fe7be9991f9863369e9

        Xie, J.; Chen, W.; Long, G.; Gao, W.; Xu, Z. J.; Liu, M.; Zhang, Q. Boosting the Performance of Organic Cathodes through Structure Tuning. J. Mater. Chem. A 2018, 6 (27), 12985– 12991,  DOI: 10.1039/C8TA03857K
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        56
        Boosting the performance of organic cathodes through structure tuning
        Xie, Jian; Chen, Wangqiao; Long, Guankui; Gao, Weibo; Xu, Zhichuan J.; Liu, Ming; Zhang, Qichun
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2018), 6 (27), 12985-12991CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The decisive factor to realize high-capacity rechargeable batteries is the cathode. Since the exptl. capacity of inorg. cathodes is usually less than 200 mA h g-1, searching for new cathode materials to boost the capacity is highly desirable. Here, we design and synthesize two novel org. cathodes, poly(pyrene-4,5,9,10-tetraone) (PPTO) and poly(2,7-ethynylpyrene-4,5,9,10-tetraone) (PEPTO), based on the highly redox-active pyrene-4,5,9,10-tetraone. Due to their four Li+ ion intake characteristics, both cathodes show a large reversible capacity of 234 & 244 mA h g-1 and a high energy d. of up to 530 & 507 W h kg-1, resp. In particular, benefiting from the enhanced conjugation and planarity, PEPTO with the addn. of a carbon-carbon triple bond (C≡C) delivers a significantly improved rate stability at high current densities and an excellent capacity retention of 110 mA h g-1 after 1000 cycles (at 800 mA g-1). Our approach could provide an effective strategy to prep. new org. cathodes for the next generation of high stability and high energy d. org. batteries through structure tuning.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtFyjtbvJ&md5=d78983aa1aa9a0858b2c61de76f55218
